passages.passage_text:
Oil spills in the ocean are cleaned up by using a sorbent to soak up the oil floating on the water's surface. Two studies examined the effectiveness of 4 sorbents: 3 natural (milkweed, cotton, and kenaf) and 1 synthetic (polypropylene).

Before the studies, the following procedures were performed for each sorbent: A 1 g sample of the sorbent was completely dried and then placed in a beaker containing 500 mL of seawater. Ten minutes later, the sample was removed from the beaker and its mass was measured. The mass of seawater the sample had soaked up, mw, was calculated. The sample was discarded.

Study 1: The following procedures were performed for each sorbent: A 500 mL volume of seawater was poured into each of 5 identical 1 L beakers. A different mass of heavy crude oil—10 g, 20 g, 30 g, 40 g, or 50 g—was added to each beaker. A 1 g sample of completely dried sorbent was added to each beaker. The beakers were gently shaken for 10 min. Immediately after the beakers were shaken, each sample was removed from its beaker, and its final mass, mf, was measured. The mass of oil that had been soaked up by the sample, mo, was calculated as follows: mo = mf - mw - 1g. The results, given in grams of oil soaked up per gram of sorbent, are shown in Figure 1.

Study 2: The procedures of Study 1 were repeated except that each sorbent was placed in light crude oil and seawater instead of heavy crude oil and seawater. The results are shown in Figure 2.

Figures adapted from Hyung-Min Choi and Rinn M. Cloud, "Natural Sorbents in Oil Spill Cleanup." ©1992 by the American Chemical Society.

passages.title: Acid Solutions: Surface Tension and pH
passages.passage_text:
Three experiments were performed to study the surface tension and pH of colorless aqueous solutions of 4 different acids: nitric acid, formic acid, chloroacetic acid, and acetic acid. A liquid's surface tension in millijoules per square meter (mJ/m²) is equal to the energy in millijoules required to increase the surface area of the liquid by 1 m².

Experiment 1: Twenty 250 g aqueous solutions—5 of nitric acid, 5 of formic acid, 5 of chloroacetic acid, and 5 of acetic acid—were prepared. Each of the 5 solutions of a given acid had a different percent by mass of acid (10%, 20%, 30%, 40%, or 50%). The surface tension of each solution and of distilled H₂O was measured at 25°C (see Figure 1).

Experiment 2: One gram of each of the 50% by mass acid solutions prepared in Experiment 1 was diluted with distilled H₂O to a total mass of 10 g, forming four 5% by mass acid solutions. Six drops of methyl violet, a pH indicator, were added to each of these solutions. (A pH indicator is a compound whose color is determined by the pH of the solution in which the compound is dissolved.) The color of each resulting solution at 25°C was recorded (see Table 1).

Experiment 3: One gram of each of the 20 solutions prepared in Experiment 1 was diluted with distilled H₂O to a total mass of 10 g. The pH of each resulting solution was measured at 25°C (see Figure 2).

Table 1 adapted from Kenneth E. Kolb and Doris Kolb, "Illustrating the Inductive Effect on Acid Strength of Carboxylic Acids." ©1989 by Division of Chemical Education, Inc., American Chemical Society.

passages.title: Structural Beam Deflection
passages.passage_text:
A structural beam, such as one used in construction, will deflect (bend) when a sufficiently large force is applied perpendicular to the beam's length. Three studies of 12 trials each were performed on the deflection of 2 straight structural beams—a concrete beam and a steel beam—that had identical dimensions.

In each trial, 2 supports were separated by a distance L, measured in centimeters (cm), and a beam was centered on top of the supports. A force, F, measured in kilonewtons (kN), was then applied to the center of the beam, and the maximum deflection of the beam, d, was measured in millimeters (mm). The beam was oriented in either the H configuration or the I configuration.

Study 1: Twelve trials were performed in which L was varied and F was 1 kN. In the first 6 trials, the concrete beam was tested in the H configuration. In the last 6 trials, the concrete beam was tested in the I configuration. Figure 1 shows the results of these trials.

Study 2: In 12 trials, the procedures of Study 1 were repeated, except that the steel beam was tested. Figure 2 shows the results of these trials.

Study 3: Twelve trials were performed in which L was 100 cm and F was varied. In the first 6 trials, the concrete beam was tested in the I configuration. In the last 6 trials, the steel beam was tested in the I configuration. Figure 3 shows the results of these trials.

passages.title: Spring Oscillation Student Viewpoints
passages.passage_text:
A spring with a spring constant k (which indicates the spring's stiffness) is attached to a cube of mass M and then to a wall. The cube initially rests at Point Q on a frictionless horizontal surface. The cube is pulled from Point Q to Point P, stretching the spring. Once released, the cube oscillates between Points P and R, each a distance A (the amplitude) from Point Q.

The frequency, f, is the number of times per second the cube completes a cycle (travels from P to R, then back to P); v is the average speed of the cube during 1 cycle.

The teacher asks each of 3 students to predict which combination of the independent variables k, M, and A would produce the highest f.

Student 1: As k increases, v decreases, because a stiffer spring moves less freely. Therefore, f decreases because it takes more time for the cube to complete each cycle. As M increases, v decreases, and so f also decreases. As A increases, v increases, because the distance the cube travels during a complete cycle increases. Therefore, f also increases. The highest f would be produced when each of k and M has its least value and A has its greatest value.

Student 2: As k increases, v increases, because the force exerted on the cube by the spring also increases, giving the cube a greater average acceleration and, therefore, a greater v. When v increases, f increases. As M increases, v and f increase, because during the spring's oscillations, the momentum of the cube keeps its average speed from decreasing. As A increases, the force exerted on the cube by the spring increases, so v, f, and average acceleration increase. The highest f would be produced when each of k, M, and A has its greatest value.

Student 3: As k increases, the potential energy stored in the spring just before its release increases, so both v and f also increase. As M increases, the cube's average acceleration decreases, and so both v and f decrease. As A increases, both the cube's average acceleration and v increase, but so does the total distance through which the cube must travel. Consequently, f remains the same. The highest f would be produced when k has its greatest value and M has its least value.

passages.title: Moving Rocks in the Playa
passages.passage_text:
In a particular playa (relatively flat, dry desert basin) evidence shows that some large rocks have moved along the surface, leaving shallow trails in the clay sediment, some up to several hundred meters long. Three scientists provided explanations for how these rocks moved.

Scientist 1:
In the spring, snowmelt from surrounding mountains runs downhill and collects in the playa. At night, cold temperatures cause this water to freeze around the rocks. When temperatures rise again, the ice begins to melt, leaving a layer of mud on the surface and ice "rafts" around the rocks. The buoyancy of the ice rafts floats the rocks on top of the mud such that even light winds can then push the rocks along the surface. Evidence of this lifting is seen in that the trails left by rocks are both shallow and only about 2/3 as wide as the rocks themselves. Due to the combination of ice, mud, and light winds, the rocks are able to move several hundred meters in a few days.

Scientist 2:
Snowmelt from surrounding mountains does collect in the playa during the spring. However, the temperature in the playa does not get cold enough for ice to form. When the playa's surface gets wet, the top layer of clay transforms into a slick, muddy film. In addition, dormant algae present in the dry clay begin to grow rapidly when the clay becomes wet. The presence of mud and algae reduces friction between the rocks and the clay. Even so, relatively strong winds are required to push the rocks along the wet surface, forming trails. Due to the combination of mud, algae, and strong winds, the rocks are able to move several hundred meters in a few hours.

Scientist 3:
Water does collect in the playa, producing mud and ice. However, neither mud nor ice is responsible for the rocks' movements. The playa is located along a fault line between tectonic plates. Minor vertical shifts in the plates cause the rocks to move downhill, leaving trails. Due to the combination of tectonic plate movement and strong winds, the rocks are able to move only a few meters over several years.

passages.title: CO2 Gas Production from Diet Cola
passages.passage_text:
When certain substances are added to diet cola, CO2 gas is produced, generating a foam. Two experiments were done to study this process.

In each trial, an apparatus like that shown in Figure 1 was used as follows: A jar was nearly filled with H2O and fitted with a 2-holed lid. One end of a tube (Tube B) was inserted through one of the holes and submerged. The other end of Tube B was placed in an empty graduated cylinder. Another tube (Tube A) was inserted through the other hole in the lid. A certain solid substance was inserted into the other end of Tube A, and the substance was secured by a clamp. Tube A was then attached to a freshly opened bottle containing 355 mL of diet cola. The clamp was removed, releasing the substance into the diet cola. The foam that was produced traveled into the jar, and liquid was transferred into the cylinder. The mass of CO2 produced was calculated based on the volume of liquid that was measured in the cylinder after foaming had ceased.

Experiment 1:
In each of Trials 1-4, a different 1 of 4 substances of equal mass—a piece of chalk, a sugar cube, a fruit-flavored piece of candy, or a mint-flavored piece of candy—was added to a bottle of diet cola at 3°C.

Table 1 shows volume of liquid in cylinder (mL) and mass of CO2 produced (g) for each trial:
Trial 1 (chalk): 699 mL, 1.36 g
Trial 2 (sugar cube): 570 mL, 1.11 g
Trial 3 (fruit candy): 525 mL, 1.02 g
Trial 4 (mint candy): 631 mL, 1.23 g

Experiment 2:
In each of Trials 5-8, Trial 4 from Experiment 1 was repeated, except that the temperature of the diet cola was different in each trial.

Table 2 shows temperature (°C), volume of liquid in cylinder (mL), and mass of CO2 produced (g):
Trial 5: 10°C, 598 mL, 1.13 g
Trial 6: 25°C, 539 mL, 0.969 g
Trial 7: 45°C, 501 mL, 0.844 g
Trial 8: 60°C, 476 mL, 0.766 g

passages.title: Effects of pH and Nickel on Plant Growth
passages.passage_text:
Scientists studied the effects of pH and of nickel concentration on plant growth and on the uptake of iron and zinc by plants. Recently germinated seedlings of Species M and Species U were fed 1 of 12 nutrient solutions (Solutions 1-12) for 8 days and then were harvested. Solutions 1-12 differed only in pH and/or nickel concentration.

Table 1 shows, for each species, the average dry mass of the plants that were fed each nutrient solution.

Solutions and average dry mass (g) for Species M and Species U:
Solution 1: pH 7, 0 μM nickel - M: 33.9 g, U: 10.7 g
Solution 2: pH 7, 5 μM nickel - M: 28.8 g, U: 10.7 g
Solution 3: pH 7, 10 μM nickel - M: 23.8 g, U: 9.6 g
Solution 4: pH 7, 15 μM nickel - M: 18.7 g, U: 8.5 g
Solution 5: pH 6, 0 μM nickel - M: 33.9 g, U: 9.2 g
Solution 6: pH 6, 5 μM nickel - M: 28.8 g, U: 9.2 g
Solution 7: pH 6, 10 μM nickel - M: 23.8 g, U: 8.1 g
Solution 8: pH 6, 15 μM nickel - M: 18.7 g, U: 7.0 g
Solution 9: pH 5, 0 μM nickel - M: 27.8 g, U: 7.7 g
Solution 10: pH 5, 5 μM nickel - M: 22.7 g, U: 7.7 g
Solution 11: pH 5, 10 μM nickel - M: 17.6 g, U: 6.6 g
Solution 12: pH 5, 15 μM nickel - M: 12.4 g, U: 5.4 g

Figure 1 shows, for each species, the average iron content and the average zinc content of the plants that were fed Solutions 1-4.

For Solutions 1-4 (0, 5, 10, 15 μM nickel):
Species M iron content (μg/g): ~400, ~300, ~200, ~100
Species M zinc content (μg/g): ~100, ~150, ~200, ~400
Species U iron content (μg/g): ~400, ~400, ~400, ~400
Species U zinc content (μg/g): ~400, ~500, ~650, ~900

passages.title: Ammonia Production
passages.passage_text:
Ammonia (NH3) can be produced according to the chemical equation:
N2 + 3H2 ⇌ 2NH3

The equilibrium arrow (⇌) indicates that this reaction proceeds in both directions until it is at equilibrium, so that both the forward reaction (production of NH3) and the backward reaction (production of N2 and H2) occur at the same rate. Equilibrium can be shifted forward or backward by changing the temperature, pressure, or concentration of reactants or products.

Two experiments were done using an apparatus with a reactor and condenser. In each trial, Steps 1-4 occurred:
1. A fresh catalyst (Catalyst W, X, Y, or Z), 160 kg of H2, and 745 kg of N2 were placed in the reactor.
2. The H2 and N2 reacted at a constant temperature and a constant pressure until equilibrium was established.
3. A mixture of NH3 and any unreacted H2 and N2 flowed through Pipe A to a -50°C condenser at 1 atmosphere (atm) of pressure.
4. NH3 condensed and exited the apparatus. Any unreacted H2 and N2 flowed into Pipe B, returning to the reactor.

Steps 2-4 reoccurred in cycles until no more H2 and N2 returned from the condenser.

Experiment 1:
A set of 9 trials was conducted with each of the 4 catalysts. For each set, the pressure was 150 atm; within each set, the temperature was different for each trial. Figure 1 shows, for each trial, the number of cycles of Steps 2-4.

At 300°C, 350°C, 400°C, 450°C, 500°C respectively:
Catalyst W: ~5, ~10, ~20, ~35, ~48 cycles
Catalyst X: ~5, ~8, ~15, ~25, ~37 cycles
Catalyst Y: ~7, ~12, ~22, ~32, ~42 cycles
Catalyst Z: ~5, ~10, ~18, ~30, ~45 cycles

Experiment 2:
Four sets of 9 trials each were conducted with Catalyst Z. For each set, the temperature was different; within each set, the pressure was different for each trial. Figure 2 shows, for each trial, the amount of NH3 produced in the first cycle of Steps 2-4.

At 100, 150, 200, 250, 300 atm respectively:
300°C: ~150, ~250, ~350, ~450, ~550 kg
350°C: ~200, ~300, ~400, ~500, ~600 kg
400°C: ~250, ~350, ~450, ~500, ~550 kg
450°C: ~300, ~375, ~425, ~450, ~500 kg

passages.title: Sound Wave Attenuation
passages.passage_text:
As a sound wave travels through a medium, the wave becomes attenuated (loses energy). The attenuation coefficient, α, is the rate at which the wave's intensity level (a measure of sound volume) decreases with distance as a result of this energy loss; the greater the value of α, the greater the decrease in intensity level with distance.

Figure 1 shows, for waves of 3 different frequencies (in hertz, Hz), how α (in decibels per kilometer, dB/km) varies with temperature in air at 10% relative humidity.

At temperatures from -20°C to 100°C:
200 Hz wave: α ranges from ~1 to ~3 dB/km, with peak around 35°C
500 Hz wave: α ranges from ~3 to ~9.5 dB/km, with peak around 10°C
1,000 Hz wave: α ranges from ~6 to ~21 dB/km, with peak around 10°C

Figure 2 shows, for waves of 3 different frequencies, how α varies with relative humidity in air at 20°C.

At relative humidity from 10% to 90%:
200 Hz wave: α decreases from ~2.5 to ~0.5 dB/km
500 Hz wave: α peaks at ~12 dB/km around 15% humidity, then decreases
1,000 Hz wave: α peaks at ~18 dB/km around 15% humidity, then decreases to ~7 dB/km

passages.title: Effects of Sweeteners on Rats
passages.passage_text:
Three studies compared the effects of 5 sweeteners (Sweeteners Q-U) on food consumption by rats and on the concentrations of leptin and ghrelin (hormones that regulate appetite) in the blood of rats. Sweeteners Q-U differ only in the percent by mass of fructose and of glucose.

Table 1 shows percent by mass:
Sweetener Q: 0% fructose, 100% glucose
Sweetener R: 42% fructose, 58% glucose
Sweetener S: 50% fructose, 50% glucose
Sweetener T: 55% fructose, 45% glucose
Sweetener U: 100% fructose, 0% glucose

Study 1:
Each of 5 groups (Groups 1-5) of rats was assigned a solution having a 100 g/L concentration of 1 of the 5 sweeteners. Each rat was placed in a separate cage and provided unlimited access to the assigned sweetener solution and to solid food for 56 days.

Table 2 shows amount consumed per rat per day:
Group 1 (Q): 73 mL solution, 9 g solid food
Group 2 (R): 55 mL solution, 14 g solid food
Group 3 (S): 52 mL solution, 16 g solid food
Group 4 (T): 48 mL solution, 18 g solid food
Group 5 (U): 29 mL solution, 23 g solid food

On Day 56, blood was collected from each rat for analysis in Studies 2 and 3.

Study 2:
A 1 mL blood sample from each rat was placed in a separate test tube containing 0.2 mL of Indicator N (which reacts with leptin to form a blue dye). The concentration of blue dye in each tube was directly proportional to the leptin concentration in the blood sample.

Table 3 shows leptin concentration per sample (pM):
Group 1 (Q): 804 pM
Group 2 (R): 622 pM
Group 3 (S): 553 pM
Group 4 (T): 475 pM
Group 5 (U): 251 pM

Study 3:
Study 2 was repeated, except that Indicator P (which reacts with ghrelin to form a yellow dye) was used instead of Indicator N. The concentration of yellow dye in each tube was directly proportional to the ghrelin concentration in the blood sample.

Table 4 shows ghrelin concentration per sample (pM):
Group 1 (Q): 852 pM
Group 2 (R): 1,125 pM
Group 3 (S): 1,279 pM
Group 4 (T): 1,450 pM
Group 5 (U): 1,758 pM

passages.title: Molar Volume of Gases
passages.introduction: Study of molar volumes of different gases at various temperatures and pressures
passages.passage_text:
The molar volume of a gas is the volume occupied by 1 mole (mol; 6 × 10²³ atoms or molecules) of that gas at a given pressure and temperature.

Table 1 shows how the molar volume, in L, of each of 6 gases—helium (He), neon (Ne), argon (Ar), hydrogen (H₂), nitrogen (N₂), and oxygen (O₂)—varies with pressure, in atmospheres (atm), at a temperature of 273 kelvins (K).

Table 2 shows how the molar volume of each of the 6 gases varies with temperature at a pressure of 1.00 atm.

tables.title: Table 1: Molar Volume at Different Pressures
tables.subtitle: Molar volume (L) at 273 K

tables.title: Table 2: Molar Volume at Different Temperatures
tables.subtitle: Molar volume (L) at 1.00 atm

passages.title: Plant Stem Color Genetics
passages.introduction: Four students propose explanations for green vs. purple stems in plants
passages.passage_text:
Four students observed that in a population of land plants, Population A, a plant could have a green stem or a purple stem. Each student proposed an explanation for this observation.

Student 1
All plants in Population A produce the green pigment chlorophyll. If a plant receives 8 hr or more of sunlight each day, it also produces a purple pigment, causing its stem to be purple. If a plant receives less than 8 hr of sunlight each day, it does not produce this purple pigment, so its stem is green. All plants in Population A are genetically identical, so they all have the ability to produce both pigments.

Student 2
All plants in Population A produce the green pigment chlorophyll. If a plant receives too little phosphorus (a nutrient), it also produces a purple pigment, causing its stem to be purple. If a plant receives enough phosphorus, it does not produce this purple pigment, so its stem is green. All plants in Population A are genetically identical, so they all have the ability to produce both pigments. The amount of sunlight received by a plant does not affect stem color.

Student 3
All plants in Population A produce the green pigment chlorophyll. The production of purple pigment is determined by Gene Q, which has 2 alleles (Q and q) and 3 possible genotypes (QQ, Qq, and qq). A plant with either the Gene Q genotype QQ or the Gene Q genotype Qq produces the purple pigment, causing its stem to be purple. A plant with the Gene Q genotype qq does not produce this purple pigment, so its stem is green. The amount of sunlight or nutrients received by a plant does not affect stem color.

Student 4
All plants in Population A produce the green pigment chlorophyll. The production of purple pigment is determined by Gene Q, which has 2 alleles (Q and q) and 3 possible genotypes (QQ, Qq, and qq). A plant with the Gene Q genotype qq produces the purple pigment, causing its stem to be purple. A plant with either the Gene Q genotype QQ or the Gene Q genotype Qq does not produce this purple pigment, so its stem is green. The amount of sunlight or nutrients received by a plant does not affect stem color.

passages.title: Buoyant Forces Study
passages.introduction: Studies on buoyant forces using different fluids and objects
passages.passage_text:
When an object is submerged in a fluid, the object displaces a volume of fluid equal to the object's submerged volume. The fluid exerts an upward buoyant force on the object that is equal in magnitude to the weight of the displaced fluid. The object floats if the buoyant force equals the object's weight.

A group of students conducted 2 studies on buoyant forces using 3 fluids—water, Fluid A, and Fluid B—having densities of 1.0 g/cm³, 1.25 g/cm³, and 1.50 g/cm³, respectively.

Study 1: The students placed a 10 cm long cylinder in a container of water and measured the length of the portion that was submerged. They repeated this with Fluid A and Fluid B.

Study 2: The students placed stones (Stone X, Y, or Z) in a net tied to a spring balance, recorded the weight W, then submerged each stone in each fluid and calculated the buoyant force as W minus the submerged weight.

passages.title: Bacterial Survival After Lyophilization
passages.introduction: Study on Species C bacteria survival during transport
passages.passage_text:
Samples of Species C bacteria must often be transported from the areas in which they are collected. During transport, the samples are typically packed in ice to keep them alive. However, ice is not always available where the samples are collected. Scientists studied how lyophilization (a freeze-drying process that doesn't require ice) followed by incubation affects the survival of 2 strains (Strain E and Strain V2) of Species C bacteria.

Experiment 1: The scientists placed a 100 μL sample of a nutrient medium containing 4 × 10⁶ Strain E elementary bodies into each of 8 sterile test tubes. The sample in each tube was then lyophilized, and each tube was sealed. Two tubes were incubated at each of four temperatures: 4°C, 20°C, 30°C, and 37°C. One week after incubation began, the percent survival was determined for one tube at each temperature. One month after incubation began, the percent survival was determined for the remaining tube at each temperature.

Experiment 2: The procedure from Experiment 1 was repeated using Strain V2 instead of Strain E.

passages.title: Mendelian Genetics in Plant Breeding
passages.introduction: Study of inheritance patterns in flowering plants using controlled crosses.
passages.passage_text:
Gregor Mendel's principles of inheritance explain how traits are passed from parents to offspring through discrete units called genes. Modern plant breeding relies heavily on these principles.

Experiment 1: Researchers crossed pure-breeding purple-flowered plants with pure-breeding white-flowered plants. All F1 offspring had purple flowers, suggesting that purple is dominant over white.

Experiment 2: F1 plants were allowed to self-pollinate to produce an F2 generation. The results showed a 3:1 ratio of purple to white flowers, confirming Mendel's predictions for a simple dominant-recessive trait.

Table 3 shows the results of both generations, demonstrating classic Mendelian inheritance patterns. The researchers also performed test crosses to verify the genotypes of the F1 plants.

These experiments confirm that flower color in this species follows simple Mendelian inheritance, with purple (P) being dominant over white (p).

tables.data:
Generation | Purple Flowers | White Flowers | Ratio
F1 | 156 | 0 | All purple
F2 | 423 | 141 | 3:1
tables.title: Table 3: Inheritance of Flower Color

passages.title: pH and Chemical Indicators
passages.introduction: Investigation of pH changes in various solutions and indicator responses.
passages.passage_text:
The pH scale measures the acidity or alkalinity of solutions, ranging from 0 (most acidic) to 14 (most alkaline), with 7 being neutral. Each unit represents a 10-fold change in hydrogen ion concentration.

Experiment 1: Researchers measured the pH of various hydrochloric acid (HCl) solutions at different concentrations to establish the relationship between concentration and acidity.

Experiment 2: Different chemical indicators were tested to determine their color changes at various pH levels. Indicators are substances that change color depending on the pH of the solution.

Table 5 shows the relationship between HCl concentration and pH, demonstrating the logarithmic nature of the pH scale.

The experiments confirmed that as acid concentration increases, pH decreases proportionally on the logarithmic scale. Common substances like lemon juice (pH ≈ 2), pure water (pH = 7), and baking soda (pH ≈ 9) were used as reference points.

passages.title: Primary Amines Chemistry
passages.passage_text:
Primary amines (PAs) are compounds containing an amino (NH₂) group bound to a hydrocarbon chain (a group made up of C and H atoms). Table 1 lists, for each of 5 PAs, the chemical formula, molecular mass (mass of 1 molecule) in atomic mass units (amu), melting point (MP), and boiling point (BP).

[Table 1 shows: 1-propanamine (59 amu, MP -85°C, BP 47°C), 1-butanamine (73 amu, MP -49°C, BP 77°C), 1-pentanamine (87 amu, MP -55°C, BP 104°C), 1-hexanamine (101 amu, MP -23°C, BP 131°C), 1-heptanamine (115 amu, MP -18°C, BP 156°C)]

Table 2 lists, for each of the 5 PAs, the flash point (the lowest temperature at which a flammable mixture is formed in the air above a liquid) and the temperature at which the vapor pressure (the pressure exerted by a vapor in equilibrium with its liquid state) equals 0.1 kPa, 1 kPa, 10 kPa, and 100 kPa.

[Table 2 shows flash points and vapor pressure temperatures for all 5 PAs]

Tables adapted from W. M. Haynes, ed., CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics on CD-ROM, Version 2011. ©2011 by CRC Press, LLC.

passages.title: Amino Acid Production on Earth
passages.passage_text:
The amino acid molecules necessary for life are thought to have been produced on Earth before organisms were present. Amino acids can be produced through chemical reactions among ammonia (NH₃), methane (CH₄), hydrogen (H₂), and water (H₂O). Four hypotheses have been proposed to describe the conditions that were responsible for the production of amino acids on Earth.

Hypothesis 1
Amino acids were introduced to Earth by meteors containing NH₃, CH₄, H₂, and H₂O. If the reactions among these 4 substances are provided enough energy, amino acids can be produced. As meteors containing these substances entered Earth's atmosphere, the substances were rapidly heated by friction, and this heat resulted in immediate amino acid production on the surface of the meteors.

Hypothesis 2
Hypothesis 1 is correct that meteors brought NH₃, CH₄, H₂, and H₂O to Earth; however, amino acid production did not occur on the meteors. Once a meteor containing these substances entered Earth's atmosphere, the substances were released into the atmosphere. Meteors continued to enter the atmosphere over hundreds of millions of years. The concentration of these substances in the atmosphere eventually became high enough for the reactions that produce amino acids to occur. The energy provided to these reactions was UV light energy from the sun.

Hypothesis 3
Meteors had nothing to do with the production of amino acids. Thermal vents (cracks in the floors of Earth's oceans) allowed magma from Earth's crust to seep into the ocean. The magma caused some of the ocean water to boil. Since ocean water contains dissolved NH₃, CH₄, and H₂, these substances were released into the atmosphere (along with H₂O) upon boiling. Then, UV light from the sun provided the energy for these substances to react to produce amino acids.

Hypothesis 4
Magma from thermal vents did not provide enough energy to cause ocean water to boil; however, the magma did provide enough energy to cause the NH₃, CH₄, and H₂ dissolved in ocean water to react with the ocean water, producing amino acids. These reactions occurred near the thermal vents.

passages.title: Sunscreen UV Light Absorbance
passages.passage_text:
Ultraviolet (UV) light is harmful to skin. A sunscreen applied to the skin lessens the skin's exposure to the harmful light, such as through absorption of the light. A sunscreen's sun protection factor (SPF) is a measure of its ability to lessen exposure.

Students did 2 experiments to measure the absorbance of UV light by various solutions at 25°C, each solution containing a single sunscreen. To make their measurements, the students used a spectrophotometer (see diagram).

In each trial of the experiments, Steps 1-4 were performed:
1. A solution having a particular sunscreen concentration was prepared.
2. Four mL of the solution was poured into a clear plastic vial, and the vial was placed in the spectrophotometer.
3. A beam of UV light was directed through the solution.
4. The absorbance was measured as the wavelength of the UV light was varied from 290 nanometers (nm; 1 nm = 10⁻⁹ m) through 400 nm. (Note: UVB light has wavelengths from 290 nm to 320 nm; UVA light has wavelengths from 320 nm to 400 nm.)

Experiment 1
Five sunscreens were tested. Each sunscreen had a different SPF, but the concentration of each sunscreen in solution was the same (0.10 g/L). The results are shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1: Graph showing absorbance vs wavelength (nm) for different SPF values

Experiment 2
Three sunscreens—the SPF 8 sunscreen, the SPF 15 sunscreen, and the SPF 50 sunscreen—were tested, each at 3 different concentrations in solution (0.025 g/L, 0.050 g/L, and 0.20 g/L). Table 1 shows the maximum absorbance by each solution.

Table 1
Maximum absorbance at a sunscreen concentration of:
SPF | 0.025 g/L | 0.050 g/L | 0.20 g/L
8   | 0.20      | 0.28      | 1.17
15  | 0.22      | 0.46      | 1.74
50  | 0.31      | 0.55      | 2.25

passages.title: Gas Exchange in the Human Body
passages.passage_text:
In the human body, O₂ and CO₂ are exchanged between the lungs and the blood and between the blood and the tissues as indicated in Figure 1. These exchanges occur by the diffusion of each gas from a region where its partial pressure (the pressure contributed by a single gas) is higher to a region where its partial pressure is lower. The figure gives the partial pressures Po₂ and Pco₂ in the lung alveoli (sacs), in the tissue cells, and in the blood of a healthy resting person at sea level.

Figure 1:
Atmosphere: Po₂ = 152 mm Hg, Pco₂ = 0.3 mm Hg
Lung alveoli: Po₂ = 104 mm Hg, Pco₂ = 40 mm Hg
Lung capillaries (leaving): Po₂ = 100 mm Hg, Pco₂ = 40 mm Hg
Right side of heart: Po₂ = 40 mm Hg, Pco₂ = 46 mm Hg
Left side of heart: Po₂ = 100 mm Hg, Pco₂ = 40 mm Hg
Tissue capillaries: Po₂ = 40 mm Hg, Pco₂ = 46 mm Hg
Tissue cells: Po₂ < 40 mm Hg, Pco₂ > 46 mm Hg

Figure 2 shows how alveolar Po₂ and Pco₂ vary with alveolar ventilation (volume of air per unit time available to the alveoli for gas exchange).

Figure 2: Graph showing alveolar Po₂ and Pco₂ (mm Hg) vs alveolar ventilation (L/min)

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.5 - Pronouns
lessons.content:
Pronoun questions make up about 9% of the ACT English Test—roughly 7 questions per test! You'll need to know how to select the proper pronoun based on case ("he" vs. "him" or "who" vs. "whom"), make sure that a pronoun agrees with the word it's replacing, and spot ambiguous pronouns.

1. Pronoun Case: Subject vs. Object

  • Pronouns are words that stand in for a person, place, or thing
    • Pronouns have two cases: subject and object
    • The pronoun's role in the sentence (subject or object) dictates which type is correct

Subject Pronouns vs. Object Pronouns

  • Subject pronouns (I, we, you, he, she, it, they, who) are used when the pronoun is doing the action
    • Example: "They went to the street festival on Saturday afternoon."
  • Object pronouns (me, us, you, him, her, it, them, whom) are used when the pronoun is receiving the action
    • Example: "The man handed us a stack of flyers."
  • For simple pronoun case questions, trust your ear

Pronouns in a List

  • Pronouns in lists are tricky because we often say them incorrectly in conversation
    • Ignore the other items in the list and just read the pronoun by itself to tell which is correct
    • Example: "The policeman asked to speak to my friends and me."
    • Test: "The policeman asked to speak to me." ✓ (not "speak to I")
    • Example: "His girlfriend and he went to the hockey game."
    • Test: "He went to the hockey game." ✓ (not "him went")

Pronouns in Prepositional Phrases

  • Pronouns in prepositional phrases are ALWAYS in the object case
    • This rule can be difficult to hear by ear alone, so remember it
    • Example: "The bet between Joe and me was for just five dollars." (not "between Joe and I")
    • Example: "To whom was the award given?" (not "to who")
    • Example: "Jerry claims that a great rivalry exists among Tim, Scott, and him." (not "among...and he")

Who vs. Whom

  • The difference between "who" and "whom" is tested on almost every ACT
    • Technically, "who" is the subject and "whom" is the object
    • But here's the trick you need to memorize:
  • The he/him replacement trick
    • If you can replace the word with "he," "she," or "they" → use "who"
    • If you can replace the word with "him," "her," or "them" → use "whom"
    • You may need to rearrange the sentence, but this trick works for any who vs. whom question
  • Examples
    • "Who stole the apple off the teacher's desk?" → Test: "He stole the apple" ✓ → Use "who"
    • "To whom should I address this letter?" → Test: "I should address this letter to him" ✓ → Use "whom"
    • "Who do you want to win the Bachelor?" → Test: "You want him to win" ✓ → Actually "whom" is correct here!

Who vs. Whom in Descriptive Phrases

  • On difficult questions, who/whom can introduce a phrase describing a person
    • The normal "he/him" trick doesn't work if you look at the entire sentence
    • Instead, look only at the phrase itself
  • Example: "The child whom I invited to the party was very noisy."
    • Look only at the phrase: "whom I invited to the party"
    • Test: "I invited him to the party" ✓ → Use "whom"
  • Example: "The child who was running down the street was very noisy."
    • Look only at the phrase: "who was running down the street"
    • Test: "He was running down the street" ✓ → Use "who"
  • Quick trick: Look at the word right after "who" or "whom"
    • If the word right after is a verb → use "who"
    • If the word right after is a noun → use "whom"

Reflexive Pronouns (myself, yourself, himself...)

  • Reflexive pronouns use the "-self" ending and can only be used when the pronoun refers back to a person or thing elsewhere in the sentence
    • ✓ Correct: "I grabbed three donuts and put them in a box for myself." (refers back to "I")
    • ❌ Incorrect: "I asked my coworker to put three donuts in a box for myself." ("myself" doesn't work because the subject is "my coworker," not "I")
    • ✓ Correct: "I asked my coworker to put three donuts in a box for me."

2. Possessive Pronouns

  • Possessive pronouns show ownership
    • These pronouns must match with the word(s) they're replacing
    • They come in two forms: possessive nouns and possessive adjectives

Possessive Nouns vs. Possessive Adjectives

  • Possessive nouns stand alone: mine, ours, yours, his, hers, its, theirs
    • Example: "That book is mine." (stands alone, not followed by a noun)
  • Possessive adjectives come before a noun: my, our, your, his, her, its, their
    • Example: "That is my book." (comes before the noun "book")

Matching Possessive Pronouns to the Antecedent

  • Possessive pronouns must match the word they're replacing in number (singular vs. plural)
    • ❌ Incorrect: "The entire team went on stage to pick up their trophy."
    • The pronoun refers back to "team," which is singular (remember: group nouns are singular!)
    • ✓ Correct: "The entire team went on stage to pick up its trophy."
  • More examples
    • "Emmanuel and James came back home after forgetting their phones." (plural subjects → "their")
    • "Thousands of tourists travel to Egypt each year to see its ancient pyramids." (Egypt is singular → "its")

3. Pronoun Agreement

  • Pronouns must agree with the antecedent, which is the noun the pronoun is replacing
    • Whenever you see a pronoun on the ACT, find exactly who or what it's referring to
    • The antecedent can be in the same sentence or in a preceding sentence
    • The antecedent can appear anywhere (unnecessary information, prepositional phrases, etc.)

Matching in Plurality

  • A singular antecedent must have a singular pronoun; a plural antecedent must have a plural pronoun
    • ❌ Incorrect: "Each attendee at the party raised their drink for a toast."
    • "Each attendee" is singular → pronoun must be singular
    • ✓ Correct: "Each attendee at the party raised his or her drink for a toast."
    • ✓ Also correct: "The guests at the party raised their drinks for a toast." (plural → plural)

Matching in Gender

  • A male antecedent must have a male pronoun; a female antecedent must have a female pronoun
    • Example: "Jane and Sarah, after a long conversation with another group of hikers on the trail, said they were too tired to go any farther today."
    • "Jane and Sarah" (female, plural) → "they" (plural, works for any gender)

Common Tricky Cases

  • Watch out for singular words that seem plural
    • "Each member of the women's track team improved her time." ("each member" is singular → "her")
    • "A person who is committed to his or her dreams can achieve them." ("a person" is singular → "his or her")
  • Consistency with pronoun style
    • "If you plan to give a presentation on the importance of accurate data, you should check your facts first."
    • Keep the same pronoun style throughout: "you...you...your" (not "you...one...one's")

4. Ambiguous Pronouns

  • For a pronoun to be correct, we must know exactly who or what it's referring to
    • If we don't know exactly who or what a pronoun is referring to, the pronoun is ambiguous and is always incorrect

Examples of Ambiguous Pronouns

  • Ambiguous "he"
    • ❌ Incorrect: "Stephen smiled at his father as he threw the ball."
    • We don't know if "he" refers to Stephen or his father, so "he" is ambiguous
    • ✓ Correct: "Stephen smiled at his father as his father threw the ball."
    • Even though it seems redundant, replacing "he" with "his father" fixes the error
  • Ambiguous "some"
    • ❌ Incorrect: "Even though the order had not yet shown up, the librarian insisted that she had ordered some."
    • We have no idea what "some" refers to
    • ✓ Correct: "Even though the order had not yet shown up, the librarian insisted that she had ordered four copies of the new book."

Spotting Ambiguous Pronouns Questions

  • Anytime you see a pronoun in the answer choices, check if it's ambiguous
    • Pronouns to watch for: he, him, his, she, her, hers, they, them, their, it, its, this, that, these, those, some, none
  • Look for answer choices that replace the pronoun with a specific noun
    • The correct answer often specifies exactly what or who is being referred to
    • Example: Instead of "he is the most famous," the answer might be "Biggie is the most famous"
    • Example: Instead of "asked for one," the answer might be "asked for a slider"

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓subject pronouns when the pronoun does the action.
  • ✓Possessive pronouns must match the word they're replacing in number.
  • ✓Pronouns must agree with their antecedent in both plurality and gender.
  • ✓Ambiguous pronouns are always incorrect.

lessons.subject: reading
lessons.title: Topic 1.4 - Pacing and 10 Time Management Skills
lessons.content:
The Reading Test is the section students most commonly struggle to finish—you have just 40 minutes for 4 passages and 36 questions (60 minutes with extended time). Mastering pacing and learning effective time management skills is critical to ensuring you finish all passages and maximize your score.

1. Understanding Your Pacing

  • You have 10 minutes per passage on average (15 minutes for extended time)
    • Standard time: Passage 1 at 10 min, Passage 2 at 20 min, Passage 3 at 30 min, Passage 4 at 40 min
    • Extended time: Passage 1 at 15 min, Passage 2 at 30 min, Passage 3 at 45 min, Passage 4 at 60 min
    • These are general estimates—not every passage will take exactly the same time

Staying on Pace

  • Monitoring your timing
    • Some passages will take longer, others will go faster—this is normal
    • You should never get more than 1-2 minutes behind the pace breakdown
    • Check your watch at the end of each passage to assess if you're on pace
    • If on pace or ahead, keep working as you have been; if behind, pick up the pace slightly

2. Skills 1-3: Foundational Time Strategies

  • Skill #1 - Know Your Order: Complete passages in your preferred order, not the test's order
    • Do your favorite/easiest passage type first, save the hardest for last
    • If you run out of time, better to rush on a passage you find challenging
    • Typical order: Literary Narrative, then 3 Informational passages (Social Science, Humanities, Natural Science)
    • With practice, discover which passage types you prefer
  • Skill #2 - Skip Broad Passage Questions: Save main idea questions for last
    • The first question (sometimes first 2) often asks about the passage as a whole
    • Answer these last—after answering other questions, you'll understand the passage better
    • This saves time because you won't need to reread/skim the entire passage
    • You're also more likely to get these questions correct when you answer them last
  • Skill #3 - Get to Know the Pace: Internalize timing so you don't constantly check your watch
    • With practice, you'll develop an internal sense of when you're on/off pace
    • You'll know when you have time to dig deeper vs. when you need to move on
    • Only way to achieve this: practice, practice, practice!

3. Skills 4-6: Avoiding Getting Stuck

  • Skill #4 - The 30-Second Rule: Don't spend more than 30 seconds stuck on a question
    • If you can't find evidence after 30 seconds, bubble in your best guess and move on
    • Better to guess on tough questions and finish the test than run out of time
    • You can return to the question later if you have time or find evidence while answering others
  • Skill #5 - Circle Guesses, Box Non-Confident Answers: Mark questions to revisit
    • If you completely guess on a question, circle the question number
    • If you answer but aren't 100% confident, box the question number
    • If you finish early, go back to circled questions first, then boxed questions
    • Better to make educated guesses and finish than get stuck and not finish
  • Skill #6 - Answer Questions Out of Order: Be flexible with question sequence
    • You don't need to answer questions in the order presented
    • Start with questions that have line references—easier to find quickly
    • Skip questions where you can't quickly find the relevant passage section
    • As you answer other questions, you may stumble upon evidence for skipped questions
    • Questions are NOT strictly chronological in the passage

4. Skill 7: Finding Evidence Efficiently

  • Know Where Waldo Is Likely Based on Question Number: Rough location patterns
    • Questions 1-3: Start of passage, most likely in the first third (not counting broad passage questions)
    • Questions 4-7: Could be anywhere, but start looking in the middle of the passage
    • Questions 8-9: End of passage, most likely in the last 2 paragraphs

Important Caveat

  • These are guidelines, NOT rules
    • Sometimes question 8 evidence is in the middle; sometimes question 6 is in the first sentence
    • If you don't find evidence in the expected location, keep looking elsewhere
    • This is just a method to save time by starting your search in the most likely place

5. Skills 8-10: Managing Pressure and Instincts

  • Skill #8 - Wear a Watch: Monitor timing without relying on room clocks
    • Wear a watch on test day (not a smart watch; no noise)
    • Check your watch at the end of each passage
    • Combined with memorized pacing, you'll know if you're ahead, on pace, or behind
    • Adjust accordingly to ensure you finish all 4 passages
  • Skill #9 - Don't Freak Out If Behind Pace: Manage stress when running late
    • If behind pace, DON'T panic, rush excessively, or lose focus
    • Make minor adjustments: read slightly faster (but maintain comprehension)
    • Make quicker decisions on questions—answer from memory if confident
    • It's okay to be 50-75% sure and finish, rather than guess on many questions at the end
    • Panicking leads to careless mistakes and worse performance
  • Skill #10 - Know When to Trust Your Gut: Balance instinct with verification
    • If you know the answer immediately, bubble it in and move on without checking the passage
    • If you think you know but aren't 100% confident, go back to verify
    • If you don't remember the details, either find evidence or skip and return later
    • Students with strong recall can rely on memory more; know your own abilities

Common Test Day Mistake to Avoid

  • Warning about over-verification
    • Many students who normally finish practice tests suddenly have timing issues on the real ACT
    • This happens because they stop trusting their gut on test day
    • They start finding evidence for every single question instead of answering from memory when confident
    • Build the skill of knowing when to trust yourself vs. when to verify

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓You have 10 minutes per passage on average —check your watch after each passage to stay on track.
  • ✓Skip broad passage questions and answer them last after you understand the passage better.
  • ✓Answer questions out of order—start with line-reference questions that are easier to locate.
  • ✓If you fall behind pace, don't panic—make minor adjustments.

lessons.subject: reading
lessons.title: Topic 2.1 - How to Spot and Approach the 7 Most Common Types of Questions
lessons.content:
Knowing which type of question you're answering is critical to maximizing your Reading score—each question type requires a slightly different approach. This lesson teaches you the 7 most common question types (covering 95%+ of ACT Reading questions), how to identify each type by its keywords, and the best strategy for approaching it.

1. Broad Passage Questions

  • Broad passage questions ask about the passage as a whole, not specific details
    • Often the first question (sometimes first 2) in a passage
    • Ask about overall themes, structure, purpose, or narrator/author's perspective
    • Generally easy to identify as broad questions

Common Phrasings

  • Look for these question stems:
    • "The passage can be best described as..."
    • "The main idea of the passage is..."
    • "The main purpose of the passage is to..."
    • "The author's central claim is..."
    • "A central theme of the passage is..."
    • "Which choice best describes the narrator?"
    • "Which choice best describes the overall structure of the passage?"

How to Approach

  • Strategy for broad passage questions
    • Skip these questions and answer them LAST
    • After completing other questions, you'll understand the passage better
    • This saves time—you won't need to reread/skim the entire passage
    • You're more likely to answer correctly when you have full passage context

2. Clear Evidence Questions

  • Clear evidence questions: the correct answer is a restatement or rephrasing of evidence directly stated in the passage
    • Once you find your Waldo, the answer is "slap-you-in-the-face" obvious
    • The answer uses exact words from the passage or simple rephrasing
    • Usually easier than inference questions, but can be challenging if evidence is well-hidden

Keywords to Identify These Questions

  • Almost always contains one of these keywords:
    • Indicates, States, Argues, Describes, Claims
    • "According to the passage/author/narrator"
    • "Based on the passage"
    • "In the passage"
    • Less common: Characterizes, Clarifies, "As presented in the passage"

How to Approach

  • Strategy for clear evidence questions
    • Look for clear, direct evidence in the passage
    • Do NOT make any inferences—this is the most common mistake!
    • The evidence should directly match or simply rephrase the correct answer
    • If you can't find evidence after 30 seconds, guess and move on

3. Inference Questions

  • Inference questions: the correct answer is not directly stated but is demonstrated in the passage
    • There's still strong evidence, but it won't directly match the answer choice
    • Once you find your Waldo, the answer is clear but not as obvious as clear evidence questions
    • You must read between the lines slightly

Keywords to Identify These Questions

  • Always contains at least one of these keywords:
    • Inferred, Implies, Suggests, Assumed
    • "Most reasonably," "Most likely," "Most clearly"
    • "Most nearly," "Most strongly," "Best supports"

How to Approach

  • Strategy for inference questions
    • Look for evidence that demonstrates or shows the answer, not states it directly
    • The answer must still be supported by the passage—don't make wild leaps
    • Read for context around the relevant section
    • The correct answer logically follows from what the passage shows

4. Purpose and Main Idea Questions

  • Purpose questions: ask WHY a sentence, quotation, or paragraph is included
    • Keywords: Purpose, "Serve(s) to," "In order to," "Mainly to," Function, "Primarily to"
    • Must read for context—reading just the referenced lines won't give you enough information
    • Think about WHY the information is included in the passage
  • Main idea questions: ask WHAT a portion of the passage is saying
    • Keywords: "Main idea," "Best summarizes," "Central claim," Paraphrases
    • The correct answer summarizes the referenced section
    • Focus on the specific part the question asks about
    • Context is less critical than for purpose questions, but still helpful

Example Phrasings

  • Purpose: "The author includes the quotation in the third paragraph in order to..."
    • Purpose: "The references to the Hulk and Ironman primarily serve to..."
  • Main Idea: "Which of the following best summarizes the author's justification for..."
    • Main Idea: "The main idea of the fifth paragraph (lines 60-73) is..."

5. Words in Context Questions

  • Words in context questions: ask what a word or phrase "most nearly means" in the passage
    • Usually testing a word/phrase used in an uncommon way
    • The correct answer is often NOT the actual definition—it's an alternate meaning based on context
    • Always contains the phrase "most nearly means"

How to Approach

  • Read for context to find the meaning
    • Read the sentence before, the sentence with the word, and the sentence after
    • If still unclear, read more of the paragraph for additional context
    • Don't just pick the standard dictionary definition of the word

Two Effective Methods

  • Method #1 - Pick Your Own Word: Read context, choose your own word for what it means, then find the answer choice closest to your word
    • Method #2 - Substitute Each Answer: Plug each answer choice into the sentence and see which makes the most sense

6. Comparing Passages Questions

  • Comparing passages questions: appear at the end of dual text passages (3 questions total)
    • Ask you to compare the two passages in various ways
    • May use any of the question types already covered (inference, purpose, main idea, etc.)
    • Easy to spot—question clearly references both passages or both authors

Example Phrasings

  • Look for questions like:
    • "Which choice best describes the relationship between the two passages?"
    • "One similarity between passage A and passage B is that both passages argue..."
    • Any question that explicitly mentions both passages or both authors

How to Approach

  • Use the same methods as regular passage questions
    • Identify the question type (inference, purpose, etc.) and apply that strategy
    • Just remember to consider evidence from BOTH passages
    • Advanced tips for comparing passages covered in a later chapter

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Broad passage questions ask about the passage as a whole and should be answered LAST after you've completed other questions and understand the full passage.
  • ✓Inference questions require you to read between the lines—the answer is demonstrated but not directly stated.
  • ✓Purpose questions ask WHY information is included and require reading for context beyond just the referenced lines.
  • ✓Words questions always say "most nearly means" and test uncommon word usage—read the sentences before.

lessons.subject: reading
lessons.title: Topic 2.2 - Breaking Down Questions
lessons.content:
The most important skill for ACT Reading success is effectively breaking down each question to identify exactly what you're being asked. Most students believe they already do this, but they're not doing it effectively enough—if you can't articulate exactly what you're looking for before going back to the passage, you don't know what the ACT is asking and you're wasting time.

1. Skill #1 — Identify the Type of Question

  • When you read a question, first identify the question type
    • You should memorize all keywords and approaches from Chapter 5 (7 question types)
    • Knowing the type is critical to knowing how to approach the question
    • Different question types require different types of evidence in the passage

Example Question Type Identification

  • Practice identifying types:
    • "The passage indicates that Austin had what reaction..." → Clear Evidence (keyword: indicates)
    • "The author discusses dual insulation in order to..." → Purpose (keyword: in order to)
    • "It can be inferred that the first attempt failed because..." → Inference (keyword: inferred)
    • "According to the passage, Terry would occasionally..." → Clear Evidence (keyword: according to)

Why This Matters

  • Understanding the question type determines your strategy
    • Clear evidence questions: Look for exact text that matches the answer
    • Inference questions: Look for evidence that demonstrates or shows the answer
    • Purpose questions: Read for context to understand WHY information is included
    • Main idea questions: Focus on summarizing WHAT a section says

2. Skill #2 — Identify the Keywords

  • To find evidence quickly, identify the keywords in the question
    • Keywords are words/phrases you can skim for in the passage
    • On the ACT, keywords from the question are almost always right near the evidence
    • Keywords are like little flags saying "Look over here for the evidence!"
    • After finding the keyword, use the 2-sentence rule: read 2 sentences before and 2 after

How to Identify Keywords

  • Underline important keywords as you read the question
    • Once underlined, you'll know what words/phrases to skim for in the passage
    • Keywords help you locate the right section of the passage quickly
    • The evidence is almost always near the keywords

Examples of Keyword Identification

  • Example 1: "In the passage, the narrator describes a brick wall of an abandoned restaurant as:"
    • Keywords: "brick wall" and "abandoned restaurant"
    • This is a clear evidence question (keyword: "in the passage")
    • If you find where the passage discusses the brick wall of the abandoned restaurant, the answer should be right nearby and clearly match one answer choice
  • Example 2: "The passage suggests that one difference between a white dwarf and a red giant is that a red giant:"
    • Keywords: "white dwarf" and "red giant"
    • This is an inference question (keyword: "suggests")
    • Look for where the passage discusses both terms and find a difference between them
    • The answer won't be as clearly stated as a clear evidence question

Primary vs. Secondary Keywords

  • Understanding keyword hierarchy
    • Primary keywords: The main words/phrases that will help you locate the evidence section
    • Secondary keywords: Additional words that confirm you're in the right place
    • Example: "According to the passage, compared to the temperature of a volcano undergoing an eruption, the temperature of a blue flame is:"
    • Primary keywords: "volcano," "eruption," "blue flame," "temperature"
    • You need to find where the passage compares these two temperatures

3. Skill #3 — Rephrase the Question (If Necessary)

  • For many questions, keywords alone are enough—no need to rephrase
    • Simple/short questions are usually clear enough as written
    • Example: "According to the passage, the Egyptians invented addition at the same time as:"
    • This question makes it very clear what you're looking for
    • Skim for "Egyptians inventing addition," find the date, check which answer choice matches

When to Rephrase the Question

  • For more complicated questions, rephrasing helps you know exactly what to look for
    • Use this skill when questions are complex or challenging to break down
    • If you can rephrase it in your own words, you know exactly what you need from the passage

Example of When to Rephrase

  • Complex question: "The narrator indicates that which of the following potential risks that doctors face while at work is a concern to her father?"
    • Rephrase: "What risk that doctors face is a concern for her father?"
    • There's no clear primary keyword to easily skim for
    • Best primary keyword is probably "father"
    • But if you just skim for "father" without clarity on what you're looking for, you'll have trouble finding the answer
    • By rephrasing, you know you need: risks + doctors + father's concern

4. Putting It All Together

  • Use all three skills systematically for every question
    • Step 1: Identify the question type (clear evidence, inference, purpose, etc.)
    • Step 2: Identify and underline the keywords
    • Step 3: If needed, rephrase the question in your own words
    • Only then should you go back to the passage to find evidence

The Test: Can You Articulate What You're Looking For?

  • Before going to the passage, ask yourself:
    • "What EXACTLY am I looking for?"
    • If you can't answer this precisely, you haven't broken down the question well enough
    • Go back and apply these three skills until you can articulate exactly what you need
    • This prevents wasted time wandering through the passage aimlessly

Benefits of Effective Question Breakdown

  • Why mastering these skills matters:
    • Find evidence faster = better time management
    • Know exactly what you're looking for = higher accuracy
    • Understand question types = use the right approach for each
    • The better you get at breaking down questions, the easier Reading becomes

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓First identify the question type using keywords from Chapter 5—this determines your approach and what type of evidence to look for.
  • ✓Identify and underline keywords in the question—these are the words/phrases you'll skim for .
  • ✓simple questions, keywords alone are enough—no need to rephrase.
  • ✓Before going to the passage, ask yourself "What EXACTLY am I looking for?" If you can't articulate this precisely, you haven't broken down the question well enough.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.6 - Misplaced Modifiers
lessons.content:
Misplaced modifier questions make up about 5-7% of the ACT English Test—roughly 4-5 questions per test! These questions test whether descriptive words, phrases, or clauses are placed next to the nouns they're supposed to modify.

1. What is a Misplaced Modifier?

  • A misplaced modifier is a word, phrase, or clause that is improperly separated from the noun it modifies
    • This leads to a sentence with an incorrect or unintended meaning
    • Misplaced modifiers are hard to spot because we usually know what the sentence is really supposed to be saying

Example of a Misplaced Modifier

  • ❌ Incorrect: "Consistently erupting, Jack loves taking pictures of the Old Faithful geyser at Yellowstone National Park."
    • What's wrong? The modifier "consistently erupting" is supposed to modify the Old Faithful geyser, but instead it's modifying Jack!
    • This sentence suggests Jack is consistently erupting (which doesn't make sense)
  • When a sentence begins with a modifying phrase, the phrase must modify the very first noun that follows the comma

How to Fix Misplaced Modifiers

  • Option 1: Put the modifier right next to what it's describing
    • ✓ Correct: "Consistently erupting, the Old Faithful geyser at Yellowstone National Park is one of Jack's favorite things to take pictures of."
    • Now "consistently erupting" is right next to "the Old Faithful geyser"
  • Option 2: Change the modifier from a phrase to a dependent clause
    • ✓ Correct: "Since it is consistently erupting, Jack loves taking pictures of the Old Faithful geyser at Yellowstone National Park."
    • Adding "it is" changes the modifier to a dependent clause, making it clear the geyser is erupting

The "Next-Door Neighbor" Rule

  • For a modifier to be properly placed, it must be right "next-door" to the noun it's describing
    • Modifiers can be at the beginning, middle, or end of a sentence
  • If the modifier is at the beginning of the sentence, the first noun after it must be the word being modified
    • Example: "Running from the police, Eric hopped the fence and hid underneath a car."
    • "Running from the police" modifies "Eric" (the first noun after the comma)
  • If the modifier is in the middle or end of the sentence, it must be modifying the noun directly before it
    • Example: "Dr. Anderson, a world-renowned surgeon, fixed my broken leg."
    • "A world-renowned surgeon" modifies "Dr. Anderson" (the noun directly before it)

2. Front of the Sentence Modifiers with a Comma

  • On the ACT, most misplaced modifier questions have a modifier at the front of the sentence separated by a comma
    • For this type of question, consider who or what the modifier is describing
    • Then make sure that person, place, or thing is the first noun in the rest of the sentence

Example: Front Modifier Error

  • ❌ Incorrect: "Not popular since the early 1980s, the documentary about mullets explored the origins of the wildly popular hairstyle."
    • The modifier is "not popular since the early 1980s"
    • What is "not popular since the early 1980s"? Mullets, not documentaries!
    • But the first noun after the comma is "documentary," which is wrong
  • ✓ Correct: "Not popular since the early 1980s, mullets were the topic of a recently released documentary."
    • Now "mullets" (the thing that's not popular since the 1980s) is the first noun after the comma
    • The modifier is right "next-door" to what it describes

Strategy for Front Modifiers

  • Step 1: Identify the modifying phrase at the beginning (before the comma)
    • Look for descriptive phrases before the first comma
  • Step 2: Ask yourself: Who or what is being described by this modifier?
    • Think about what noun makes logical sense with the description
  • Step 3: Find the first noun after the comma
    • This is what the modifier is currently describing
  • Step 4: Make sure the first noun matches who or what should be described
    • If it doesn't match, the modifier is misplaced
    • Choose the answer that puts the correct noun first

3. Middle or End of the Sentence Modifiers with Commas

  • A modifier in the middle or at the end of the sentence must be directly after whoever or whatever it is modifying
    • These modifiers are often set off by commas or use "which" or "that"

Example: Middle Modifier Error

  • ❌ Incorrect: "The research team, which arrived at their nesting grounds early this year, tracked the movements of the blue storks."
    • The modifier is "which arrived at their nesting grounds early this year"
    • This is placed right after "research team," so it's describing the research team
    • But the blue storks (not the research team) arrived at their nesting grounds early!

How to Fix Middle/End Modifiers

  • Option 1: Move the modifier to be right after what it describes
    • ✓ Correct: "The research team tracked the movements of the blue storks, which arrived at their nesting grounds early this year."
    • Now the modifier is right after "blue storks"
  • Option 2: Change the modifier to describe what's actually before it
    • ✓ Correct: "The research team, which tracked the movement of the blue storks, noted that the birds arrived at their nesting grounds early."
    • Now the modifier correctly describes the research team

Strategy for Middle/End Modifiers

  • Step 1: Identify the modifying phrase (often with "which," "that," or set off by commas)
    • Look for descriptive phrases in the middle or end of the sentence
  • Step 2: Ask: What noun is the modifier describing?
    • Think logically about what makes sense
  • Step 3: Check what noun comes right before the modifier
    • This is what the modifier is currently describing
  • Step 4: Make sure the noun before the modifier is what should be described
    • If not, choose the answer that moves the modifier or changes the sentence structure

4. Modifiers without Commas

  • In some questions, the modifier will not be separated by any commas
    • These are harder to spot, but the "next-door neighbor" rule still applies
    • Keep an eye out for phrases starting with "that" or words ending in "-ing" and "-ed"

Common Patterns without Commas

  • Phrases starting with "that"
    • Example: "The book that I borrowed from the library is overdue."
    • "That I borrowed from the library" modifies "book" (right before it)
  • Words ending in "-ing" (present participles)
    • Example: "The dog chasing the cat ran into the street."
    • "Chasing the cat" modifies "dog" (right before it)
    • ❌ Incorrect: "Chasing the cat, the street was where the dog ran."
    • This suggests the street is chasing the cat!
  • Words ending in "-ed" (past participles)
    • Example: "The cake baked by my grandmother was delicious."
    • "Baked by my grandmother" modifies "cake" (right before it)

Strategy for Modifiers without Commas

  • Look for descriptive phrases that aren't set off by commas
    • Watch for "that," "-ing," and "-ed" words
  • Apply the same "next-door neighbor" rule
    • The modifier should be right next to what it's describing
    • If it's at the beginning, check the first noun after it
    • If it's in the middle or end, check the noun right before it
  • Ask yourself: Does the modifier logically describe the noun next to it?
    • If not, it's misplaced

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓A misplaced modifier is a word, phrase.
  • ✓front-of-sentence modifiers separated by a comma.
  • ✓middle or end-of-sentence modifiers with commas .
  • ✓Modifiers without commas follow the same "next-door neighbor" rule.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.7 - Parallel Structure
lessons.content:
Parallel structure questions make up about 7-9% of the ACT English Test—roughly 5-7 questions per test! These questions test whether items in a list or comparison are written with the same grammatical form.

1. What is Parallel Structure?

  • Parallel structure is the repetition of a chosen grammatical form within a sentence as items are listed or compared
    • The items in a list can be words, phrases, or clauses
    • Whenever we see items in a list or a comparison between items, we must make sure they have parallel structure
  • Items in any list must be written with the same grammatical form
    • Items must be all nouns, all verbs, all adjectives, etc.
    • When lists are written with proper parallel structure, the sentence flows more smoothly and sounds better
    • Many students can "hear" which answer choice is correct without even realizing they're being tested on parallel structure

Examples of Parallel Structure Errors

  • ❌ Incorrect: "To protect her fragile hands, Julia will not rake the leaves, wash the dishes, and has decided she will not take out the trash."
    • List items: "rake the leaves" (verb phrase), "wash the dishes" (verb phrase), "has decided she will not take out the trash" (clause)
    • Not parallel! The third item is much longer and has a different structure
  • ✓ Correct: "To protect her fragile hands, Julia will not rake the leaves, wash the dishes, or take out the trash."
    • All three items are now verb phrases: "rake," "wash," "take out"
    • Parallel!

2. Parallel Structure with Lists

  • No matter how simple or complex the items in the list are, they must be parallel
    • Lists can contain nouns, verb phrases, adjectives, or entire clauses
    • All items must match in grammatical form

Lists of Nouns or Noun Phrases

  • ❌ Incorrect: "Elon Musk is known for self-driving cars and pioneering the SpaceX program."
    • "Self-driving cars" (noun phrase) vs. "pioneering the SpaceX program" (verb phrase)
    • Not parallel!
  • ✓ Correct: "Elon Musk is known for self-driving cars and the SpaceX program."
    • Both are noun phrases: "self-driving cars" and "the SpaceX program"
  • ✓ Also correct: "Elon Musk is known for manufacturing self-driving cars and pioneering the SpaceX program."
    • Both are verb phrases: "manufacturing" and "pioneering"

Lists of Verb Phrases

  • ❌ Incorrect: "After calling in sick to school, Charlie hoped to get excused from class, receiving an extension on his homework assignment, and spend the afternoon watching movies at home."
    • "To get excused" (infinitive), "receiving" (gerund), "spend" (base verb)
    • Not parallel!
  • ✓ Correct: "After calling in sick to school, Charlie hoped to get excused from class, receive an extension on his homework assignment, and spend the afternoon watching movies at home."
    • All three use the base verb form after "hoped to": "get," "receive," "spend"
    • Parallel!

Lists of 3+ vs. Lists of 2

  • Lists of 3 or more items are easier to spot
    • You will be able to more obviously "hear" which answer choice is correct or incorrect
    • Example: "She made her bed, cleaned the shelves, and swept the floor" (all past tense verbs)
  • Lists of 2 are more difficult to spot and can trick you
    • They can often sound good even if they're not parallel
    • Be extra aware of parallel structure anytime you see a list of 2 on the ACT
    • ❌ Incorrect: "It's harder to lift the couch by myself than lifting it with some friends."
    • ✓ Correct: "It's harder to lift the couch by myself than to lift it with some friends." (both use "to lift")

3. Special Cases: Correlative Conjunctions

  • In addition to lists, there are certain special cases for parallel structure
    • These are officially called correlative conjunctions
    • They must have the same grammatical structure for both parts of the conjunction

The Four Main Correlative Conjunctions

  • Neither ___ nor ___
    • Example: "The news report is neither accurate nor fair."
    • Both blanks must have the same form (both adjectives here)
  • Either ___ or ___
    • Example: "You can either call me or text me."
    • Both blanks must match (both verb phrases here)
  • Not only ___ but also ___
    • This is the most commonly tested correlative conjunction on the ACT
    • Example: "My mother not only took away my keys but also locked them in the safe."
    • Both blanks must match (both verb phrases here)
  • Both ___ and ___
    • Example: "Both a scholar and an athlete, Sylvia got a scholarship to row crew in college."
    • Both blanks must match (both noun phrases here)

How to Check Parallel Structure with Correlative Conjunctions

  • Identify what comes immediately after the first part of the conjunction
    • What type of word or phrase follows "not only," "either," "neither," or "both"?
  • Check what comes immediately after the second part
    • What type of word or phrase follows "but also," "or," "nor," or "and"?
  • Make sure both parts match in grammatical form
    • If the first part has a verb phrase, the second must have a verb phrase
    • If the first part has a noun, the second must have a noun

4. Common Parallel Structure Patterns

  • Watch for these common patterns on the ACT
    • Lists connected by "and" or "or"
    • Comparisons using "than"
    • Correlative conjunctions (neither/nor, either/or, not only/but also, both/and)

Strategy for Parallel Structure Questions

  • Step 1: Identify that there's a list or comparison
    • Look for words like "and," "or," "than," or correlative conjunctions
  • Step 2: Find all the items in the list or comparison
    • How many items are there? What are they?
  • Step 3: Check the grammatical form of each item
    • Is the first item a noun? Verb? Adjective? Phrase? Clause?
    • Are all the other items the same type?
  • Step 4: Choose the answer that makes all items match
    • All items must have the same grammatical structure
    • Trust your ear—parallel structure usually "sounds right"

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Parallel structure is the repetition of a chosen grammatical form within a sentence as items are listed or compared.
  • ✓Lists of 3 or more items are easier to spot because you can clearly hear.
  • ✓Correlative conjunctions require parallel structure on both sides.
  • ✓To check parallel structure, identify all items in the list or comparison, determine the grammatical form of each item.

lessons.subject: science
lessons.title: Topic 2.5 - Figures + Text Questions
lessons.content:
On certain Science questions, the information shown in figures and tables alone is insufficient to answer the question, requiring you to consult the experimental text above the figures to find missing details about variables, experimental conditions, or setup parameters. These questions test your ability to integrate information from multiple sources—combining numerical data from figures with contextual information from the passage text to arrive at the correct answer.

1. When Figures Alone Aren't Enough

  • Most Science questions can be answered using only the figures and tables, but some questions require additional context from the experimental text
    • The question asks about units or values for a specific term that are not shown anywhere in the figures or tables
    • The question references experimental conditions, setup details, or control variables not visible in the data displays
    • You need definitions of abbreviations, variables, or scientific terms used in the question

How to Recognize These Questions

  • The question asks about something not visible in any figure or table
    • Example: "How many trials were run without electricity?" when electricity isn't shown in any chart
    • Example: "What was the initial temperature?" when figures only show final temperatures
  • The question uses terms or abbreviations you don't recognize
    • Example: A question mentions "RM" but you don't know what RM stands for
    • The experimental text will define these terms in the introduction or setup description

2. Where to Look in the Experimental Text

  • The experimental text typically appears directly above the figures and tables, organized into clear sections
    • Introductory section — Defines terms, explains the general topic, describes what the experiment is studying
    • Experiment/Study descriptions — Details the specific procedures, lists control variables, explains what changed between trials
    • Figure captions — Sometimes crucial information appears in small text directly below or above figures

Strategic Reading Approach

  • Don't read the experimental text during your initial 30-second preview
    • Most questions won't need it, so reading it upfront wastes time
    • Only go to the text when a question specifically requires information not in the figures
  • When you do need the text, scan strategically
    • Look for bold terms, capitalized abbreviations, or numbered experiments that match the question
    • Read only the relevant section—you don't need to read the entire passage
    • Once you find the information, return immediately to the question

3. Common Scenarios Requiring Text

Scenario 1: Control Variables

  • Question asks: "In which trials was [variable X] held constant?"
    • Variable X doesn't appear in any figure or table
    • Solution: Check the experimental text describing each experiment's conditions
    • The text will explicitly state which variables were controlled

Scenario 2: Initial Conditions

  • Question asks about starting values or initial setup
    • Figures only show final measurements or changes over time
    • Solution: The experimental description states initial conditions before measurements began

Scenario 3: Term Definitions

  • Question uses abbreviations or specialized terms
    • Example: "RM," "reactive material," "compound X"
    • Solution: Introductory paragraph defines all key terms and abbreviations

4. Pro Tips and Common Mistakes

Pro Tips

  • Check figures first, always — Even on "text required" questions, start by checking if the answer might actually be in a figure you missed
  • Use keywords to locate information — If the question asks about "electricity," scan the text for that exact word
  • Don't read more than necessary — Extract only the specific fact you need, then return to the question
  • Mark helpful text — If a passage requires multiple text lookups, underline or circle key facts for quicker reference

Common Mistakes

  • Reading all the text upfront — This wastes precious time since most questions don't need it
  • Assuming information must be in a figure — If you can't find it after checking all figures, go to the text instead of guessing
  • Reading the wrong experiment's description — Make sure you're reading about Experiment 1 if the question asks about Experiment 1
  • Getting lost in unnecessary details — Stay focused on finding the one specific piece of information the question needs

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Don't read experimental text during your initial passage preview—only consult it.
  • ✓When you need the text, scan strategically for keywords rather than reading everything—look for bold terms, capitalized abbreviations.
  • ✓check figures and tables first before going.
  • ✓Extract only the specific fact you need from the text, then immediately return.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.8 - Miscellaneous Topics
