lessons.content:
Miscellaneous grammar questions make up about 8-10% of the ACT English Test—roughly 6-8 questions per test! This chapter covers commonly confused words, active vs. passive voice, and other important grammar rules that don't fit into other categories.

1. Commonly Confused Words

  • The ACT tests many commonly confused words
    • The most common is "affect" vs. "effect"
    • If you're unsure, go with your gut—you'll usually be correct

Affect vs. Effect

  • Affect = verb meaning to act on or produce a change in
    • Example: "Sunshine and palm trees affect my mood positively."
  • Effect = noun meaning the result of a change
    • Example: "Sunshine and palm trees have a positive effect on my mood."

Other Commonly Confused Words

  • Accept (receive) vs. Except (exclude)
  • Advice (noun - recommendation) vs. Advise (verb - to recommend)
  • Lie (to lie down) vs. Lay (to place)
  • Lose (to misplace) vs. Loose (not tight)
  • Passed (moved beyond) vs. Past (gone by in time)
  • Principal (head of school) vs. Principle (a rule)
  • Their (possessive) vs. There (location) vs. They're (they are)
  • To (toward) vs. Too (also) vs. Two (2)

2. Than vs. Then

  • Than is ONLY used for comparisons
    • Example: "I think that chocolate with almonds is much better than ice cream."
  • Then has multiple meanings
    • Used when dealing with time: "First we eat, then we clean up."
    • Means "in addition to": "I need to call my mother, and then we can leave."
    • Used with if/then statements: "If it rains, then we'll stay inside."
  • Quick rule: For a comparison, use "than." Otherwise, use "then."

3. Have vs. Of

  • Many people mistakenly use "could of" or "would of"
    • This is ALWAYS incorrect!
    • The correct forms are "could have" or "would have"
  • The words "could," "should," "would," and "might" should always be followed by "have," not "of"
    • The reason for this mistake: The contraction "could've" (short for "could have") is pronounced like "could of"
    • ❌ Incorrect: "If we left the show earlier, we could of avoided the traffic."
    • ✓ Correct: "If we left the show earlier, we could have avoided the traffic."

4. Countable vs. Non-countable Adjectives

  • A countable noun is something you can count
    • Examples: bottles of milk, hours, trophies, calories
  • A non-countable noun is something that cannot be expressed in plural form
    • Examples: time, air, milk, significance

Which Adjectives to Use

  • For COUNTABLE nouns, use: number, many, fewer, few
    • Example: "The number of ingredients" (you can count ingredients)
    • Example: "How many trophies" (you can count trophies)
    • Example: "Fewer calories" (you can count calories)
    • Example: "A few minutes" (you can count minutes)
  • For NON-COUNTABLE nouns, use: amount, much, less, little
    • Example: "The amount of time" (you can't count time itself)
    • Example: "How much significance" (you can't count significance)
    • Example: "Less whole milk" (you can't count milk itself, only containers)
    • Example: "A little time" (you can't count time itself)

5. Active Voice vs. Passive Voice

  • Active voice means the subject performs the verb's action
    • Example: "I picked up the pencil." (I performed the action)
    • Example: "The police chief announced the list of suspects." (The police chief performed the action)
  • Passive voice means the subject is acted upon by the verb
    • Example: "The pencil was picked up by me." (The pencil didn't do the action)
    • Example: "The list of suspects was announced by the police chief." (The list didn't do the action)
  • On the ACT, NEVER select an answer choice in passive voice
    • Active voice is always better than passive voice
    • Active voice is clearer, more direct, and stronger

6. Prepositional Idioms

  • Idioms are expressions stated in a certain way because it's widely accepted practice
    • Certain words must be paired with certain prepositions to be correct
    • These questions don't come up often on the ACT
  • When prepositional idioms appear, rely on what sounds best
    • ❌ Incorrect: "Bobby was afraid by the dark."
    • ✓ Correct: "Bobby was afraid of the dark."
  • Common prepositional idioms to know
    • Afraid of (not afraid by)
    • Anxious about (not anxious of)
    • Different from (not different than)
    • Responsible for (not responsible of)

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓"Affect" is a verb , while "effect" is a noun .
  • ✓countable nouns , use number, many, fewer.
  • ✓Active voice is better than passive voice .
  • ✓Prepositional idioms pair specific words.

lessons.subject: reading
lessons.title: Topic 2.3 - How to Approach the Answer Choices
lessons.content:
Knowing when and how to use the answer choices effectively is crucial for Reading success. This chapter teaches you strategic approaches for reading answer choices and how to work both forwards (finding evidence) and backwards (eliminating incorrect answers) simultaneously to find the correct answer as quickly and consistently as possible.

1. When to Read the Answer Choices

  • After reading the question, you can either read the answer choices right away or go back to the passage first
    • The answer depends on the question type, your reading comprehension skills, and your recall of the passage
    • There is no 100% right or wrong time to read the answer choices—it's about finding what works for you
    • Try different methods on practice passages and practice tests to discover your optimal approach

Strategy 1: Read Answer Choices Right Away for "Which of the Following" Questions

  • For "which of the following" questions, always read the answer choices before going to the passage
    • Without reading the answer choices, it's impossible to know what you're looking for
    • Example: "Which of the following best describes the author's view of Grier's theory?"
    • The question is too broad without seeing the four specific options
    • Knowing the 4 options makes it easier to find the correct answer and usually saves time

Strategy 2: Come Up With Your Own Answer First for Purpose Questions

  • For purpose questions, go back to the passage first and come up with your own answer
    • Read for context and determine WHY the information is included
    • Once you have your answer, look at the answer choices to see which one matches your reasoning
    • If none match, you may have misunderstood—reread with the answer choices in mind

Strategy 3: Try Your Own Answer First for Broad Passage Questions

  • After reading the entire passage and answering all other questions, come up with your own answer
    • You'll understand the passage well by this point, so you can answer questions about the passage as a whole
    • Once you have your answer, look at the choices to see which one matches
    • If you found the passage difficult and can't come up with your own answer, read the choices right away
    • Knowing the 4 options can make it easier to find the answer or eliminate incorrect choices

Strategy 4: Try Both Methods for Clear Evidence and Inference Questions

  • Method #1: Read answer choices right away
    • You know the 4 options before going back to the passage
    • As you read, you may recognize evidence that matches an answer choice you just read
    • Helps you recognize the correct answer more quickly and can save time if you remember the answer
    • WARNING: This doesn't work if reading the choices distracts you from knowing EXACTLY what the question asks
    • Some students reread the question after reading all 4 choices to ensure they know what they're looking for
  • Method #2: Go back to the passage first
    • If reading answer choices distracts you, go to the passage first and look for evidence
    • Clear evidence and inference questions are usually specific, so you'll know where to read
    • By reading before looking at choices, you're 100% focused on answering the question
    • Once you find potential evidence, read the answer choices and eliminate incorrect ones
    • If you can't find evidence in 20-30 seconds, read the answer choices—they may trigger your memory

Strategy 5: Read Answer Choices When You Don't Have Primary Keywords

  • For vague questions without primary keywords, read the answer choices right away
    • The answer choices may help identify where to go or trigger your memory
    • Example: "How did the narrator's personality affect her research?" has no clear keywords to skim for
    • Reading the 4 options makes it easier to eliminate incorrect choices and know what to look for

Strategy 6: Use Answer Choices to Help on Difficult Passages

  • For passages you have trouble understanding, read the answer choices more quickly
    • If you read a passage and don't understand what's going on, let the answer choices help you
    • For any questions in a difficult passage, read the answer choices right away
    • Example: If asked about a paragraph's main idea but you don't understand it, read the 4 options then reread the paragraph
    • Knowing the 4 options may help you recognize what the paragraph is saying
    • The more you use the answer choices to help, the more you'll understand and answer correctly

2. How to Read Answer Choices Most Effectively

  • The recommended approach: Work both forwards and backwards simultaneously
    • Working forwards = looking for evidence in the passage that matches the correct answer
    • Working backwards = eliminating incorrect answer choices
    • In an ideal world, you'd find Waldo every time by working forwards, but that's difficult
    • For some questions, it's easier to eliminate three incorrect answers than find evidence for the correct one
    • If you can eliminate 3 answer choices as incorrect, you've found the correct answer—even without evidence

Working Forwards — Look for Evidence in the Passage

  • Put your finger on the evidence (the Waldo!) and match it to the correct answer choice
    • This is the ideal approach when you can clearly identify the supporting evidence
    • Finding evidence that supports the correct answer for every question is difficult
    • Don't rely solely on working forwards—combine it with working backwards

Working Backwards — Eliminate Incorrect Answer Choices

  • Anytime you see an answer choice that is incorrect for any reason, cross it off
    • You'll learn the 5 types of incorrect answer choices in Chapter 2.4
    • For some questions, eliminating three incorrect choices is easier than finding the evidence
    • Even without finding evidence in the passage, if you eliminate 3 choices, you've found the correct answer

3. Working Forwards and Backwards Simultaneously

  • As you read each answer choice, ask yourself two questions:
    • Question 1 (Working Forwards): "Is there evidence in the passage that matches what this answer choice says?"
    • Question 2 (Working Backwards): "Is there any specific detail or strong statement in this answer choice that could make it incorrect?"

Evaluating Answer Choices

  • Working forwards requires going back to the passage
    • If you find Waldo, you'll know the correct answer
    • If there's no evidence to support the answer choice, it's incorrect—cross it off
  • Working backwards means looking for words that could make the answer incorrect
    • Be cautious about specific details or strong statements in answer choices
    • Stronger and more specific answer choices are usually incorrect because they can't be supported by the passage
    • More boring answer choices are more commonly correct
    • The ACT knows students prefer to pick specific choices when struggling (easier to justify), so they use this as a trap
    • Nobody wants to pick boring answers, but boring is usually better on ACT Reading!

4. Key Strategy When Stuck Between Two Answers

  • If you're stuck between two answer choices and cannot find evidence to support either one:
    • Always pick the less detailed answer choice
    • Boring is usually better on the ACT Reading Test
    • More specific answer choices tend to include details that go beyond what the passage supports
    • More general (boring) answer choices are safer because they're less likely to contradict the passage

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓When to read answer choices depends on question type.
  • ✓Work both forwards and backwards simultaneously—look for evidence.
  • ✓Be cautious of specific details and strong statements in answer choices—stronger and more specific choices are usually incorrect because they can't be supported by the passage.
  • ✓If stuck between two answer choices and you cannot find evidence.

lessons.subject: science
lessons.title: Topic 3.1 - 2-Part Answers
lessons.content:
Two-part answer questions present claims paired with explanations, requiring you to evaluate both components independently. The key strategy is to start with the explanation (second part) first, as it's typically easier to validate using figures or scientific knowledge, then work backward to evaluate the claim.

How to Identify Two-Part Questions

  • Two-part questions have answer choices formatted as "claim, because explanation"
    • Example: "Yes, because the boiling point of water is above 100°C"
    • Example: "No, acetone has the lowest percent combustibility at 40°C"
    • The claim is the first part (Yes/No or which option)
    • The explanation follows "because" or "as" or similar connecting words
  • Most two-part questions follow a standard pattern:
    • Answers A and B share the same claim
    • Answers C and D share the same claim (opposite of A/B)
    • Answers A and C share the same explanation
    • Answers B and D share the same explanation (different from A/C)
  • Always read carefully - some questions don't follow the standard pattern

Strategy: Start with the Explanation

  • Begin by evaluating the explanation (the part after "because"):
    • Explanations are usually based on figures, tables, or basic scientific facts
    • They're much easier to verify than claims
    • You can quickly eliminate 2 incorrect answers by finding the wrong explanation
  • How to check explanations:
    • Look at the figure or table referenced
    • Verify specific numerical values or trends
    • Use basic scientific knowledge (boiling point of water = 100°C, etc.)
  • Once you've eliminated 2 answers with wrong explanations, evaluate the claim between the remaining 2 answers

Common Patterns and Shortcuts

  • Using the standard pattern to your advantage:
    • If you determine the explanation is correct, eliminate answers with the opposite explanation
    • If you can't determine the claim, picking the right explanation gives you a 50/50 chance
    • This reduces guessing from 4 options to 2 options
  • Be careful with contradiction traps:
    • Some wrong answers pair a correct claim with an incorrect explanation
    • Or pair an incorrect claim with a correct explanation
    • Both parts must be correct for the answer to be correct

Key Takeaways

  • ✓start by evaluating the explanation first, as it's easier to verify.
  • ✓the standard pattern (A/B same claim, C/D same claim.
  • ✓Verify explanations using figures, tables.
  • ✓Both the claim and explanation must be correct.

lessons.subject: reading
lessons.title: Topic 2.4 - Correct vs. Incorrect Answer Choices
lessons.content:
Understanding what makes an answer choice correct or incorrect is one of the most important skills for Reading success. Many students feel like they're looking for the "best" answer, but this is wrong—there is always 1 correct and 3 incorrect answer choices, and the challenge is knowing what makes the correct answer right and the incorrect answers wrong.

1. The 5 Common Types of Incorrect Answer Choices

  • For success on the Reading Test, you must be able to explain what makes an answer choice incorrect
    • For an answer choice to be correct, it must be supported by evidence in the passage AND answer the question being asked
    • If you understand not only what makes an answer correct but also what makes the others incorrect, finding the right answer becomes much easier
    • The 5 most common types of incorrect answers on the ACT Reading Test are: Not in the Passage, Too Specific, Too Broad, Opposite or Slant of the Passage, and In the Passage but Not Answering the Question

2. Type #1 — Not in the Passage

  • Many incorrect answer choices include information that is not in the passage
    • If the answer choice includes details that are not in the passage, the answer is incorrect
    • Could you picture the detail being true? Maybe. Could it be possible? Sure. But we don't know it for sure from the passage.
    • If we cannot point to evidence in the passage that supports an answer choice, we can only tell a story of why we think it could be true
    • As learned in Chapter 1: There is no storytelling!
    • If an answer choice is not clearly supported by evidence in the passage, then it is always wrong

Example: Adam's Clothing

  • Passage excerpt: "Adam rolled up the tattered sleeves of his sweater, exposing the winding snake tattoos on both of his forearms... Despite now living in upstate New York, he still wore his Army boots every day, the tops of which were hidden below his faded black jeans, the only pair that he owns..."
    • Question: "Which of the following can be assumed about Adam's clothing?"
    • INCORRECT: "He only wears the most comfortable clothing" (not stated—we cannot point to evidence for this)
    • INCORRECT: "The army provided him with free clothes" (not stated—this is storytelling)
    • CORRECT: "His clothes are old and worn out" (supported by "tattered sleeves" and "faded black jeans")
    • INCORRECT: "He only owns one sweater" (not stated—the passage only mentions one pair of jeans)

3. Type #2 — Too Specific

  • Incorrect answer choices are very commonly too specific
    • Often, a single word or short phrase in an answer choice makes the entire answer incorrect
    • If the answer choice is too specific and goes beyond what the passage says, it is always incorrect
    • As you read each answer choice, look for specific details and strong statements that could make it incorrect
    • Ask yourself: "Does the passage really say that?"
    • Remember: The more specific and stronger an answer choice is, the more likely it will be incorrect

Example: Pelicans' Fishing Habits

  • Passage excerpt: "Pelicans' diets include fish, amphibians, small turtles, crabs, and even other small birds... The groups of birds will form a line to drive schools of smaller fish into the shallower waters... and then scooping up their favorite prey."
    • Question: "Which of the following statements can be inferred from the passage?"
    • INCORRECT: "Pelicans prey predominantly on fish during the summer months" (too specific—"summer months" not mentioned)
    • INCORRECT: "Great White pelicans are the only species that hunt for turtles" (too specific—species not mentioned)
    • CORRECT: "Small ocean fish are the main prey for pelicans" (supported by "favorite prey" referring to smaller fish)
    • INCORRECT: "Pelicans do the majority of their hunting in shallow waters" (too specific—"majority" goes beyond what's stated)

4. Type #3 — Too Broad

  • Sometimes an answer choice is incorrect because it is too broad
    • More common: The answer choice does not specifically answer the question being asked
    • Less common: The answer does not match a more specific statement made in the passage
    • While broad answer choices are better in general, make sure your choice is always specific enough to answer the exact question asked

Example: Darwin's Finches and Evolution

  • Passage excerpt: "Dr. Anders Robert became fascinated with evolution... But he was never fully satisfied with Darwin's explanation... Dr. Robert will travel to the Galapagos Islands to study changes in the beaks of some of the same species of finches that Darwin studied..."
    • Question: "The main idea of the passage is to:"
    • INCORRECT: "Research the theory of evolution using Darwin's finches" (too broad—doesn't answer what the passage is about)
    • CORRECT: "Test a new idea about evolution by studying finches' beaks" (specific enough and captures the main idea)
    • INCORRECT: "Highlight Dr. Robert's lifelong fascination with evolution" (too broad and "lifelong" not supported)
    • INCORRECT: "Recreate Darwin's research" (word "recreate" doesn't match—he's testing his own new theory)

5. Type #4 — Opposite or Slant of the Passage

  • Many incorrect answers on the ACT are the opposite or a slant of what the passage states
    • These answer choices often look correct because they include exact words or phrases from the passage
    • However, they are incorrect because the answer choice is the opposite or a slant of what is in the passage
    • Do not pick an answer choice just because you find a word or phrase that is directly in the passage
    • Always make sure the answer choice is 100% correct—exact words from the passage are often in incorrect choices

Example: Ocean Currents

  • Passage excerpt: "As water freezes in the North and South Poles, the water surrounding the ice becomes saltier and colder... The cold, salty water sinks due to its increased density... it travels southward to spread across the submerged surface of the earth... Warm water replaces it on the surface and moves to the north."
    • Question: "Which statement about the global conveyor belt is best supported by the passage?"
    • INCORRECT: "Cold, salty water comes to the surface" (opposite—passage says it sinks)
    • INCORRECT: "The currents change with the seasons" (not in the passage)
    • INCORRECT: "Melting ice is the first step" (opposite—passage says freezing water, not melting ice)
    • CORRECT: "Cold, salty water travels south on the ocean floor and warm water moves north on the surface" (matches passage)

6. Type #5 — In the Passage but Not Answering the Question

  • This final type of incorrect answer is often the most difficult to avoid
    • These are answer choices that are directly stated in the passage but do not answer the question being asked
    • You will be able to go to the passage, find the information, and match it with the answer choice
    • However, it will still be incorrect because it doesn't answer what the question is asking!

Two Critical Reminders

  • Reminder #1: Do not select an answer choice because it has a word or phrase that matches the passage
    • Make sure the answer choice is 100% correct
    • The ACT will often put exact words or phrases from the passage in incorrect answer choices to try to trick you
  • Reminder #2: Finding evidence for an answer choice in the passage does not mean you found the correct answer
    • You still need to make sure you are answering the question the ACT is asking
    • Evidence in the passage + answering the question = correct answer
    • Evidence in the passage alone ≠ correct answer (if it doesn't answer the question)

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Type #1 : If an answer choice includes details not , it's incorrect—no matter how possible or logical it seems.
  • ✓Type #2 and Type #3 : Look for specific details and strong statements.
  • ✓Type #4 : Don't pick an answer just because it contains exact words or phrases from the passage—the ACT often puts passage words in incorrect choices.
  • ✓Type #5 : The most difficult type.

lessons.subject: reading
lessons.title: Topic 2.5 - Words in Context Questions
lessons.content:
Words in context questions ask you to select what a word or phrase "most nearly means" in the context of the passage. Usually, you're determining the meaning of a word or phrase used in an unusual or uncommon way, and the correct answer is not the actual definition of the word but instead an alternate meaning based on the context.

1. How to Identify Words in Context Questions

  • Words in context questions always have the phrase "most nearly means"
    • Example: "As used in line 9, 'critical' most nearly means:"
    • The question will specify the exact line number where the word or phrase appears
    • Answer choices typically provide 4 different possible meanings of the word

Finding the Correct Answer

  • To find the correct answer, you must read for context
    • Read the sentence before, the sentence the word or phrase is in, and the following sentence
    • If you're still not clear on what the word or phrase means, read for more context—as much as you need
    • The surrounding text will help you understand how the word is being used in this specific instance

2. Method #1 — Pick Your Own Word

  • Step 1: Read for context
    • Read at least 1 sentence before and after the word or phrase in the question
    • Read more if necessary to understand the context
  • Step 2: Pick your own word(s) to replace the word or phrase in the question
    • Write your word(s) down to keep track of your thinking
    • If you're having trouble picking a specific word, try to pick a tone instead
    • Decide if the tone of the word or phrase is positive, negative, or neutral based on the surrounding text
  • Step 3: Look at the answer choices and pick the one that best matches
    • Compare each answer choice to your word(s) or tone
    • Select the answer that most closely matches what you came up with

3. Method #2 — Read the Answer Choices Back in the Passage

  • Step 1: Read each answer choice back in the passage
    • Substitute each answer choice in place of the word in the passage
    • Make sure to still read for context when you plug in each answer choice
    • Don't just read the single sentence—read the surrounding sentences too
  • Step 2: Pick the answer choice that best replaces the word in the passage
    • The correct answer will fit naturally in the context of the passage
    • Both approaches are equally effective, so which one you use is a matter of preference

4. Tip #1 — Do Not Assume the Hard Vocabulary Word is Correct

  • Words in context questions are one place the ACT commonly tests vocabulary knowledge
    • If you see any word(s) that you do not know, do not assume the hard word is correct
    • Many students mistakenly think: "Oh, this is the ACT...it must be the hard word since they're testing my vocabulary"
    • Wrong! Sometimes the ACT is testing your vocabulary and the hard word is correct
    • Other times, the hard word is just a decoy and a simpler word that you know fits correctly

5. Tip #2 — Do Not Pick the Answer Choice That Defines the Word

  • The correct answer is rarely the definition of the word
    • Most commonly, the word or phrase in the passage is used in an uncommon or unusual way that differs from the definition
    • The ACT is testing whether you can understand the word based on context, not just whether you know the definition
    • However, this is not always the case—sometimes the correct answer is the definition
    • This occurs most commonly for hard vocabulary words where the ACT is genuinely testing if you know the word

6. Tip #3 — Do the Best You Can With the Words You Know

  • On words in context questions, do the best you can with the words you know
    • If there is a word you know and it works, pick that word
    • If you know a word and it does not work, cross it off
    • If you're stuck between two words that you do not know, bubble in your best guess and move on

Do Not Waste Time on Unknown Words

  • Do not waste time trying to figure out the definitions of words that you do not know
    • You either know what a word means, or you don't
    • No amount of time thinking about what the word means will help you
    • Move on and use your time answering other questions where you can make progress
    • It's better to guess and spend your time on questions you can answer confidently

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Words questions always have the phrase "most nearly means" and ask you.
  • ✓Two effective methods: Method #1 is to read for context, pick your own word , then find the answer choice that best matches.
  • ✓Do not assume the hard vocabulary word is correct—sometimes it is.
  • ✓Do the best you can with words you know: pick words that work, eliminate words that don't.

lessons.subject: science
lessons.title: Science Section Basics
lessons.content:
The ACT Science section tests your ability to analyze scientific data, interpret graphs and tables, understand experimental design, evaluate competing hypotheses, and draw evidence-based conclusions. Unlike traditional science tests that assess memorized content knowledge, the ACT Science section primarily measures your scientific reasoning and data interpretation skills.

With only 35 minutes to answer 40 questions across 6-7 passages, you must work quickly and efficiently while maintaining accuracy. This lesson introduces the fundamental structure of the Science section, explains what skills are actually being tested, and provides a roadmap for approaching this challenging but highly manageable section of the ACT.

1. Understanding the Science Section Format

The ACT Science section is the fourth and final section of the test, consisting of 6-7 passages with 40 total questions. You have exactly 35 minutes to complete all questions, which translates to approximately 5 minutes per passage.

Understanding the structure, passage types, and time constraints is essential for developing an effective strategy that maximizes your score.

Section Timing and Passage Distribution

  • 40 questions:
    • . The number of questions per passage varies depending on the passage type
    • most passages have 5-6 questions, but the Conflicting Viewpoints passage typically has 7 questions. This means you have approximately 52.5 seconds per question, but in practice, you need to account for the time required to read and understand passages, study figures
  • analyze data. The strict time limit makes the Science section one of the most time-pressured parts of the ACT. Many students report that their biggest challenge is finishing all passages within the allotted time, which is why developing efficient reading and data analysis strategies is crucial.

The Three Passage Types

  • Data Representation: (2-3 passages with 5 questions each)
  • Research Summaries: (3-4 passages with 6 questions each), and
  • Conflicting Viewpoints:
    • (1 passage with 7 questions). Data Representation passages present scientific information through graphs
    • and diagrams with minimal text
    • testing your ability to extract and analyze data. Research Summaries passages describe one or more experiments
    • testing your understanding of experimental design
  • results. Conflicting Viewpoints passages present two or more scientists or students discussing different hypotheses or theories about the same phenomenon, testing your ability to compare and contrast scientific perspectives. Recognizing these passage types immediately helps you adjust your reading strategy and know what to expect.

Content Areas Covered

  • Earth/space sciences:
    • . Topics might include genetics, ecology, chemical reactions, atomic structure, motion and forces, electricity, geology, meteorology, astronomy, and more. However, the ACT does not expect you to have memorized extensive science content
    • nearly all information needed to answer questions is provided in the passage itself. The section primarily tests your ability to interpret data, understand experimental methods
  • apply basic scientific reasoning rather than recall specific facts. That said, having a general familiarity with basic science concepts (like understanding what pH measures, knowing that temperature affects reaction rates, or recognizing common scientific units) can help you work more efficiently.

Scoring and Performance Expectations

  • raw score: (0-40), which is then converted to a
  • scaled score: from 1-36. The conversion table varies slightly from test to test to account for difficulty differences
  • generally, missing 2-3 questions can still yield a score in the 33-35 range, while missing 6-8 questions typically results in a score around 28-30. There is
  • no penalty for wrong answers: so you should always guess if you're running out of time. The Science section is often considered one of the most improvable sections of the ACT because success depends more on test-taking strategies and data interpretation skills than on extensive content knowledge
  • Students who initially struggle with timing often see significant score improvements after learning efficient passage navigation techniques and question-answering strategies.

Example: Section Breakdown Typical Science section structure: - Data Representation passages: 2-3 passages × 5 questions = 10-15 questions - Research Summaries passages: 3-4 passages × 6 questions = 18-24 questions - Conflicting Viewpoints passage: 1 passage × 7 questions = 7 questions Total: 6-7 passages with 40 questions in 35 minutes. Recommended pacing: 5 minutes per passage, with flexibility to spend more time on complex passages and less on straightforward ones.

2. What the Science Section Actually Tests

Despite its name, the ACT Science section is better understood as a scientific reasoning test rather than a traditional science knowledge test. The section assesses three main skill categories: Interpretation of Data, Scientific Investigation, and Evaluation of Models, Inferences, and Experimental Results.

Understanding these skill categories helps you recognize what each question is asking and how to approach it strategically.

Interpretation of Data (40-50% of questions)

Interpretation of Data questions test your ability to read graphs and tables, identify trends, extract specific values, and interpolate or extrapolate data. You might be asked to determine what temperature corresponds to a specific pressure value from a graph, identify whether two variables have a positive or inverse relationship, or predict what would happen if an experiment continued beyond the data shown.

These questions require careful attention to axis labels, units, scales, and legends. Common question stems include:.

  • "According to Figure 1, what was the pH when temperature was 40°C?", "Based on Table 2, as concentration increased
  • reaction rate:
    • or "If the experiment had continued
    • the mass at 60 seconds would most likely have been:"
  • Success on these questions comes from methodically reading data representations and avoiding careless errors like misreading scales or confusing which variable is which

Scientific Investigation (20-30% of questions)

  • Scientific Investigation: questions test your understanding of
  • scientific methodology:
    • . You need to identify which variables were manipulated (independent variables)
    • which were measured (dependent variables)
    • which were held constant (control variables)
    • and what the purpose of specific experimental procedures was. Questions might ask: "Which variable was directly manipulated by the researchers?"
  • "What was the purpose of Trial 1?", "Which of the following would be the best way to extend this experiment?", or "What hypothesis was being tested in Experiment 2?" These questions assess whether you understand how scientific experiments are structured and how scientists test hypotheses systematically. Strong performance requires understanding the logic behind experimental design and recognizing the difference between correlation and causation.

Evaluation of Models, Inferences, and Experimental Results (30-40% of questions)

  • Evaluation: questions test your ability to
  • evaluate whether evidence supports a hypothesis:
    • . These questions require higher-order thinking and often involve synthesizing information from multiple sources within a passage. You might be asked: "Based on the results of Experiments 1 and 2
    • which conclusion is best supported?"
    • "Which hypothesis is consistent with the data in Table 3?"
    • "Student 1 would most likely agree with which statement?"
  • or "What additional information would help determine which theory is correct?" These questions are typically more challenging because they require you to go beyond simply reading data and instead think critically about what the data means, what assumptions underlie different viewpoints, and what logical conclusions can be drawn. Success requires careful reasoning and avoiding common pitfalls like choosing answers that sound plausible but aren't actually supported by the passage.

The Minimal Role of Outside Knowledge

  • One of the most important things to understand about the ACT Science section is that it requires minimal outside content knowledge.
  • The vast majority of questions can be answered using only the information provided in the passage, figures, and tables. You might encounter 1-3 questions per test that require basic scientific knowledge (such as knowing that water boils at 100°C at standard pressure, understanding that photosynthesis produces oxygen, or recognizing common lab equipment), but these represent a very small percentage of total questions.
  • In fact, trying to apply outside knowledge can sometimes lead you astray if you make assumptions that contradict the passage's specific setup.
  • The best approach is to trust the passage and base your answers on what is explicitly stated or clearly implied by the data.
  • Students with limited science coursework can still achieve excellent scores by focusing on data interpretation and reasoning skills rather than worrying about content gaps..

Example: Skill Category Breakdown In a typical 40-question Science section: - 16-20 questions test Interpretation of Data (reading graphs, identifying trends, extracting values) - 8-12 questions test Scientific Investigation (experimental design, variables, controls) - 12-16 questions test Evaluation (drawing conclusions, analyzing viewpoints, making inferences) Knowing this distribution helps you understand where to focus your practice and what skills matter most for a high score. The majority of questions test data interpretation and evaluation skills rather than memorized science facts.

3. Common Misconceptions About the Science Section

Many students approach the Science section with incorrect assumptions that hinder their performance. Understanding and correcting these misconceptions is crucial for developing an effective strategy and avoiding common pitfalls that prevent students from reaching their scoring potential.

Misconception #1: You Need Extensive Science Knowledge

  • scientific reasoning and data interpretation skills:
    • not memorized content. Students who have taken Advanced Placement science courses don't necessarily score higher than students with basic science coursework if they haven't developed strong graph-reading and analytical skills. The passage provides all necessary context
    • definitions
    • and background information. Your job is to
  • apply logical reasoning: not recall obscure scientific facts. In fact, overthinking questions by trying to apply outside knowledge often leads students to incorrect answers when they should simply trust what the passage explicitly states. Focus on developing strong data analysis skills rather than cramming science content.

Misconception #2: You Must Read Every Word of Text

  • strategic skimming approach: quickly reading the introduction to understand the general topic, focusing primarily on
  • figures and tables: and only reading detailed text when needed to answer specific questions. The figures often contain the most important information
  • paragraphs of text frequently just explain procedures in more detail than necessary. Learning to
  • prioritize visual data:
    • over lengthy descriptions can save significant time. However, this doesn't mean ignoring text entirely
    • you need to read enough to understand what was studied and what the variables represent, but you don't need to memorize every procedural detail

Misconception #3: Harder Science Topics Mean Harder Questions

Students often feel intimidated when they see passages about unfamiliar or complex-sounding topics like "polymerase chain reaction" or "superconductivity." However, passage topic complexity does not correlate with question difficulty. A passage about a sophisticated physics concept might have straightforward questions that simply ask you to read values from a graph, while a passage about a simple experiment with plants might have challenging questions that require synthesizing information from multiple trials.

The ACT deliberately uses technical-sounding topics to test whether you can stay focused and confident when faced with unfamiliar material. Don't let intimidating vocabulary or advanced-sounding topics psyche you out.

The questions are designed to be answerable regardless of your prior knowledge of the specific topic. Stay calm, focus on the data, and trust that all necessary information is provided.

Misconception #4: The Passages Must Be Completed in Order

Many students assume they must work through Science passages in the order they appear, but this is not a requirement. In fact, strategic passage selection can improve both your score and confidence.

Some students find Data Representation passages faster and easier because they focus primarily on graphs with minimal text, so they tackle those first to bank time for more complex passages. Others prefer starting with Research Summaries because they find the experimental format more intuitive.

Still others save the Conflicting Viewpoints passage for last because it has the most text and different question types. You can also preview passages quickly and identify which ones look most straightforward based on figure complexity and text length.

Experiment during practice to find an order that maximizes your efficiency. Just be careful to bubble answers in the correct spots on your answer sheet when you skip around.

Example: Correcting Misconceptions in Practice Before: "I need to read every word carefully and I'm worried because I haven't taken AP Chemistry yet." After: "I'll focus primarily on the figures and tables, skim the text for context, and trust that all information I need is in the passage. My score depends on data interpretation skills, not memorized content." This mindset shift alone can lead to significant time savings and reduced anxiety, allowing you to work more efficiently and confidently through Science passages.

4. Building Your Science Section Foundation

Success on the ACT Science section requires developing a systematic approach that combines efficient passage navigation, strong data interpretation skills, strategic time management, and focused practice. This section introduces foundational concepts and habits that will support your improvement across all Science question types.

Developing a Passage Attack Strategy

  • quickly reading the introduction to understand what phenomenon or question is being studied
  • examining all figures and tables to understand what variables are being measured and what trends are visible
  • skimming any experimental descriptions to identify how trials differ from each other, and
  • moving to the questions, referring back to specific parts of the passage as needed.

This approach prioritizes the most important information (the data itself) while avoiding getting bogged down in procedural details. However, you should experiment with variations during practice to find what works best for your reading style and strengths.

Some students prefer reading questions first to know what to look for, while others find this disruptive. Find your optimal approach through deliberate practice.

Mastering Figure and Table Analysis

  • graphs, tables, and diagrams: developing strong figure-reading skills is essential. When you look at any figure, immediately identify: (1) what
  • variables: are being shown (check axis labels and table headers), (2) what
  • units: are being used (meters, seconds, grams, etc.), (3) what
  • scale: is being used (does the axis start at zero or some other value?), (4) what
  • relationships or trends:
    • are visible (do values increase
    • or stay constant?)
    • and (5) what different
  • lines or symbols: represent (check the legend). Practice reading figures actively by asking yourself these questions for every graph or table you encounter
  • Also train yourself to spot common pitfalls like logarithmic scales, multiple y-axes, or unusual units that could cause misinterpretation.

Understanding Variables and Experimental Design Basics

  • independent variables: (what the researcher changes)
  • dependent variables: (what the researcher measures), and
  • control variables:
    • (what the researcher keeps the same). For example
    • if an experiment tests how different fertilizers affect plant growth
    • the fertilizer type is the independent variable
    • plant height is the dependent variable
  • factors like water amount, sunlight, and temperature should be control variables. You should also understand why scientists run
  • control groups:
    • (to provide a baseline for comparison)
    • why they repeat trials multiple times (to ensure results are reliable and not due to chance)
    • and how to distinguish between
  • correlation and causation: . These fundamental concepts appear repeatedly across Science passages.

Time Management and Practice Strategies

  • Improving your Science score requires deliberate practice with a focus on both accuracy and speed
  • Start by working on individual passages untimed to ensure you understand how to analyze data and answer questions correctly.
  • Once your accuracy is consistently high (80%+ correct), begin adding time pressure by setting a 5-minute timer per passage
  • Track which passage types and question types give you the most trouble, and dedicate extra practice to those areas.
  • When reviewing practice questions, don't just check whether you got them right or wrong—carefully review the reasoning behind each answer
  • figure out why wrong answers are incorrect, and identify what clues in the passage you should have noticed.
  • Also practice on full-length Science sections to build stamina and ensure your strategy works under realistic testing conditions
  • Many students find that their Science score improves more rapidly than other sections once they understand the underlying skills being tested and develop efficient strategies..

Example: Building Your Science Practice Plan Week 1-2: Master individual passage types untimed. Focus on Data Representation passages first (simplest), then Research Summaries, then Conflicting Viewpoints.

Week 3-4: Practice full Science sections with timing (35 minutes). Identify your weak passage types and question types.

Week 5-6: Target your weaknesses with focused practice. Review every question you miss to understand the reasoning.

Week 7-8: Take full-length practice ACTs to build stamina and refine your pacing strategy. Adjust your approach based on results.

This structured progression builds skills systematically while maintaining motivation through visible progress.

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓The Science section has 35 minutes for 6-7 passages and 40 questions—approximately 5 minutes per passage.
  • ✓The section tests scientific reasoning and data interpretation skills.
  • ✓Three passage types appear: Data Representation , Research Summaries .
  • ✓Focus primarily on figures and tables—they contain most of the important information for answering questions.
  • ✓Questions test three skills: Interpretation of Data , Scientific Investigation .
  • ✓Nearly all questions can be answered using only information provided —outside knowledge is rarely needed.
  • ✓You don't need to read every word—strategic skimming focused on data and key concepts is more efficient.
  • ✓Passages don't have to be completed in order—identify and tackle your strongest passage types first.
  • ✓Master figure analysis by identifying variables, units, scales, trends.
  • ✓The Science section is highly improvable through strategic practice focused on data interpretation and time management.

lessons.subject: science
lessons.title: Topic 3.2 - Cannot Be Determined
lessons.content:
Questions with "cannot be determined" as an answer choice test whether you can identify when the provided data is insufficient to answer the question. The key is to systematically search for the required information in figures, tables, and experimental text before concluding that it cannot be determined.

When to Choose "Cannot Be Determined"

  • Choose "cannot be determined" when the locators from the question cannot be found in the data:
    • The figure doesn't show the specific variable you need
    • The table doesn't include the row or column required
    • The experimental text doesn't provide the necessary information
    • The data shows aggregated totals but the question asks for individual values
  • Do NOT treat these questions differently - use the same systematic approach:
    • Start by checking figures and tables
    • Then check experimental text above the figures
    • Only after exhausting all sources should you choose "cannot be determined"

Common Traps: Units and Aggregated Data

  • Unit mismatches are a common trick in difficult questions:
    • Question asks for grams per week, but figure shows total weight gain
    • Question asks for individual dog consumption, but figure shows group totals
    • Question asks for percentage of one food type, but only total percentages are given
    • Pay close attention to what units the question asks for vs. what units are provided
  • Aggregated vs. individual data:
    • If the figure shows total for a group, you cannot determine individual values
    • Example: Figure shows total food remaining for 5 dogs → cannot determine for 1 dog
    • Example: Table shows weight gain → cannot determine starting weight without baseline

Systematic Search Strategy

  • Step 1: Identify exactly what the question is asking for:
    • What variable? (weight, food amount, percentage, etc.)
    • What units? (grams, grams per week, percentage, etc.)
    • For which subject? (individual, group, specific food type, etc.)
    • At what time/condition? (after 3 hours, at Week 4, etc.)
  • Step 2: Check the figure referenced:
    • Look at axis labels - do they match what you need?
    • Check the legend - does it show the specific group/food type?
    • Verify the units match what the question asks for
  • Step 3: Check tables (if present):
    • Do the rows/columns include the specific item you need?
    • Can you combine information from multiple tables/figures?
  • Step 4: Check experimental text:
    • Sometimes the answer is in the description above the figures
    • Look for setup details, control variables, or baseline measurements
  • Step 5: Only if you cannot find the information anywhere:
    • Choose "Cannot be determined"
    • Be confident - if the data truly isn't there, this is the correct answer

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Systematically search figures, tables.
  • ✓Pay close attention to units - mismatched units are a common trap (grams vs.
  • ✓Distinguish between aggregated group data and individual data.
  • ✓If the required locators (specific variables, conditions.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: ACT Test Basics & Overview
lessons.content:
Understanding the ACT Test structure, scoring system, timing strategies, and question types is essential before diving into specific content. The ACT consists of four required sections—English, Math, Reading, and Science—plus an optional Writing section. This lesson will give you a complete overview of the test format, teach you how scores work, and provide strategic insights to help you maximize your performance on test day.

1. Test Structure and Format

The ACT is a standardized test used by colleges for admissions decisions. Unlike the SAT, the ACT tests more straightforward knowledge and has a Science section. The test is divided into four required sections and one optional section, with a total testing time of about 3 hours (or 3.5 hours with Writing).

English Section: 45 Minutes, 75 Questions

The English section tests grammar, punctuation, sentence structure, and rhetorical skills across five passages. You'll have approximately 45 seconds per question. Questions test conventions of standard English (grammar and usage), production of writing (strategy and organization), and knowledge of language (style and tone). This section appears first on the test, so starting strong is crucial for building confidence.

Math Section: 60 Minutes, 60 Questions

The Math section covers pre-algebra, elementary algebra, intermediate algebra, coordinate geometry, plane geometry, and trigonometry. You have one minute per question on average. A reference sheet with basic formulas is provided, but memorizing key formulas will save time. Calculators are permitted (and highly recommended) for this entire section.

Reading Section: 35 Minutes, 40 Questions

The Reading section includes four passages: Prose Fiction/Literary Narrative, Social Science, Humanities, and Natural Science. Each passage has 10 questions. You'll have about 8 minutes and 45 seconds per passage, so time management is critical. Questions test your ability to determine main ideas, locate details, understand sequences, make comparisons, comprehend cause-effect relationships, determine word meaning, and analyze author's voice and method.

Science Section: 35 Minutes, 40 Questions

The Science section tests interpretation, analysis, evaluation, reasoning, and problem-solving skills through data representation, research summaries, and conflicting viewpoints passages. Don't worry—you don't need advanced science knowledge! The section primarily tests your ability to read graphs, charts, and tables, and apply scientific reasoning. Most students find this section challenging due to the pace (about 53 seconds per question).

2. Scoring System and What Scores Mean

Understanding how the ACT is scored helps you set realistic goals and track your progress. The ACT uses a scaled scoring system from 1-36, and there's no penalty for wrong answers, so you should always guess if you're running out of time.

How Scores Are Calculated

Each section (English, Math, Reading, Science) receives a scaled score from 1-36 based on the number of questions you answer correctly (your raw score). These four section scores are then averaged to create your Composite Score, which is the most important number for college admissions. The composite is rounded to the nearest whole number—for example, if your four section scores are 28, 30, 26, and 32, your composite is (28+30+26+32)/4 = 29.

What's a Good Score?

The national average composite score is around 20-21. A score of 24 puts you in approximately the 75th percentile, meaning you scored higher than 75% of test-takers. Competitive colleges typically want scores above 27, while highly selective schools (Ivy League, top liberal arts colleges) generally expect 32-36. However, "good" depends on your target schools—research the average ACT scores for admitted students at colleges you're interested in.

Subscores and STEM Score

In addition to section scores, you'll receive subscores (1-18 scale) for specific skill areas like "Production of Writing" in English or "Integrating Essential Skills" in Math. You'll also see a STEM score, which averages your Math and Science scores. While colleges primarily focus on your composite and individual section scores, subscores can help identify specific areas for improvement.

Superscoring

Many colleges practice superscoring, which means they take your highest section scores across multiple test dates and recalculate a new composite. For example, if you score English 28, Math 30, Reading 25, Science 27 on Test 1, then English 26, Math 32, Reading 28, Science 26 on Test 2, your superscore would combine the best from each: 28, 32, 28, 27 = composite 28.75, rounded to 29. Check whether your target colleges superscore—this policy encourages retaking the ACT to improve individual sections.

3. General Test-Taking Strategies

Success on the ACT requires more than content knowledge—you need effective time management, strategic guessing, and stress management skills. These universal strategies apply across all four sections.

Always Answer Every Question

The ACT has no guessing penalty—wrong answers don't count against you. This means you should NEVER leave a question blank. If you're running out of time, quickly bubble in an answer for every remaining question. Statistically, random guessing gives you about a 20-25% chance of being correct, which is better than 0%!

Pace Yourself and Use a Watch

Time pressure is one of the ACT's biggest challenges. Wear a watch (analog watches are best since digital devices aren't allowed) and set checkpoints. For example, in Reading, you should finish passage 1 by minute 8, passage 2 by minute 17, passage 3 by minute 26, and passage 4 by minute 35. Don't spend too long on any single question—if you're stuck after 30-45 seconds, make your best guess, circle it in the test booklet, and move on. You can return if time permits.

Answer Easy Questions First

Not all questions are created equal. Some are straightforward, while others require complex reasoning. Within each section, scan for "quick points"—questions you can answer confidently in 20-30 seconds. Rack up these easy points first, then tackle harder questions with your remaining time. This strategy maximizes your score even if time runs out.

Process of Elimination

When you're unsure of the correct answer, use process of elimination. Cross out answers you know are wrong in your test booklet, then guess among remaining choices. Eliminating even one wrong answer improves your odds from 20% to 25% (for 4-choice questions) or 25% to 33% (for 3-choice questions). Often you can eliminate 2-3 choices, giving you a strong chance of guessing correctly.

4. Test Day Preparation and Logistics

Your performance on test day depends not only on preparation but also on practical considerations like what to bring, how to manage stress, and what to expect at the testing center. Being well-prepared logistically helps you focus entirely on the test itself.

What to Bring

Mandatory items: your admission ticket (printed from your ACT account) and an acceptable photo ID (school ID, driver's license, or passport). Recommended items: several sharpened No. 2 pencils with erasers, an approved calculator with fresh batteries, a watch (not a smartwatch), snacks and water for breaks, and layered clothing in case the room is too hot or cold. Do NOT bring: cell phones, smartwatches, prohibited calculators, reference materials, or scratch paper (you can use the test booklet).

Night Before and Morning Of

The night before: review a few key formulas or grammar rules, but don't cram—it's more important to get 8 hours of sleep. Pack your backpack with everything you'll need. Set multiple alarms. The morning of: eat a substantial, protein-rich breakfast (avoid sugary foods that cause energy crashes). Arrive at the test center by 7:45 AM for an 8:00 AM start—latecomers aren't admitted. Use the bathroom before testing begins, as breaks are limited.

Managing Test Anxiety

Feeling nervous is normal, but excessive test anxiety can hurt your performance. Practice deep breathing techniques: inhale slowly for 4 counts, hold for 4 counts, exhale for 4 counts. During the test, if you feel overwhelmed, close your eyes for 10 seconds, take a deep breath, and refocus. Remember: you can retake the ACT—this one test doesn't define you. Confidence comes from preparation, so thorough practice with realistic timed tests is your best defense against anxiety.

After the Test

Scores are typically released 2-8 weeks after your test date (check your ACT account for the exact release date). You can send your scores to colleges for free on test day (list up to 4 schools), or pay later to send additional score reports. Many students take the ACT 2-3 times to improve their composite score—each attempt gives you new experience and insights. Review your score report carefully to identify weak areas, then create a targeted study plan for your next attempt.

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓The ACT has four sections: English , Math , Reading , Science .
  • ✓Scores range from 1-36 per section; your Composite is the average of all four sections.
  • ✓There's no guessing penalty—ALWAYS answer every question, even if you have to guess.
  • ✓Time management is crucial: use a watch, set checkpoints.
  • ✓Many colleges superscore—taking the ACT multiple times can improve your composite.
  • ✓Test day essentials: admission ticket, photo ID, No.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.1 - Building Complete Sentences
lessons.content:
Sentence structure questions make up 15-20% of the ACT English Test—that's 11-15 questions per test! To master these questions, you must understand how to identify and properly combine clauses, fix fragments, and avoid comma splices.

1. Clauses, Phrases, and Fragments

Independent Clauses

  • An independent clause can stand as a sentence by itself
    • Always has a subject and a verb
    • Read the sentence out loud—if you can stop talking at the end, it's an independent clause
    • Examples: "The dog chased its tail" / "He picked it up"

Dependent Clauses

  • A dependent clause cannot stand alone as a complete sentence
    • Most often created by adding a subordinating conjunction to the front
    • Common subordinating conjunctions: after, although, as, because, before, even though, if, in order to, once, since, that, though, unless, until, when, whenever, where, whether, while, whatever
    • Examples: "While the dog chased its tail..." / "Because he picked it up..."
  • How to identify: If you feel like you need to keep talking after reading it, it's dependent
    • Cover the first word and read the rest—if it becomes a complete sentence, the original was a dependent clause
    • If it's still incomplete after covering the first word, it's a phrase

Phrases

  • A phrase lacks a subject or verb or both
    • Does not express a complete thought and can never stand alone
    • Provides additional descriptive information in a sentence
    • Examples: "Chasing its tail..." / "Excited to open up his present..."
    • All missing the subject—we don't know who is doing the action

Sentence Fragments

  • A sentence fragment is missing a subject or verb or both
    • Cannot stand by itself as a complete sentence
    • Usually sounds plain wrong when you read it aloud
    • Incorrect: "The student running to get to class on time" (missing verb)
    • Correct: "The student running to get to class on time dropped her water bottle"

2. Five Types of Compound Sentences

  • On the ACT, multiple clauses must always appear as one of these 5 types
    • The ACT tests these rules constantly—memorize all 5!
    • Answer choices that "sound good" but break these rules are wrong

Type 1: Two Separate Independent Clauses with Periods

  • Structure: Independent clause + period + Independent clause
    • Example: "Mary loves dogs. Andrew loves cats."

Type 2: Comma + FANBOYS Joining 2 Independent Clauses

  • Structure: Independent clause + comma + FANBOYS + Independent clause
    • FANBOYS = For, And, Nor, But, Or, Yet, So (memorize these!)
    • Example: "Mary loves dogs, and Andrew loves cats."
    • CRITICAL: Must have BOTH the comma AND the FANBOYS word

Type 3: Semicolon Between 2 Independent Clauses

  • Structure: Independent clause + semicolon + Independent clause
    • Example: "Mary loves dogs; Andrew loves cats."
    • On the ACT, a semicolon functions the same as a period
    • Both sides MUST be independent clauses

Type 4: Dependent Clause Followed by Independent Clause (Comma)

  • Structure: Dependent clause + comma + Independent clause
    • Example: "While Mary loves dogs, Andrew loves cats."
    • When dependent clause comes BEFORE independent, use a comma

Type 5: Independent Clause Straight Into Dependent Clause (No Comma)

  • Structure: Independent clause + no comma + Dependent clause
    • Example: "Mary loves dogs while Andrew loves cats."
    • When independent clause comes BEFORE dependent, NO comma

3. Comma Splices

  • A comma splice joins two independent clauses with only a comma—this is ALWAYS incorrect
    • Incorrect: "It is believed that bulls are enraged by the color red, they are actually colorblind"
    • A comma by itself CANNOT join two independent clauses
    • Most common error students make with sentence structure

Five Ways to Fix a Comma Splice

  • Use the 5 compound sentence rules to fix comma splices
    • Rule #1 (Period): "...color red. They are actually colorblind."
    • Rule #2 (Comma + FANBOYS): "...color red, but they are actually colorblind."
    • Rule #3 (Semicolon): "...color red; they are actually colorblind."
    • Rule #4 (Dependent → Independent): "While it is believed that bulls are enraged by the color red, they are actually colorblind."
    • Rule #5 (Independent → Dependent): "It is believed that bulls are enraged by the color red though they are actually colorblind."

4. Spotting and Solving Sentence Structure Questions

How to Identify Sentence Structure Questions

  • Punctuation variations in answer choices
    • Periods, semicolons, commas, and FANBOYS appear in different positions
    • If you see these variations, it's a sentence structure question
  • Subject or verb forms vary between choices
    • One choice says "drove" while another says "driving"
    • Some choices have subjects/verbs, others don't
    • Watch for comma splices in these questions

Three-Step Approach to Sentence Structure Questions

  • Step 1: Find where the sentence is being "split"
    • Look for the punctuation point in the underlined portion
  • Step 2: Look left and right of the split point
    • Identify whether each side is independent, dependent, or a phrase
    • Read each side separately to test if it can stand alone
  • Step 3: Apply the sentence structure rules
    • Use the 5 compound sentence types to determine the correct answer
    • Eliminate choices that break the rules

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Independent clauses can stand alone as complete sentences, while dependent clauses (starting.
  • ✓There are exactly 5 ways to combine clauses correctly.
  • ✓A comma by itself CANNOT join two independent clauses—this creates a comma splice.
  • ✓To solve sentence structure questions.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.9 - Grammar Review
lessons.content:
This comprehensive grammar review synthesizes all the major concepts tested on the ACT English Test. Now that you've studied individual topics, it's essential to develop integrated strategies, error recognition patterns, and efficient test-taking approaches. The ACT doesn't announce which grammar rule each question tests—you must quickly identify error types and apply the appropriate fix. This lesson provides a systematic framework for approaching any grammar question with confidence and speed.

1. The Complete Grammar Error Checklist

When you encounter an underlined portion, systematically check for the most common error types. This mental checklist helps you identify problems quickly without wasting time.

The "Big 7" Grammar Categories

These seven categories account for approximately 70-80% of all grammar questions on the ACT:

1. Punctuation (15-18 questions) Commas, semicolons, colons, dashes, apostrophes 2. Sentence Structure (15-18 questions) Fragments, run-ons, comma splices, subordination 3. Verbs (8-10 questions) Agreement, tense, form, voice 4. Pronouns (5-7 questions)

Agreement, case, clarity, reference 5. Modifiers (4-6 questions) Misplaced, dangling, squinting modifiers 6. Parallel Structure (3-5 questions) Lists, conjunctions, comparisons 7. Word Choice & Idioms (3-5 questions) Commonly confused words, prepositional idioms

Quick Diagnostic Questions

Ask yourself these questions in order when you see an underlined portion:

→ Is there punctuation? Check comma rules, semicolon/colon usage → Is there a verb? Check subject-verb agreement, tense, form → Is there a pronoun? Check agreement, case, clear antecedent → Does the sentence begin with a phrase? Check for dangling modifiers

→ Is there a list or conjunction? Check parallel structure → Can the sentence stand alone? Check for fragments/run-ons

Common Error Combinations

The ACT often tests multiple concepts in one question. Watch for these combinations:

Comma + Verb Agreement: Prepositional phrase between subject and verb, with comma placement Modifier + Pronoun: Dangling modifier where the pronoun reference is ambiguous Parallel + Verb Tense: List items with inconsistent verb forms

2. Systematic Error Recognition Strategies

Develop a consistent approach to every grammar question. This systematic method prevents you from missing errors and helps you work efficiently under time pressure.

Step 1: Read the Sentence Completely

Always read from the beginning of the sentence (or previous sentence if needed) through the end. Context matters—you can't identify tense errors, pronoun agreement, or modifier placement without understanding the full sentence.

Why this matters: Many errors depend on elements outside the underlined portion. Subject-verb agreement requires finding the subject (often not underlined). Verb tense requires checking surrounding verbs. Pronoun clarity requires seeing the antecedent.

Step 2: Trust Your Ear, But Verify with Rules

If something sounds wrong, it probably is. However, some errors sound correct (like "everyone...their"), so verify with the rules you've learned.

Ear + Rules = Accuracy → If it sounds wrong: Identify which rule is violated → If it sounds right: Still check the Big 7 categories systematically

Step 3: Eliminate Obviously Wrong Answers

Use process of elimination to narrow choices before identifying the specific error.

Common eliminators:

• Creates a fragment or run-on • Uses wrong verb tense for the context • Creates pronoun agreement error • Breaks parallel structure in a list • Makes the sentence significantly more wordy without adding clarity

Step 4: Look for Visual Cues

Certain patterns in the answer choices tell you what the question is testing.

Different punctuation marks? → Punctuation question Different verb forms? → Verb agreement or tense Different pronouns? → Pronoun agreement or case Sentence restructured? → Modifier placement or sentence structure Different word order in list? → Parallel structure

3. Time Management and Pacing

The ACT English section gives you 45 minutes for 75 questions across 5 passages. That's 36 seconds per question or 9 minutes per passage. Effective time management is crucial for finishing strong.

The 9-Minute Per Passage Strategy

Aim to complete each passage in approximately 9 minutes, which includes reading and answering all 15 questions.

Minute 0-2: Read the passage naturally, answering inline grammar questions as you encounter them Minute 2-7: Work through remaining grammar and style questions systematically Minute 7-9: Handle rhetorical skills questions (organization, purpose, style)

Quick vs. Slow Questions

Not all questions take equal time. Recognize which should be fast and which require more thought.

Quick questions (15-20 seconds):

• Obvious verb agreement errors • Clear punctuation rules (commas with introductory phrases) • Obvious fragments or run-ons • Word choice errors (their/there/they're)

Slower questions (45-60 seconds):

• Rhetorical skills (transitions, adding/deleting sentences) • Complex modifier questions requiring sentence restructuring • Pronoun clarity when multiple antecedents possible • Organization questions (sentence placement)

When to Skip and Return

If you're stuck after 45 seconds, mark your best guess, circle the question number, and move on. Return to it if you have time at the end.

Critical Strategy: Never leave questions blank. Even if you're unsure, eliminate obviously wrong answers and make an educated guess. There's no guessing penalty on the ACT.

Pacing Checkpoints

Check your progress at these intervals to ensure you're on track:

15 minutes: Should be finishing passage 2 (question 30) 30 minutes: Should be finishing passage 4 (question 60) 40 minutes: Should be on passage 5 with 5 minutes to finish

4. Test Day Strategies and Final Tips

Beyond knowing grammar rules, test day success requires strategic approaches to maximize your score. These final strategies help you navigate the test efficiently and avoid common pitfalls.

When "NO CHANGE" Is Correct

About 20-25% of questions have "NO CHANGE" as the correct answer. Don't avoid this choice if you can't find an error.

Choose NO CHANGE when:

• You've checked all grammar rules and found no violations • Other answer choices create new errors • Other choices are unnecessarily wordy • The original is clear, concise, and correct

Shorter Is Usually Better

When choosing between grammatically correct options, the ACT typically favors conciseness. If two answers are both correct, choose the shorter one.

Example:

✗ Wordy: due to the fact that ✓ Concise: because

However: Never sacrifice clarity or correctness for brevity. If the shorter version creates an error or changes meaning, choose the longer correct option.

Avoid Extreme or Absolute Language

On rhetorical questions about adding/deleting information or main ideas, be wary of answer choices with extreme words like "always," "never," "only," "completely."

Read Answer Choices Carefully

The ACT loves to include answer choices that look similar but differ in one key detail. Read every word of each choice.

Common trap: Three choices are identical except one uses "affects" and another uses "effects." Missing this difference means picking the wrong answer.

Grammar Doesn't Always "Sound" Wrong

Some grammatically incorrect constructions sound natural in casual speech. Trust the rules over your ear in these cases:

• "Everyone brought their book" sounds fine but is grammatically wrong (everyone = singular) • "Between you and I" sounds formal but is wrong (object of preposition = me) • "The team are winning" sounds right to some but is wrong (team = singular)

Final Mental Checklist

Before moving to the next question, quickly verify:

✓ Your answer creates no new errors ✓ The sentence is complete and logical ✓ All subjects have verbs and all verbs have subjects ✓ Pronouns have clear antecedents ✓ Modifiers are placed next to what they describe

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓The Big 7 categories: Systematically check punctuation, sentence structure, verbs, pronouns, modifiers, parallel structure.
  • ✓Systematic approach: Always read the complete sentence for context, trust your ear but verify with rules, eliminate obviously wrong answers, and look for visual cues in answer choices to identify what's being tested
  • ✓Time management: Aim for 9 minutes per passage.
  • ✓Test day strategies: "NO CHANGE" is correct 20-25% of the time.
  • ✓Final verification: Before moving on, confirm your answer creates no new errors, the sentence is complete and logical, all subjects have verbs, pronouns have clear antecedents.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.2 - Essential Comma Rules
lessons.content:
Commas are the most common punctuation on the ACT English Test, appearing in 15-20 questions per test. To master comma questions, you need to understand the 4 types of commas and when each one should be used.

1. The Four Types of Commas

  • The ACT tests exactly 4 comma rules—master these and you'll handle every comma question
    • Each type has a specific purpose and can't be substituted with another
    • Understanding when to use each type is critical for avoiding comma errors

Type 1: Comma + FANBOYS

  • Use a comma and a FANBOYS word to join two independent clauses
    • FANBOYS = For, And, Nor, But, Or, Yet, So
    • Example: "My alarm clock did not go off this morning, so I arrived late at school"
    • Both sides must be independent clauses (complete sentences)

Type 2: Dependent Clause Followed by Independent Clause

  • When a dependent clause comes before an independent clause, use a comma to separate them
    • Example: "While electronic music has become very popular, many people still prefer classic rock"
    • The dependent clause starts with subordinating conjunctions like while, although, because, if
    • This is from Chapter 1's Rule #4 for compound sentences

Type 3: Unnecessary Information

  • Commas separate unnecessary information from the rest of the sentence
    • Information is unnecessary if you can remove it without fundamentally changing the sentence's meaning
    • Unnecessary information can be as short as one word or as long as a lengthy phrase
    • Example: "Mrs. Ellison, who is known for giving pop quizzes, is my least favorite teacher"
    • Example: "The basketball team, though, did not mount a comeback this week"

Type 4: Listing

  • Use commas when listing more than two items or with multiple adjectives modifying the same noun
    • Example with list: "The group ordered coconut shrimp, hot wings, and onion rings"
    • Example with adjectives: "The old, limping dog still managed to complete the 3-mile hike"
    • Use commas between all items in a series, including before the final "and" or "or"

2. Unnecessary Information Commas

  • The most common comma type on the ACT separates unnecessary information
    • Information is unnecessary if removing it doesn't fundamentally change the sentence's meaning
    • Unnecessary information can appear before a comma, after a comma, or between two commas
    • After removing unnecessary information, what remains must still be a complete sentence

The "Crossing-Out" Trick

  • To test if information is unnecessary, cross it out and read what remains
    • If the sentence is still complete and makes sense, the information is unnecessary
    • If the sentence becomes incomplete or loses critical meaning, the information is necessary (no commas)
    • Example: "The wooden beam, set at an angle, created an optical illusion"
    • Cross out "set at an angle" → "The wooden beam created an optical illusion" (still complete!)

Necessary vs. Unnecessary Information

  • Determining if information is truly unnecessary requires careful reading
    • Correct (necessary): "The dresses that need to be hemmed are hanging in the closet"
    • Without "that need to be hemmed," we don't know which specific dresses
    • Correct (unnecessary): "Judith, who went to fashion school, designs dresses for a living"
    • We already know who designs dresses (Judith), so the fashion school detail is extra

The Names Rule

  • The ACT loves testing comma usage with names—you'll see at least one question on this
    • If the identifier is NOT specific to one person (friend, teacher, physicist), the name is necessary—no commas
    • Example: "My friend Kelly recently moved to London" (I have multiple friends, so Kelly is necessary)
    • If the identifier IS specific to one person (best friend, youngest sister, CEO), the name is unnecessary—use commas
    • Example: "My best friend, Andrew, is a certified scuba diver" (I have only one best friend)

"That" vs. "Which" Phrases

  • Phrases starting with that never get commas—phrases starting with which always get commas
