Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Semicolons can replace periods—both sides must be independent clauses .
  • ✓Dashes can function like unnecessary information commas or parentheses when used in pairs.
  • ✓Apostrophes show possession or contractions.
  • ✓Quotation marks are used for direct quotes and.

lessons.subject: reading
lessons.title: Topic 1.3 - How to Approach the Reading Test
lessons.content:
There is no single best approach to the ACT Reading Test, but there is a best approach for you based on your reading speed, comprehension level, and personal preferences. This lesson presents six proven approaches—try different methods on practice tests to discover which one maximizes your score and confidence on test day.

1. Approach #1 — The Big Read

  • The simplest approach: read the entire passage at once, then work through the questions
    • Read the entire passage including the short intro above it
    • Read to understand the passage—don't skim
    • Take 2-4 minutes (3-6 minutes for extended time) at a medium pace
    • Be an active reader: move your finger/pencil along as you read, consider annotating

After Reading: Answering Questions

  • Strategic question approach
    • Skip broad passage questions (main idea, best summarizes) and save for last
    • Go back to the passage to find evidence for each question
    • Follow the 30-second rule: if you can't find evidence in 30 seconds, guess and move on
    • You don't need to answer questions in order—skip difficult ones and return later

Who Should Use This Approach

  • Best for students who:
    • Have strong reading comprehension
    • Can read and retain information well
    • Prefer understanding the big picture before diving into details
    • Can finish passages with time to spare

2. Approach #2 — The Big Read with Notes

  • Same as Approach #1, but with systematic note-taking while reading
    • Take brief notes in the margin summarizing each paragraph's main idea
    • Keep notes short—just 2-5 words per paragraph
    • Focus on what the paragraph is about, not every detail
    • Notes help you quickly locate information when answering questions

How to Take Effective Notes

  • Note-taking strategy
    • Example: For a paragraph about sea turtle migration, write "migration patterns"
    • Don't write full sentences—waste of time
    • Focus on the topic, not specific facts
    • Your notes create a roadmap for finding evidence later

Who Should Use This Approach

  • Best for students who:
    • Benefit from active reading through writing
    • Have trouble remembering where specific information appeared
    • Want a quick reference map of the passage
    • Can take notes quickly without losing too much time

3. Approach #3 — Label Then Read

  • Skim questions first to know what to look for, then read the passage
    • Quickly skim all 9 questions (don't read answer choices yet)
    • Label questions with line numbers in the margin next to relevant passage text
    • Then read the passage normally, already knowing what questions will ask
    • When you encounter a labeled section, you know a question relates to it

How to Label Effectively

  • Labeling process
    • If question #3 references lines 15-20, write "Q3" next to those lines in the passage
    • Don't spend time understanding the question deeply—just note where it points
    • This takes 30-60 seconds but saves time finding evidence later
    • You'll know which parts of the passage are most important for questions

Who Should Use This Approach

  • Best for students who:
    • Like knowing what to focus on before reading
    • Struggle to find evidence quickly
    • Want to read with purpose and direction
    • Can skim questions quickly without getting bogged down

4. Approach #4 — The Speed Reader

  • Read very quickly for general understanding, then use questions to guide detail-finding
    • Read the passage in 1-2 minutes (2-3 minutes for extended time)
    • Focus on understanding the main idea and passage structure
    • Don't worry about remembering every detail
    • When answering questions, return to the passage to find specific evidence

Key Strategy Points

  • How to speed read effectively
    • Read the first and last sentence of each paragraph carefully
    • Skim the middle sentences for the general idea
    • Note where different topics are discussed (mental map of passage)
    • Expect to reread sections carefully when answering questions

Who Should Use This Approach

  • Best for students who:
    • Are naturally fast readers
    • Can quickly locate information in text
    • Struggle with time management on Reading
    • Don't need to read every word to understand main ideas

5. Approach #5 — First and Last

  • Read only the first and last sentence of each paragraph, then answer questions
    • First sentence usually introduces the paragraph's topic
    • Last sentence often concludes or transitions to the next idea
    • This gives you the passage structure in 1-2 minutes
    • When answering questions, read the full relevant paragraph(s) for evidence

How This Approach Works

  • Strategic reading process
    • You'll understand the general flow and main topics
    • You won't know specific details until you read for questions
    • This approach is fastest but requires strong detail-finding skills
    • Plan to read full paragraphs when answering detail questions

Who Should Use This Approach

  • Best for students who:
    • Are extremely short on time
    • Struggle to finish all passages
    • Can quickly find and understand details when needed
    • Are comfortable with minimal initial passage understanding

6. Approach #6 — Working Backwards

  • Don't read the passage first—go straight to questions and find answers in the passage
    • Start with Question 1 (or any question with line numbers)
    • Read only the relevant passage section to answer that question
    • Move to the next question and repeat
    • Build your understanding of the passage as you answer questions

Strategy Details

  • How to work backwards effectively
    • Answer questions with line numbers first (easiest to locate)
    • Skip broad passage questions until last
    • By the time you answer specific questions, you'll understand enough for broad questions
    • This is covered in much greater depth in a dedicated later chapter

Who Should Use This Approach

  • Best for students who:
    • Have severe time management issues
    • Can't finish all passages with traditional reading
    • Are strong at finding specific information quickly
    • Don't need full passage context to answer most questions

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓There is no single best approach for everyone—the right method depends on your reading speed.
  • ✓The Big Read works best for strong readers who can retain information.
  • ✓Label Then Read and Speed Reader balance speed.
  • ✓First and Last and Working Backwards are for students.

lessons.subject: science
lessons.title: Topic 1.2 - Question Diagnosis
lessons.content:
The most important skill for success on the Science Test is knowing where to look for information in the passage—a skill called question diagnosis. When you read a question and its answer choices, both provide crucial clues that direct you to the specific part of the passage containing your answer.

1. The Four Places to Look in a Science Passage

  • Every Science passage contains four distinct information sources
    • Figures and Tables (most common, 60-70% of questions)
    • Experimental Text (procedures and descriptions)
    • Introductory Text (definitions and background)
    • Not in the Passage (basic science knowledge & experimental thinking)

Place 1: Figures and Tables

  • The most frequently used source—approximately 60-70% of all questions
    • Most figure/table questions can be answered without reading any passage text
    • The ACT typically makes it easy by explicitly directing you ("According to Figure 2...")
  • When to look at Figures and Tables:
    • The question explicitly references a figure or table
    • Answer choices are numbers with units (25 m/s, 1.5 kg, 300°C)
    • The question asks about trends, relationships, or comparisons between variables

Place 2: Experimental Text

  • Paragraphs that describe how experiments were conducted, what materials were used, and what variables were controlled
    • Usually appears near the figures, often labeled "Experiment 1," "Trial 2," etc.
    • Provides essential context that explains what the data represents
  • When to look at Experimental Text:
    • Questions about experimental setup, procedures, or methods
    • Questions about differences between experiments/trials
    • Questions about variables or conditions not shown in figures
    • Answer choices contain units or values not appearing in any figures

Place 3: Introductory Text

  • Appears at the beginning and provides background information, context, and definitions
    • Important defined terms appear in italics for easy scanning
    • Most questions don't require using this section
  • When to look at Introductory Text:
    • Question contains terms, abbreviations, or words you don't recognize
    • You need general background or context
    • You've checked figures and experimental text but still can't find what you need

Place 4: Not in the Passage

  • Some questions require basic scientific knowledge or experimental reasoning
    • Scientific Knowledge: Fundamental concepts from biology, chemistry, or physics
    • Experimental Thinking: How to design experiments, set up controls, test hypotheses
    • These are relatively uncommon (2-4 times per test)
  • When to use Outside Knowledge/Reasoning:
    • Questions about general scientific principles or facts
    • Questions about how to improve experiments or what should be controlled
    • Answer choices don't match any information in the passage

2. Diagnostic Signals in Question Stems

  • Question stems contain powerful signals that tell you where to look
    • Learning to recognize these instantly improves efficiency
    • You'll know exactly where to go without hesitation or random searching

Explicit References (Strongest Signal)

  • When you see these, trust them completely:
    • "According to Figure 2..." → Go directly to Figure 2
    • "Based on Table 1..." → Go directly to Table 1
    • "In Experiment 3..." → Go to Experiment 3 description
    • "In the passage..." → Information is in the text

Variable-Based Questions

  • Use mentioned variables as search terms:
    • "As temperature increased..." → Find figure with temperature on an axis
    • "When pH was 7..." → Find figure or table showing pH values
    • Scanning axis labels is faster than reading paragraphs

Procedure and Setup Questions

  • These phrases indicate experimental text:
    • "How did scientists measure..." → Experimental text describes methods
    • "Which variable was held constant..." → Experimental text states controlled variables
    • "What was the difference between Trial 1 and Trial 2..." → Experimental text explains changes

3. Diagnostic Signals in Answer Choices

  • Answer choices provide equally important diagnostic information
    • Always read answer choices before searching for information
    • The format and units tell you what type of information to look for

Numerical Answers with Units

  • All choices are numbers with units → You're looking for data in a figure or table
    • Units act as a "search key"—scan figures for those exact units
    • Example: Choices show "g/mL" → Look for density data labeled "g/mL"

Categorical or Descriptive Answers

  • Words or phrases rather than numbers → Looking for trends or concepts
    • Trend descriptions (Increased, Decreased, Remained constant) → Look at figure for pattern
    • Comparison terms (Greater than, Less than, Equal to) → Compare values in figures
    • Experimental conditions (Temperature, pH, Concentration) → Check experimental text

4. The Question Diagnosis Workflow

  • Follow this systematic sequence for every question:
    • Step 1: Read the complete question stem (identify references, variables, what's being asked)
    • Step 2: Read all answer choices (determine format, units, eliminate impossibilities)
    • Step 3: Diagnose the source based on signals
    • Step 4: Go to that source and find/verify the answer
    • Step 5: Eliminate wrong choices and select the correct answer
  • If stuck after 45-60 seconds:
    • Check if you're in the correct figure/section
    • Try the next most likely source
    • Make your best guess and move on—don't waste time

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Every Science passage contains four information sources.
  • ✓Look at Figures and Tables when questions explicitly reference them.
  • ✓Question stems provide diagnostic signals: explicit references ("According.
  • ✓Answer choices act as powerful diagnostic tools: numerical answers.

lessons.subject: science
lessons.title: Topic 2.1 - Specific Data Point Questions
lessons.content:
Specific data point questions are the most straightforward question type on the ACT Science Test, asking you to locate and extract a single piece of data from a figure, table, graph, or chart. These questions represent approximately 30-40% of all Science Test questions, making them essential for building your score quickly and efficiently.

1. How to Identify Specific Data Point Questions

  • Two distinctive characteristics make these questions instantly recognizable:
    • Direct figure or table references ("According to Figure 2...", "Based on Table 1...")
    • All four answer choices are numbers with units (5 cm, 8 cm, 12 cm, 18 cm)
  • When you see both characteristics together, you have absolute certainty
    • The ACT is directly telling you where the answer is—trust it completely
    • Don't waste time checking other figures or reading text descriptions

Why Answer Choice Units Matter

  • Units serve as a powerful search tool
    • If answer choices show "g/mL," immediately look for density data labeled with "g/mL"
    • If choices show "°C," scan for temperature data
    • Don't waste time examining figures with different units

2. The Systematic 5-Step Approach

  • Step 1: Locate the Correct Figure or Table
    • Go immediately to the referenced figure—don't look elsewhere first
    • Verify you're looking at the correct numbered figure if multiple are shown
    • Always verify by checking the passage, even if you think you remember
  • Step 2: Identify What You're Looking For
    • Determine what variable you need (temperature? pressure? concentration? growth?)
    • Note what conditions are specified ("at 17 days," "at 40°C," "in Trial 2")
    • Check the units in answer choices to confirm what measurement you're finding
  • Step 3: Locate the Correct Axes, Row, or Column
    • For graphs: Identify which axis shows which variable (x-axis vs. y-axis)
    • For tables: Find the correct row and column headers
    • Check legends/keys if multiple data series are shown
  • Step 4: Find the Intersection or Data Value
    • For graphs: Find the value on one axis, trace to the data line, then trace to the other axis
    • For tables: Find where the relevant row and column intersect
    • Use your finger or pencil to trace accurately if needed
  • Step 5: Match to Answer Choices
    • Select the closest answer if exact value isn't listed
    • Verify units match between your data and the answer choice
    • If your value doesn't match any choice, double-check your figure, axis, scale, and data line

3. Common Mistakes and How to Avoid Them

  • Mistake #1: Confusing X-Axis and Y-Axis
    • Always verify which variable and units are on which axis before finding data
    • Don't assume temperature is always on x-axis—check the labels!
    • This is the #1 most common error on specific data point questions
  • Mistake #2: Misreading the Scale
    • Check what each labeled mark represents—don't assume consistent intervals
    • Count unlabeled grid lines to determine interval size
    • Pay attention when axes don't start at zero
  • Mistake #3: Ignoring Units
    • Always read units on axis labels or table headers
    • Verify answer choice units match figure units
    • Don't select based on number alone—check units too
  • Mistake #4: Using the Wrong Figure or Data Series
    • Verify figure number before reading any data
    • Check legend/key to identify correct line/curve/symbol
    • Pay attention to line styles (solid vs. dashed) and symbols (circles vs. squares)
  • Mistake #5: Rushing and Misreading Questions
    • Read carefully: "how much lower" ≠ "how high"
    • Note exact values: "at 4 seconds" ≠ "at 40 seconds"
    • Taking 3 extra seconds to read carefully prevents careless errors

4. Tips for Speed and Accuracy

  • Use answer choices to eliminate impossible values
    • If figure shows values 10-50, eliminate choices with 5 or 75
    • If graph clearly shows increasing trend, eliminate "decreased" answers
  • These questions should be fast—30-45 seconds per question
    • They're designed to be straightforward if you follow the systematic approach
    • Bank time here for more difficult questions later
    • But don't rush so fast that you make careless errors
  • Always verify by checking the passage, not relying on memory
    • Even if you think you remember the data, take 3-5 seconds to confirm
    • This prevents errors from misremembering or confusing similar data

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Specific data point questions represent 30-40% of all Science questions and are the fastest.
  • ✓Follow the systematic 5-step approach every time.
  • ✓Never confuse x-axis and y-axis , always check the scale carefully, pay attention.
  • ✓These questions should take 30-45 seconds each.

lessons.subject: science
lessons.title: Topic 2.2 - Trends Questions
lessons.content:
Trend questions ask you to identify patterns in how variables change rather than reading specific numerical values, and they can range from simple questions that track how numbers change across a graph to challenging questions that require identifying non-obvious trends within complex data tables. The key to mastering trend questions is recognizing them quickly by their answer choices (which typically include phrases like "increased only," "decreased then increased," or "remained constant") and focusing on the pattern of change rather than exact values.

1. How to Identify Trend Questions

  • The easiest way to spot trend questions is by examining the answer choices, which typically describe patterns of change:
    • Increased only — The variable continuously goes up throughout the range
    • Decreased only — The variable continuously goes down throughout the range
    • Increased then decreased — The variable rises first, then falls (or vice versa)
    • Remained constant — The variable stays the same throughout
    • Varied with no general trend — The variable changes randomly without a clear pattern

Example Question Stem

  • "As the temperature decreases, the angle of the rose bush stems:"
    • A. Increased only
    • B. Increased then decreased
    • C. Decreased only
    • D. Remained constant
    • When you see answer choices formatted like this, you know immediately that you're dealing with a trend question

2. Analyzing Trends in Charts and Graphs

  • For trend questions using charts and graphs, follow this systematic approach:
    • Identify the correct data series — Bar graphs often show multiple categories (different forests, different fertilizers, etc.). Make sure you're tracking the right bars or lines
    • Follow the pattern left to right (or along the specified axis) — Trace how the values change as you move across the graph
    • Don't worry about exact numbers — You only need to determine if values are going up, down, or staying the same
    • Watch for direction changes — Look for peaks or valleys that indicate "increased then decreased" patterns

3. Analyzing Trends in Tables

  • Trend questions in tables are often more challenging because you must identify which trials or rows to compare. The key is understanding experimental design

The One-Variable Rule

  • To identify a valid trend, you must compare trials where only one independent variable changes while all other variables remain constant. This isolates the effect of that single variable
    • Step 1: Read the question carefully — Identify which variable(s) should be changing and which should remain constant
    • Step 2: Scan the table for matching trials — Find rows where only your variable of interest changes
    • Step 3: Trace the pattern — Follow how the dependent variable changes as the independent variable changes
    • Step 4: Match to answer choices — Describe the pattern using the trend terminology

4. Common Mistakes and Pro Tips

Common Mistakes to Avoid

  • Tracking the wrong data series — In multi-category graphs, students often follow the wrong bars or lines. Always double-check which category the question asks about
  • Comparing trials with multiple changing variables — If more than one variable changes between trials, you cannot determine which variable caused the trend
  • Confusing "increased then decreased" with "decreased then increased" — Pay attention to the order of the trend
  • Getting distracted by exact values — Trend questions test pattern recognition, not precise data reading. Focus on the direction of change

Speed Tips

  • Use your pencil as a visual guide — Trace along bars or lines to track the trend more clearly
  • Eliminate obvious wrong answers first — If a variable clearly goes up, immediately eliminate "decreased only" and "remained constant"
  • For tables, circle the relevant trials — Physically mark which rows you need to compare to avoid confusion
  • Watch for symmetry — Some experiments show the same trend across multiple conditions, which can help you verify your answer

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Identify trend questions instantly by looking for answer choices.
  • ✓Focus on patterns, not precise values—you only need.
  • ✓tables, apply the one-variable rule—only compare trials where a single independent variable changes.
  • ✓visual aids.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.4 - Verbs
lessons.content:
Verb questions make up about 11% of the ACT English Test—roughly 8 questions per test! These questions test you on two major topics: subject-verb agreement and verb tense.

1. Subject-Verb Agreement Basics

  • The subject is the person, place, or thing doing the action
    • Usually at the beginning of the sentence
    • Example: "Cats love to sit in empty boxes." (subject = "Cats")
  • The subject must agree with the verb in number
    • If the subject is singular, the verb must be singular
    • If the subject is plural, the verb must be plural
    • Example: "My dog barks at the mailman every day." (singular subject "dog" → singular verb "barks")

Three Ways the ACT Tricks You

  • Trick #1: Unnecessary information phrases between subject and verb
    • Unnecessary information phrases NEVER contain the subject
    • Cross out unnecessary information to find the subject
    • Example: "Tortoises, known to live to over 150 years old, are sold at the local pet shop."
    • Cross out "known to live to over 150 years old" → Subject is "Tortoises" (plural) → verb is "are" (plural)
  • Trick #2: Prepositional phrases between subject and verb (MOST COMMON)
    • Prepositional phrases NEVER contain the subject or verb
    • Cross out prepositional phrases (like "of students," "in the park," "on the table") to find the subject
    • Example: "The entire group of students is organizing a bake sale to raise money."
    • Cross out "of students" → Subject is "group" (singular) → verb is "is" (singular)
    • Example: "The pod of dolphins hunts as a team."
    • Cross out "of dolphins" → Subject is "pod" (singular) → verb is "hunts" (singular)
  • Trick #3: Group nouns that sound plural but are singular
    • Group nouns (class, committee, team, herd, jury, etc.) are SINGULAR even though the group consists of more than one person or thing
    • Example: "The sheep herd waits to be sheared." (herd = singular)
    • Example: "The jury agrees that the defendant deserves to be put in jail." (jury = singular)

Helpful Tricks

  • Read the subject and verb side-by-side
    • Once you find the subject and verb, read them next to each other and ignore the information in between
    • Example: "A large percentage of the voters, many of whom are under the age of 30, prefers the new housing proposal."
    • Cross out unnecessary phrases → "A percentage prefers the new housing proposal."
    • Now it's clear: "percentage" (singular) → "prefers" (singular)
  • Plug in "he/she/it" for singular subjects and "they" for plural subjects
    • Sometimes it's difficult to "hear" which verb matches the subject
    • For singular words, plug in "he," "she," or "it"
    • For plural words, plug in "they"
    • Example: "The exact time for the meeting with the softball coach and location for the showcase have not been finalized."
    • Cross out prepositional phrases → Subjects are "time" and "location" (plural)
    • Replace with "they" → "They (has/have) not been finalized."
    • Now it's obvious: "have" is correct

2. Verb Tense

  • For verb tense questions, trust your ear
    • As a native English speaker, you'll know what sounds right or wrong
    • Read for context by looking at the previous sentence(s) and finding other verbs
    • Match the tense in the rest of the paragraph
  • Do NOT pick a complicated tense when a simple tense works
    • Avoid unnecessary complicated forms (has run, had ran, had been running, would have run) when simple tenses work
    • Example: "Last year, Margot designed a new line of summer dresses." (simple past tense, not "was designing")
    • Example: "Before he votes tomorrow, Dale will research each candidate's positions on the major issues." (simple future tense)

Perfect Tense (has/have/had + verb)

  • Use perfect tense when there are multiple timelines in a sentence
    • Perfect tense = "has," "have," or "had" + verb
    • Example: "Many surfers enjoy paddling out, but few have ridden waves over ten feet tall."
    • Example: "While the group of entrepreneurs claimed to all be successful, only a few have started their own businesses."
    • Example: "The bison had been eating when the lions began their attack." (shows the bison were already eating before the attack started)
    • Example: "By the beginning of next year, the doctors will have finished their preliminary research on lung cancer."

Conditional Tense (would/could)

  • Conditional tense describes what would or could happen
    • The verb conjugation depends on how likely the outcome is (probable, improbable, impossible)
    • Probable: "If I make the free throw, we will win the game."
    • Improbable: "If I made the free throw, we would win the game."
    • Impossible (past): "If I had made the free throw, we would have won the game."
    • Trust your ear and go with what sounds right

Irregular Verbs

  • Irregular verbs don't follow normal patterns
    • Trust your ear and go with what sounds correct
    • Example: "Before the show began, the lights were dimmed." (not "begun")
    • Example: "The deliveryman had rung the doorbell before dropping off the package." (not "rang")
  • The "a" vs. "u" rule for irregular verbs
    • Many irregular verbs have an "a" version (swam, began, drank) and a "u" version (swum, begun, drunk)
    • With "has," "have," or "had" (perfect tense) → Use the "u" version
    • Example: "Before you arrived, I had swum some laps." (perfect tense → "swum")
    • With no "has," "have," or "had" (past tense) → Use the "a" version
    • Example: "I swam some laps this morning." (past tense → "swam")

3. Common Irregular Verbs

  • The most commonly tested irregular verbs on the ACT
    • begin → began (past tense) → has/have/had begun (perfect tense)
    • drink → drank (past tense) → has/have/had drunk (perfect tense)
    • sink → sank (past tense) → has/have/had sunk (perfect tense)
    • swim → swam (past tense) → has/have/had swum (perfect tense)
    • run → ran (past tense) → has/have/had run (perfect tense)
    • sing → sang (past tense) → has/have/had sung (perfect tense)
  • Remember the pattern
    • Past tense (no helping verb) = "a" version
    • Perfect tense (with has/have/had) = "u" version
    • This pattern applies to begin, drink, sink, swim, and sing
    • Note: "run" is irregular—both versions are "run" (I ran, I have run)

4. How to Spot Subject-Verb Agreement vs. Verb Tense Questions

  • Both question types show different forms of the same verb in answer choices
    • You need to know which type you're dealing with to answer correctly
    • The answer choices tell you what's being tested

Subject-Verb Agreement Questions

  • Look for singular and plural versions of verbs in the answer choices
    • Look for "is" vs. "are"
    • Look for "has" vs. "have"
    • Look for "was" vs. "were"
    • Look for any verb with singular (like "runs") vs. plural (like "run")
    • Anytime you see singular and plural versions, the question is testing subject-verb agreement
  • Example
    • "The addition of solar panels to the roof of a house in Nevada makes the house on average 20% more energy efficient."
    • Answer choices: make (NO CHANGE), makes, have made, were making
    • Subject = "addition" (singular) → verb must be "makes" (singular)
    • Even though there are different tenses, we only need subject-verb agreement to find the answer

Verb Tense Questions

  • Look for different tenses in the answer choices
    • For example: "requires" (present), "required" (past), "will require" (future)
  • Check that answer choices do NOT have singular and plural versions
    • If there are no options for singular vs. plural, subject-verb agreement is not being tested
    • The question is testing verb tense only
  • Example
    • "The girl scouts are hosting a bake sale tomorrow to raise money. To get ready, Adya needs to bake two trays of blondies and a box of donut holes."
    • Answer choices: would need (NO CHANGE), was needing, needed, needs
    • Previous sentence uses "are" (present tense), so this sentence should be present tense too
    • Answer: "needs" (present tense)

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓subject-verb agreement, find the subject.
  • ✓the "plug-in" trick for subject-verb agreement: replace singular subjects.
  • ✓verb tense questions, trust your ear and read for context.
  • ✓Identify question type by looking at answer choices: if you see singular vs.

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Logarithms
lessons.content:
Logarithms appear 1-2 times per ACT Math test, usually testing your ability to convert between logarithmic form and exponential form. Understanding this conversion is the key to solving almost all logarithm questions on the ACT.

1. Basics of Logarithms (Converting Between Forms)

  • The fundamental relationship between logs and exponents:
    • log_a(b) = c is the same as a^c = b
    • Where a is the base, c is the exponent, and b is the result
    • Both equations describe the exact same relationship—just different notation
  • Examples of converting from logarithmic form to exponential form:
    • log₃(3) = 1 → 3¹ = 3
    • log₃(9) = 2 → 3² = 9
    • log₃(27) = 3 → 3³ = 27
    • The pattern: "log base 3 of 27 equals 3" means "3 to the 3rd power equals 27"
  • How to solve logarithm equations:
    • Step 1: Convert from logarithmic form to exponential form
    • Step 2: Solve the exponential equation using exponent rules
    • Example: When log₄(x) = 3, what is x?
    • Convert: 4³ = x
    • Solve: x = 64
  • CRITICAL strategy:
    • Almost ALL ACT logarithm questions are solved by converting to exponential form
    • If you can convert, you can solve the problem
    • Practice this conversion until it's automatic!

2. Using Your Calculator (Change of Base Rule)

  • The change of base rule lets you use a calculator:
    • log_b(a) = log(a) / log(b)
    • This converts ANY logarithm to base 10 (which calculators can compute)
    • Example: log₃(9) = log(9) / log(3) = 0.954 / 0.477 = 2
  • Using the change of base rule on your calculator:
    • To find log₃(9): Enter log(9) ÷ log(3) in calculator
    • To find log₂(8): Enter log(8) ÷ log(2) in calculator
    • This works for ANY base and ANY value
  • Some calculators have a built-in logbase function:
    • TI-83/84: Press MATH, scroll to LOGBASE
    • This allows direct entry: logbase(3, 9) = 2
    • Check if your calculator has this feature—it's faster!
  • Calculator method vs. algebraic method:
    • For simple bases (2, 3, 4, 5): Converting to exponential form is often faster
    • For complex problems with multiple logs: Use change of base rule
    • Example: 5(log₃(9) + log₂(8)) can be solved entirely with calculator

3. Logarithm Rules (For Advanced Questions)

  • Four logarithm rules you should know:
    • Product Rule: log_a(xy) = log_a(x) + log_a(y)
    • Quotient Rule: log_a(x/y) = log_a(x) - log_a(y)
    • Power Rule: log_a(x^n) = n·log_a(x)
    • Log of 1: log_a(1) = 0 (because a⁰ = 1)
  • When to use these rules:
    • These appear RARELY on the ACT (1-2 times per test, if at all)
    • Most often on the LAST 10 questions (hardest section)
    • Students aiming for 30+ should memorize these
    • Other students can skip—focus on conversion first!
  • Example using power rule:
    • If log₉(3^x) = 3/2, what is x?
    • Use power rule: x·log₉(3) = 3/2
    • Find log₉(3) using change of base: log(3)/log(9) = 1/2
    • Substitute: x·(1/2) = 3/2
    • Solve: x = 3
  • Shortcut - backsolving with calculator:
    • If answer choices are given, plug each one in
    • Use change of base rule to evaluate both sides
    • The correct answer makes both sides equal
    • This is often faster than using logarithm rules!

4. Natural Logarithms (ln)

  • Natural logarithms use base e (approximately 2.71828):
    • ln(b) = c is the same as e^c = b
    • The base "e" is invisible—it's always e for natural logs
    • ln is just shorthand notation for log_e
  • Natural logarithms appear VERY rarely:
    • Usually only in the last 5-10 questions (hardest section)
    • Students rushing through can skip this topic entirely
    • Students aiming for 30+ should learn the basics
  • Solving natural logarithm equations:
    • Example: If ln(x-1) = 3, then x = ?
    • Step 1: Convert to exponential form: e³ = x-1
    • Step 2: Solve for x: x = e³ + 1
    • Same conversion strategy as regular logarithms!
  • All logarithm rules work for natural logs too:
    • ln(xy) = ln(x) + ln(y)
    • ln(x/y) = ln(x) - ln(y)
    • ln(x^n) = n·ln(x)
    • ln(1) = 0

5. Test-Taking Tips for Logarithms

  • Master the conversion between logarithmic and exponential form
    • This is THE most important skill for ACT logarithm questions
    • Practice until you can convert instantly without thinking
    • Almost every logarithm question becomes easy once you convert
  • Use your calculator with the change of base rule
    • log_b(a) = log(a) / log(b) works for ANY logarithm
    • This lets you evaluate complex expressions quickly
    • Check if your calculator has a built-in logbase function
  • Backsolve when answer choices are given
    • Plug each answer choice into the original equation
    • Use change of base rule to evaluate on calculator
    • Often faster than using logarithm rules algebraically
  • Prioritize logarithm rules based on your target score
    • Target score below 28: Focus ONLY on conversion and change of base
    • Target score 28-32: Memorize the four logarithm rules
    • Target score 33+: Learn natural logarithms too
    • Don't waste time on rare topics if you need basics first!
  • Remember: logarithms are just another form of exponents
    • If you understand exponents well, logarithms become easier
    • The conversion is the bridge between the two
    • All logarithm rules mirror exponent rules

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Convert between forms: log_a = c means a^c = b—this conversion solves almost all ACT logarithm questions.
  • ✓change of base rule with calculator: log_b = log / log to evaluate any logarithm quickly.
  • ✓Memorize logarithm rules only if aiming for 30+—they appear rarely.
  • ✓Natural logarithms use base e and follow the same conversion strategy: ln = c means e^c = b.

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Circles, Ellipses, and Hyperbolas
lessons.content:
Conic sections (circles, ellipses, and hyperbolas) appear 1-3 times per ACT Math test, usually focusing on the equation of a circle in standard form. Understanding how to identify the center and radius from the equation is the most important skill for these questions.

1. Equation of a Circle

  • Standard form of a circle (MEMORIZE THIS):
    • (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r²
    • Center: (h, k)
    • Radius: r
  • Reading the center from the equation:
    • Example: (x - 3)² + (y + 5)² = 16 has center (3, -5)
    • Watch the signs! (x - h) means center x = +h, (y + k) means center y = -k
    • If (x - 3), the center x-coordinate is 3
    • If (y + 5), the center y-coordinate is -5 (opposite sign!)
  • Finding the radius:
    • r² is on the right side of the equation
    • Example: (x - 2)² + (y - 1)² = 25 has r² = 25, so r = 5
    • Example: (x + 1)² + (y - 3)² = 100 has r² = 100, so r = 10
    • Don't forget to take the square root!
  • Special case - circle centered at origin:
    • x² + y² = r²
    • Center: (0, 0)
    • Example: x² + y² = 49 is centered at origin with radius 7
  • Writing the equation when given center and radius:
    • Center (3, -2) and radius 5: (x - 3)² + (y + 2)² = 25
    • Center (-4, 7) and radius 6: (x + 4)² + (y - 7)² = 36
    • Remember to square the radius!

2. Completing the Square for Circles

  • Sometimes circle equations are given in expanded form:
    • Example: x² + 4x + y² - 8y + 5 = 0
    • This doesn't look like standard form!
    • You must complete the square to find center and radius
  • Steps to complete the square:
    • Step 1: Group x terms and y terms: (x² + 4x) + (y² - 8y) = -5
    • Step 2: For x terms, take half of coefficient of x, square it: (4/2)² = 4
    • Step 3: For y terms, take half of coefficient of y, square it: (-8/2)² = 16
    • Step 4: Add these to both sides: (x² + 4x + 4) + (y² - 8y + 16) = -5 + 4 + 16
    • Step 5: Factor: (x + 2)² + (y - 4)² = 15
    • Now you can read center (-2, 4) and radius √15
  • Quick formula for completing the square:
    • For x² + bx, add (b/2)²
    • This creates a perfect square: (x + b/2)²
    • Same process for y terms

3. Ellipses and Hyperbolas (Basic Recognition)

  • Ellipse standard form:
    • (x - h)²/a² + (y - k)²/b² = 1
    • Center: (h, k), just like a circle
    • Looks like a stretched or compressed circle
    • Both terms are added (+), both squared
    • Example: (x - 2)²/9 + (y + 1)²/4 = 1 is centered at (2, -1)
  • Hyperbola standard form:
    • (x - h)²/a² - (y - k)²/b² = 1 or (y - k)²/b² - (x - h)²/a² = 1
    • Center: (h, k)
    • Has two separate curved branches
    • Key difference: One term is subtracted (-)
    • Example: (x - 3)²/16 - (y + 2)²/9 = 1 is centered at (3, -2)
  • How to identify which conic section:
    • Circle: x² and y² have same coefficient, added together
    • Ellipse: x² and y² have different coefficients, added together
    • Hyperbola: x² and y² are subtracted
  • On the ACT:
    • Circles are tested most frequently
    • Ellipses and hyperbolas appear 0-2 times per test
    • Usually just need to identify center or general shape
    • Deep knowledge of ellipse/hyperbola properties rarely needed

4. Test-Taking Tips for Conic Sections

  • Master the circle equation first
    • (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r² is the most tested formula
    • Practice reading the center until automatic
    • Remember: opposite signs! (x - 3) means center x = 3
  • Watch for completing the square questions
    • If the equation isn't in standard form, you'll need to complete the square
    • Take half the coefficient, square it, add to both sides
    • Don't forget to move the constant to the other side first!
  • Use the signs to identify the conic
    • Both terms positive (+)? Circle or ellipse
    • One term negative (-)? Hyperbola
    • This quick check eliminates wrong answers fast
  • Radius is always positive
    • r² = 25 means r = 5 (not ±5)
    • Radius cannot be negative in geometry
  • Memorize the standard forms
    • Circle: (x-h)²+(y-k)²=r²
    • Ellipse: (x-h)²/a²+(y-k)²/b²=1
    • Hyperbola: (x-h)²/a²-(y-k)²/b²=1
    • These formulas are NOT provided on the test

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Circle equation ²+²=r² with center and radius r—watch the signs.
  • ✓To complete the square for x²+bx, add ² to create a perfect square ².
  • ✓Identify conics by signs: both terms positive = circle/ellipse, one term negative = hyperbola.
  • ✓Focus on circles first—they appear most frequently ,.

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Topic 1.1 - Working Backwards Strategy
lessons.content:
The working backwards strategy is one of the most powerful time-saving techniques on the ACT Math section, letting you test answer choices instead of solving algebraically. This strategy works on 8-12 questions per test—that's 13-20% of all math questions!

1. What Is Backsolving?

  • Backsolving means plugging answer choices into the problem to find which one works
    • Instead of setting up equations and solving for x, you test each choice
    • Transforms complex algebra into simple arithmetic
    • Works by substituting values until you find one that satisfies all conditions
  • Key advantages over traditional algebra:
    • Often faster than setting up and solving complex equations
    • Less likely to make calculation errors with concrete numbers
    • Can verify your answer immediately
    • Works even if you struggle with algebra

When to Use Backsolving

  • Problem asks for a specific numerical value
    • "What is x?" or "How many marbles does Sarah have?"
    • NOT: "Which expression represents...?" or "What is the equation for...?"
  • Answer choices are concrete numbers, not algebraic expressions
    • ✓ Numbers like 2, 6, 14, 18, 22
    • ✗ Expressions like "2x + 3" or "a²b"
  • Traditional algebra looks messy or time-consuming
    • Complex equations with multiple steps
    • Radical expressions or absolute values
    • Situations with high error potential

2. The Strategic Backsolving Process

Step 1: Strategic Starting

  • Use the middle value strategy to maximize efficiency
    • ACT always lists answer choices in ascending or descending order
    • Begin with choice B or C (middle values)
    • If C is too big, eliminate D and E as well
    • If C is too small, eliminate A and B as well
    • This lets you eliminate 2-3 choices with one test

Step 2: Test Your Chosen Answer

  • Substitute the value into all problem conditions
    • Check: Does it make the equation true?
    • Check: Does it satisfy all constraints?
    • Check: Does it produce the correct result?

Step 3: If It Works, You're Done

  • Bubble in your answer and move on
    • Don't waste time double-checking or testing other choices
    • ACT only has one correct answer per question

Step 4: Eliminate and Adjust

  • If the answer doesn't work, cross it off immediately
    • Determine if you need a larger or smaller value
    • Use systematic elimination to rule out other choices
    • Use logic to narrow down remaining options

Step 5: Repeat

  • Test remaining choices systematically
    • Continue until you find the answer that works
    • Remember: exactly one of the five choices must work

3. Perfect Scenarios for Backsolving

  • Radical equations and square roots
    • Algebraically isolating variables requires squaring both sides multiple times
    • Creates opportunities for calculation errors
    • backsolving lets you test values directly in the original equation
  • Complex word problems
    • Multiple steps or complicated variable relationships
    • Test each answer against the problem's conditions
    • Helpful when you understand the question but struggle with setup
  • Systems of equations
    • Two or three equations with multiple variables
    • Often faster than elimination or substitution methods
    • Plug answer choices into all equations to find which satisfies them all

4. When NOT to Backsolve

  • Answer choices are algebraic expressions
    • Can't plug expressions like "2x + 3" or "n²" back into the problem
    • Must use traditional algebra to simplify and solve
  • Traditional algebra is very simple
    • Problems like "2x + 3 = 11, solve for x"
    • One or two steps of basic algebra is faster than testing choices
  • Testing takes more work than solving directly
    • Occasionally plugging in values requires more calculation than algebra
    • Use whichever method gets you to the answer fastest
  • Multiple variables with complex relationships
    • Many interconnected variables become confusing to test
    • Need to calculate multiple dependent values for each choice
    • Setting up equations systematically is often clearer

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Backsolving works by testing answer choices instead of solving algebraically—use.
  • ✓start with choice B or C to eliminate 2-3 options with one test using the middle value strategy.
  • ✓Perfect for radical equations, complex word problems.
  • ✓Avoid when answer choices are expressions, when algebra is simple.

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Algebra Skills
lessons.content:
Core algebra skills appear on almost every ACT Math question, from simple equation solving to complex multi-step problems. Mastering PEMDAS, negative numbers, and combining like terms is essential for avoiding careless mistakes and solving problems quickly.

1. PEMDAS (Order of Operations)

  • PEMDAS is the order you MUST follow when solving expressions:
    • P - Parentheses: Complete calculations inside parentheses first
    • E - Exponents: Next, complete any exponents or square roots
    • MD - Multiplication and Division: Work LEFT TO RIGHT
    • AS - Addition and Subtraction: Work LEFT TO RIGHT
  • CRITICAL: Work left-to-right for MD and AS
    • This is where the ACT tricks students most often!
    • Example: 16 ÷ 4 × 2 - 3
    • ✓ Correct: 16 ÷ 4 × 2 - 3 = 4 × 2 - 3 = 8 - 3 = 5
    • ✗ Wrong: Don't do 4 × 2 first! That gives 16 ÷ 8 - 3 = -1 (incorrect)
  • Calculator shortcut:
    • Your calculator is programmed to follow PEMDAS automatically
    • Enter the expression exactly as written and let the calculator solve it
    • This prevents order of operations mistakes
    • Make sure to use parentheses when needed!
  • Common PEMDAS mistakes to avoid:
    • Doing multiplication before division (or vice versa) instead of left-to-right
    • Forgetting to complete parentheses first
    • Doing exponents after multiplication/division

2. Working with Negative Numbers

  • The ACT LOVES negative number questions—these are prime mistake opportunities
    • Students make more careless errors with negatives than any other topic
    • Take extra care and write out every step
  • Subtracting negative numbers:
    • Subtracting a negative = adding a positive
    • Example: 2 - (-4) = 2 + 4 = 6
    • Think: "minus a minus is a plus"
  • Distributing negative signs (HUGE mistake area):
    • You MUST distribute the negative to ALL terms in parentheses
    • Example: 5x - (2x - 5)
    • ✓ Correct: 5x - 2x - (-5) = 5x - 2x + 5 = 3x + 5
    • ✗ Wrong: 5x - 2x - 5 = 3x - 5 (forgot to distribute to the -5!)
    • The negative sign affects BOTH the 2x AND the -5
  • Negative numbers and exponents (another huge trap):
    • -x² is NOT the same as (-x)²
    • -x²: Square x first, then make it negative → -x² = -(x²)
    • (-x)²: Square the entire negative x → (-x)² = (-x)(-x) = x²
    • Example: -2² = -(2²) = -4
    • Example: (-2)² = (-2)(-2) = 4
    • Calculator tip: ALWAYS use parentheses around negative numbers!

3. Combining Like Terms

  • Like terms have the same variable raised to the same power:
    • 3x and 5x are like terms → can be combined to 8x
    • 2x² and 4x² are like terms → can be combined to 6x²
    • 3x and 5x² are NOT like terms → cannot be combined
    • Constants (numbers without variables) can always be combined
  • Steps for combining like terms:
    • Step 1: Distribute any parentheses
    • Step 2: Group like terms together
    • Step 3: Add or subtract the coefficients
    • Step 4: Simplify the expression
  • Example: 2(3x - 6) + 3y = 6x - y + 8, solve for y:
    • Distribute: 6x - 12 + 3y = 6x - y + 8
    • The 6x terms cancel on both sides
    • Simplify: -12 + 3y = -y + 8
    • Combine: 4y = 20
    • Solve: y = 5
  • When to combine like terms:
    • Always simplify equations before solving
    • Combining like terms reduces the equation to its simplest form
    • This makes it easier to see what to do next

4. Cross-Multiplying Fractions

  • When two fractions are equal, you can cross-multiply:
    • If x/y = z/w, then xw = yz
    • Multiply the numerator of each fraction by the denominator of the other
    • This eliminates the fractions and gives you a simpler equation
  • Visual representation:
    • x/y = z/w
    • Cross-multiply diagonally: x × w and y × z
    • Result: xw = yz
  • Example: If x/4 = 6/7, solve for x:
    • Cross-multiply: 7x = 4(6)
    • Simplify: 7x = 24
    • Solve: x = 24/7
  • When to use cross-multiplication:
    • When you have one fraction equal to another fraction
    • This is the fastest way to eliminate fractions
    • Much faster than finding common denominators

5. Test-Taking Tips for Algebra Skills

  • Write out every step—do NOT do mental math
    • Careless errors happen when you skip steps
    • Writing forces you to be careful with negative signs
    • You can check your work if you write it out
  • Use your calculator strategically
    • For PEMDAS problems: enter the entire expression
    • ALWAYS use parentheses around negative numbers
    • Double-check your calculator entry matches the problem
  • Circle or underline negative signs
    • Makes them more visible so you don't forget them
    • Especially important when distributing
  • Test your answer with substitution
    • If you solved for x, plug your answer back into the original equation
    • Does it make the equation true? Then you're correct!
    • This catches algebra mistakes
  • Master the basics before moving to advanced topics
    • These fundamental skills appear in EVERY algebra problem
    • You cannot do advanced algebra without mastering these basics
    • Practice until negative numbers and PEMDAS are automatic

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Follow PEMDAS strictly, working LEFT TO RIGHT for multiplication/division and addition/subtraction—this is where most mistakes happen.
  • ✓When distributing a negative sign, apply it to ALL terms: 5x.
  • ✓-x² ≠ ²: without parentheses, square first then negate ,.
  • ✓Write out every step and always use parentheses in your calculator for negative numbers—careless mistakes lose more points than not knowing the math.

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Inequalities
lessons.content:
Inequalities appear 2-4 times per ACT Math test, testing your ability to solve algebraic inequalities and graph them on number lines or coordinate planes. The most important rule: flip the inequality sign when multiplying or dividing by a negative number.

1. Solving Algebraic Inequalities

  • Treat inequality signs (<, >, ≤, ≥) like an equals sign:
    • Use all normal algebra rules: add, subtract, combine like terms
    • Isolate the variable just like solving equations
    • The inequality sign stays the same for most operations
  • CRITICAL RULE: Flip the sign when multiplying or dividing by a negative
    • This is the #1 mistake students make with inequalities!
    • Example: -2x + 5 < 11
    • Subtract 5: -2x < 6
    • Divide by -2: x > -3 (sign flipped from < to >!)
  • When NOT to flip the sign:
    • ONLY flip when you multiply or divide BOTH SIDES by a negative
    • Don't flip just because you see a negative number somewhere!
    • Example: 3x + 6 > x - 4
    • Combine: 2x > -10
    • Divide by 2 (positive): x > -5 (sign stays the same!)
  • Step-by-step process:
    • Step 1: Move all variable terms to one side
    • Step 2: Move all number terms to the other side
    • Step 3: Combine like terms
    • Step 4: Divide to isolate variable (flip sign if dividing by negative!)

2. Graphing Inequalities on a Number Line

  • Two types of circles on number lines:
    • Open circle (○): Use for > and < (strict inequalities)
    • The endpoint is NOT included in the solution
    • Example: x > 3 has an open circle at 3
    • Solid circle (●): Use for ≥ and ≤ (inclusive inequalities)
    • The endpoint IS included in the solution
    • Example: x ≥ 3 has a solid circle at 3
  • Which direction to shade:
    • Greater than (> or ≥): Shade to the RIGHT
    • Example: x ≥ 10/3 → solid circle at 10/3, shade right
    • Less than (< or ≤): Shade to the LEFT
    • Example: x < -5 → open circle at -5, shade left
  • Quick memory trick:
    • The inequality sign "points" to the smaller values
    • So x > 3 means x is to the RIGHT of 3 (bigger values)
    • And x < 3 means x is to the LEFT of 3 (smaller values)

3. Graphing Linear Inequalities in the Coordinate Plane

  • Three-step process for graphing linear inequalities:
    • Step 1: Rearrange into y = mx + b form (slope-intercept)
    • Step 2: Plot the line (dashed or solid based on inequality)
    • Step 3: Shade the solution region (above or below the line)
  • Dashed vs. solid lines:
    • Dashed line: Use for > and < (strict inequalities)
    • Points ON the line are NOT part of the solution
    • Solid line: Use for ≥ and ≤ (inclusive inequalities)
    • Points ON the line ARE part of the solution
  • Where to shade:
    • Greater than (> or ≥): Shade ABOVE the line
    • Example: y ≥ 2x + 3 → solid line, shade above
    • Less than (< or ≤): Shade BELOW the line
    • Example: y < -x + 2 → dashed line, shade below
  • Example: Graph 2x + 3y ≥ 6
    • Step 1: Solve for y: 3y ≥ -2x + 6 → y ≥ (-2/3)x + 2
    • Step 2: Draw solid line (because of ≥)
    • Step 3: Shade above the line (because of ≥)

4. Systems of Inequalities and Advanced Graphing

  • Systems of inequalities (multiple inequalities on same graph):
    • Graph each inequality separately on the same coordinate plane
    • The solution is where the shaded regions OVERLAP
    • Example: y < 2x - 4 AND y > -(1/3)x - 2
    • Graph both lines, shade both regions, find the overlap
  • Parabola inequalities (follow same rules as lines):
    • Greater than (> or ≥): Shade ABOVE the parabola
    • Less than (< or ≤): Shade BELOW the parabola
    • Use dashed curve for > and <, solid curve for ≥ and ≤
  • Circle and ellipse inequalities (different shading rules):
    • Greater than (> or ≥): Shade OUTSIDE the circle/ellipse
    • Example: (x-2)² + (y-1)² > 4 → shade outside the circle
    • Less than (< or ≤): Shade INSIDE the circle/ellipse
    • Example: (x-2)²/4 + (y-1)²/9 ≤ 1 → shade inside the ellipse
  • When you'll see advanced inequalities:
    • Parabola/circle/ellipse inequalities appear in the LAST 10 questions
    • These are for students aiming for 30+ scores
    • Master linear inequalities first before worrying about these!

5. Test-Taking Tips for Inequalities

  • Write "FLIP SIGN" when dividing by negatives
    • This is the most common mistake on inequality questions
    • Circle any negative you're dividing by to remind yourself
    • Double-check the final sign before selecting your answer
  • Use test points to check your graph shading
    • Pick a point in the shaded region (like (0,0) if it's not on the line)
    • Plug it into the original inequality
    • If it makes the inequality true, you shaded correctly!
    • If false, you shaded the wrong side
  • Remember: Open vs solid circles/lines
    • < and > → open circle/dashed line
    • ≤ and ≥ → solid circle/solid line
    • ACT answer choices often differ only in this detail!
  • For systems, look for the overlap
    • The solution to a system is where ALL shaded regions overlap
    • This is usually the darkest shaded area on the graph
    • Test a point in the overlap to verify it satisfies all inequalities
  • Circle/ellipse shading is opposite of parabola/line shading
    • Lines/parabolas: > means shade above
    • Circles/ellipses: > means shade outside
    • This catches many students—don't mix them up!

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓FLIP the inequality sign when multiplying or dividing BOTH SIDES.
  • ✓Number lines: use open circles for > and <, solid circles for ≥ and ≤; shade right for greater than, left for less than
  • ✓Linear/parabola inequalities: > and ≥ shade above the line, < and ≤ shade below; use dashed for strict (<, >), solid for inclusive (≤, ≥)
  • ✓Circle/ellipse inequalities shade OPPOSITE: > and ≥ shade OUTSIDE, < and ≤ shade INSIDE

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Topic 1.2 - Number Substitution Technique
lessons.content:
Number substitution is a powerful test-taking strategy that transforms variable-heavy questions into simple arithmetic by plugging in concrete numbers. This technique works on 10-15% of ACT Math questions and is especially useful when you see multiple variables with few or no actual numbers!

1. What Is Number Substitution?

  • Number substitution means replacing variables with simple numbers to solve problems using arithmetic instead of complex algebra
    • Do you prefer working with numbers or variables? Most students prefer numbers!
    • Instead of manipulating algebraic expressions, you work with concrete values
    • Transform intimidating variable problems into straightforward arithmetic
  • Why this strategy is so powerful:
    • Questions with many unknown variables and few numbers often intimidate students
    • Working with real numbers is faster and less error-prone than abstract algebra
    • You can verify your answer immediately by checking it against the original problem
    • Works even if you struggle with complex algebraic manipulation

2. The 4-Step Substitution Process

Step 1: Pick Numbers for Variables

  • Choose simple, easy-to-work-with numbers
    • Avoid 0 and 1 — these can lead to incorrect answers that seem to work
    • Use 2, 3, 4, or 5 — small numbers that are easy to calculate with
    • Special cases: Use 10 for percent problems, 10 or 20 for group size problems
  • Select different numbers for each variable
    • If a question has x and y, pick x = 2 and y = 3
    • Using different values prevents confusion and ensures accurate results
  • Follow any rules stated in the question
    • If x must be negative and even, pick x = -2
    • If y must be greater than x, make sure your chosen values satisfy this
    • Pay attention to constraints like "positive integers" or "odd numbers"

Step 2: Write Down Your Numbers

  • Record your chosen values clearly
    • Write them in your test booklet or scratch paper
    • This prevents mistakes when plugging into answer choices
    • You'll need to reference these values multiple times

Step 3: Solve Using Your Numbers

  • Work through the question using your chosen values
    • Replace all variables with the numbers you picked
    • Calculate step-by-step using basic arithmetic
    • Find your numerical answer to the question

Step 4: Test Answer Choices

  • Plug your numbers into each answer choice
    • The correct answer will match the numerical answer you found in Step 3
    • Only ONE answer choice will produce your target number
    • Once you find the match, you're done — bubble it in and move on!

3. When to Use Number Substitution

  • Question asks "which of the following" or "in terms of..."
    • Looking for an expression in terms of variables (m, n, x, y, etc.)
    • The question describes a situation with variables, not specific numbers
  • Answer choices contain variables or expressions
    • ✓ Choices like "0.7nm", "2x + 3", "5(x + 3)"
    • ✗ NOT for choices that are just numbers like 2, 5, 7, 10
  • Question has multiple variables with no concrete numbers
    • Problems like "n boxes with m items each"
    • Scenarios involving undefined quantities
  • The algebra looks messy or time-consuming
    • Setting up equations with variables would take too long
    • Substitution often provides a faster path to the answer

4. Common Question Types for Substitution

  • Percent problems with variables
    • Finding percentages of unknown quantities
    • Use 10 or 100 as your starting number for easy percent calculations
    • Example: "70% of n items" → pick n = 10, so 70% of 10 = 7
  • Geometry transformation problems
    • When shapes are scaled or modified
    • Example: "length is tripled, width is halved"
    • Pick simple dimensions like length = 3, width = 2
  • Trigonometry with unknown angles
    • Questions like "if cos(2x) = a, which must be true?"
    • Pick a simple angle value (like x = 10° or x = 30°)
    • Use calculator to find what a equals, then test answer choices
  • Number property questions
    • "If x is odd and y is even, which must be odd?"
    • Pick specific values: x = 3 (odd), y = 4 (even)
    • Test each answer choice with your values

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Number substitution replaces variables with simple numbers.
  • ✓Follow 4 steps: pick numbers, write them down, solve using your numbers, test answer choices.
  • ✓when answer choices contain variables, question asks "in terms of," or has multiple variables.
  • ✓Perfect for percent problems, geometry transformations, trigonometry with unknowns.

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Fractions
lessons.content:
Fractions appear frequently on the ACT Math test, both as standalone problems and within larger algebra questions. This chapter covers ALL the fundamental techniques you need to answer any fraction question quickly and efficiently—from combining fractions with variables to using your calculator to convert between fractions and decimals.

1. Combining Fractions (Adding and Subtracting)

  • To add or subtract fractions, you MUST have the same denominator:
    • You cannot add 1/2 + 2/5 directly—the denominators are different
    • First find the least common denominator (LCD)
    • Then add or subtract the numerators while keeping the denominator the same
  • Quick trick for finding the least common denominator:
    • Multiply the denominators together
    • Example: For 1/2 + 2/5, LCD = 2 × 5 = 10
    • This always works, even if it's not the smallest possible denominator
    • On the ACT, any common denominator is fine—you don't need the smallest one
  • Step-by-step process for combining fractions:
    • Example: 1/2 + 2/5
    • Step 1: Find LCD = 2 × 5 = 10
    • Step 2: Convert each fraction: 1/2 = 5/10, and 2/5 = 4/10
    • Step 3: Add numerators: 5/10 + 4/10 = 9/10
  • Fractions with variables in denominators (harder but same concept):
    • Example: 1/x + 3/(x-4)
    • LCD = x(x-4) [multiply the denominators]
    • Multiply first fraction by (x-4)/(x-4): (x-4)/[x(x-4)]
    • Multiply second fraction by x/x: 3x/[x(x-4)]
    • Add: (x-4+3x)/[x(x-4)] = (4x-4)/[x(x-4)]

2. Dividing Fractions ("Keep, Flip, Change")

  • The "Keep, Flip, Change" method for dividing fractions:
    • Keep the first fraction exactly as it is
    • Flip the second fraction (take the reciprocal)
    • Change the division sign to multiplication
    • Example: (2/3) ÷ (4/5) = (2/3) × (5/4) = 10/12 = 5/6
  • This works even when dividing a fraction by a whole number:
    • Example: (2/3) ÷ 3
    • Write 3 as 3/1, then flip to get 1/3
    • Result: (2/3) × (1/3) = 2/9
  • The reciprocal of a fraction:
    • Flip the numerator and denominator
    • Reciprocal of 3/4 is 4/3
    • Reciprocal of 5 is 1/5 (since 5 = 5/1)
    • Reciprocal of x/(x-2) is (x-2)/x
  • Why "keep, flip, change" works:
    • Dividing by a number is the same as multiplying by its reciprocal
    • Example: 10 ÷ 2 = 10 × (1/2) = 5
    • Same principle applies to fractions

3. Simplifying Fractions (Critical Rules!)

  • Rule: You can ONLY simplify if you can divide ALL terms by the same number
    • Example: (2x+10)/4 CAN be simplified (divide all by 2) → (x+5)/2
    • Example: (8x+3)/4 CANNOT be simplified (can't divide 3 by 4)
    • Common mistake: (2x+10)/4 ≠ (x+10)/2 ❌ (You MUST divide ALL terms!)
  • When you CANNOT simplify, split the fraction instead:
    • Example: (8x+3)/4 = 8x/4 + 3/4 = 2x + 3/4
    • You CAN split numerators: (a+b)/c = a/c + b/c ✓
    • You CANNOT split denominators: a/(b+c) ≠ a/b + a/c ❌
  • Simplifying with variables in the denominator:
    • Example: 3/(6x+30) CAN be simplified → 3/[3(2x+10)] → 1/(2x+10)
    • Example: 3/(6x+10) CANNOT be simplified (can't divide 10 by 3)
    • Same rule: ALL terms must be divisible by the same number
  • CRITICAL: You cannot split denominators!
    • 3/(6x+10) ≠ 3/6x + 3/10 ❌ WRONG!
    • This is one of the most common mistakes students make
    • When in doubt, leave the denominator together

4. Getting Rid of Fractions (Multiply by LCD)

  • For equations with only numbers in denominators, eliminate fractions:
    • Find the least common multiple (LCM) of all denominators
    • Multiply EVERY term by the LCM
    • All fractions will disappear, leaving only whole numbers
    • Then solve the equation normally
  • Example: (1/4)x + (1/2) = (3/8)x
    • LCM of 4, 2, and 8 is 8
    • Multiply all terms by 8: (1/4)x×8 + (1/2)×8 = (3/8)x×8
    • Simplify: 2x + 4 = 3x
    • Solve: x = 4
  • More complex example with subtraction:
    • Example: (3x/5) - (2x/6) - (1/2) = (x/10)
    • LCM of 5, 6, 2, and 10 is 30
    • Multiply all terms by 30: 18x - 10x - 15 = 3x
    • Simplify: 8x - 15 = 3x
    • Solve: 5x = 15, so x = 3
  • When to use this method:
    • If you struggle with fractions, ALWAYS use this method!
    • It turns difficult fraction problems into easy whole number problems
    • Works great when ALL denominators are numbers (not variables)

5. Calculator Strategies for Fractions

  • Strategy #1: Turn fractions into decimals
    • Example: (3/4)x - (2/5) = (1/2)x becomes 0.75x - 0.4 = 0.5x
    • Solve: 0.75x = 0.5x + 0.4 → 0.25x = 0.4 → x = 1.6
    • Then convert 1.6 back to a fraction if needed, or check answer choices
    • This avoids dealing with fractions entirely!
  • Strategy #2: Convert decimals to fractions using your calculator
    • TI-83/84: Enter decimal → Press MATH → Select "Frac" → Press ENTER
    • TI-30XS: Enter decimal → Press 2nd → Press PRB → Select F◂▸D → Press ENTER
    • If you have a different calculator, YouTube has tutorials for your model
  • Strategy #3: Use parentheses properly!
    • ALWAYS put the entire numerator in parentheses
    • ALWAYS put the entire denominator in parentheses
    • Example: To enter (2x+1)/(x-3), type: (2x+1)÷(x-3)
    • Without parentheses, calculator follows order of operations incorrectly
  • Strategy #4: Compare answer choices as decimals
    • If you solved to get x = 1.6 (decimal)
    • And answer choices are fractions like 8/5, 5/3, 13/10, etc.
    • Enter each fraction in calculator to see which equals 1.6
    • 8/5 = 1.6 ✓ That's your answer!
  • Strategy #5: Backsolving
    • If the question asks "what is the value of x?" with answer choices
    • Plug each answer choice back into the original equation
    • Use your calculator to check which one makes the equation true
    • This is often faster than solving algebraically!

6. Test-Taking Tips for Fractions

  • Use your calculator strategically
    • For numerical fractions: let calculator do the work
    • For algebraic fractions: write out steps carefully
    • Save mental energy for the hard problems
  • Use substitution for "equivalent" questions
    • If asked "which expression is equivalent," plug in a test value
    • Example: If the original has x, try x = 2
    • Calculate both expressions—they should give the same answer
    • This is often faster than algebraic manipulation
  • Remember the "cannot split denominators" rule
    • a/(b+c) ≠ a/b + a/c ❌ This is ALWAYS wrong!
    • But (a+b)/c = a/c + b/c ✓ Splitting numerators is OK
    • This mistake appears in wrong answer choices frequently
  • When in doubt, eliminate fractions
    • If all denominators are numbers, multiply by LCM
    • If dealing with fractions makes you nervous, turn them into decimals
    • Both methods turn hard problems into easy ones
  • Master "Keep, Flip, Change" for division
    • This simple rule handles ALL fraction division
    • Keep first, flip second, change to multiplication
    • Works every time, no exceptions

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓To combine fractions, multiply denominators.
  • ✓You can ONLY simplify if you can divide ALL terms by the same number.
  • ✓To eliminate fractions from equations, multiply all terms.
  • ✓your calculator to convert between fractions and decimals, backsolve with answer choices.

lessons.subject: reading
lessons.title: Topic 2.6 - Tips for Comparing Passages Questions
lessons.content:
Each ACT has 1 dual text passage with two short passages (Passage A and Passage B) that discuss similar topics and are somehow related. At the end, there are always 3 comparing passages questions that ask about both passages—this chapter teaches you how to approach these questions effectively.

1. Understanding Dual Text Passages

  • Dual text passages include two short passages labeled as Passage A and Passage B
    • The two passages discuss similar topics and are somehow related
    • Example: Two scientists offering differing opinions on a recent discovery
    • Questions always go in this order: Passage A Questions → Passage B Questions → Comparing Passages Questions (3 questions)

How to Approach Dual Text Passages

  • Recommended approach: Read each passage separately—do not read both passages before starting the questions
    • Step 1: Read Passage A and answer questions for Passage A
    • Step 2: Read Passage B and answer questions for Passage B
    • Step 3: Answer Comparing Passages Questions
    • Since the passages are shorter, most students find it easier to read the entire passage
    • Still apply whatever method you prefer from the ones discussed in Chapter 1.3
  • If you work backwards: Answer questions for Passage A, then Passage B, then Comparing Passages Questions
    • Use the questions to guide your reading of each passage
    • Still save the Comparing Passages Questions for last

Identifying Comparing Passages Questions

  • Comparing passages questions are always the last 3 questions in the dual text passage
    • Example: "Which of the following statements best captures the main difference in the purposes of the two passages?"
    • Example: "Which of the following statements about instruments is most strongly supported by details provided in Passage A and Passage B?"
    • The ACT will have a box telling you that the question asks about both passages
    • To answer correctly, you must use information from both passages

2. Tip #1 — Read the Answer Choices Right Away

  • Comparing passages questions are generally quite broad, so you should always read the answer choices right away
    • Once you've read the answer choices and know what the 4 options are, it's much easier to accomplish two things:
    • (1) Eliminate any answer choices that are clearly incorrect
    • (2) Know what to look for in Passage A and Passage B
    • Without reading the answer choices first, you may waste time searching aimlessly through both passages

3. Tip #2 — Work Backwards More Actively with the Answer Choices

  • Comparing passages questions generally have longer answer choices because the answer choice must refer to information in both passages
    • When you see longer answer choices, work backwards more actively
    • Look for specific details that do not match the passage
    • Often, multiple answer choices are partly correct
    • It's easier to look for what is incorrect about each answer choice rather than focusing on which seems most correct

Example Strategy

  • Question: "The primary purpose of both passages is to:"
    • A. resolve a long-standing debate on the evolution of vampire bats
    • B. celebrate the findings of recent research by Brazilian scientists
    • C. present two competing theories on the development of echolocation in vampire bats
    • D. catalog evidence from multiple studies that supports a finding about vampire bats
  • We need to pick an answer that matches both passages
    • Rather than looking for the correct answer, it's easier to eliminate choices that don't match one passage
    • If Passage A only presents one theory about echolocation, C is incorrect
    • If Passage B discusses a debate but doesn't resolve it, A is incorrect
    • Working backwards with this thinking makes finding the correct answer easier

4. Tip #3 — Beware of Half-Right Answer Choices

  • For comparing passages questions, the ACT loves writing answer choices that are halfway correct
    • Part of the answer choice perfectly answers the question
    • However, there is something wrong with the remaining portion of the answer choice
    • Students often pick these incorrect choices because they get excited over the part that's correct
    • They don't read the rest of the answer choice carefully enough
    • As always, we need to be very picky when assessing each answer choice—especially for comparing passages questions

Example of Half-Right Answer Choices

  • Question: "Which choice best states the relationship between the two passages?"
    • A. Passage A provides an overview of a scientific discovery, while Passage B summarizes the experiments that led to that discovery
    • B. Passage A summarizes a scientific finding, while Passage B focuses on the potential applications of that finding
    • C. Passage A presents conflicting points of view on an issue, while Passage B presents evidence supporting a single view on that issue
    • D. Passage A considers how to best test two hypotheses, while Passage B argues that only one of the hypotheses is valid
  • Notice how the first half of A and B are both very similar
    • These could both accurately describe Passage A, but only one can be correct
    • This means one of these answer choices must be half-right
    • It's important to focus on the second half of the answer choices to determine which is correct
    • As always, the correct answer must be 100% correct!

5. Tip #4 — Do Not Focus on the Identical Parts of the Answer Choices

  • Many comparing passages questions have portions of multiple answer choices that are identical
    • When you see identical parts in the answer choices, do not focus on the similarities
    • Instead, focus on the differences
    • Students make the mistake of trying to figure out which identical part is more correct, which is often impossible
    • You should focus on the differences in the rest of the answer choice—this is what actually determines which is correct

Example of Identical Parts

  • Question: "How do the two passages differ in the attitudes of each author towards women serving in the army?"
    • A. Smith implies that women should be prevented from serving in the army, whereas Jones supports women serving in the army in non-combat roles
    • B. Smith believes that women with certain physical abilities can be considered for service in the army, whereas Jones assumes that physical ability is unrelated to any person's ability to serve
    • C. Smith argues that service should be a personal choice regardless of gender, whereas Jones contends that women are unsuitable to serve due to emotional instability
    • D. Smith asserts that anyone who can serve in the army should be able to do so, whereas Jones argues that men and women should serve in gender-specific roles
  • The first half of C and D are both saying the same thing: anyone should be able to serve
    • If Smith argues that in Passage A, there's no way to tell if C or D is correct by focusing on the first half alone
    • Instead, we need to look at the rest of the answer choices and focus on the differences
  • Similarly, the second half of A and D are making almost identical statements
    • Both say men and women should have separate roles in the army
    • If Jones argued that in Passage B, don't focus on determining which is more correct
    • Instead, look at the first half of those answer choices and focus on the differences to find which is correct

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓dual text passages, read each passage separately and answer questions in order: Passage A questions, Passage B questions, then the 3 Comparing Passages Questions at the end.
  • ✓read the answer choices right away for comparing passages questions since they're generally quite broad.
  • ✓Beware of half-right answer choices—the ACT loves.
  • ✓When multiple answer choices have identical parts.

lessons.subject: reading
lessons.title: Topic 3.1 - Working Backwards
lessons.content:
Working backwards means going straight to the questions without reading the entire passage first—it's not recommended for all students, but it may help you improve your score if you struggle with time management or recall. All students should know how to work backwards in case you mess up pacing and need to use it on the final passage on test day.

1. When Should You Work Backwards?

  • Work backwards if:
    • You cannot finish the passages in time with any method that involves reading the passage first
    • You find yourself not recalling what you read at the end of the passage—you're probably wasting time reading
    • You can finish but are tight on time, and timing (not comprehension) is your biggest issue—try it and see if it helps
    • You mismanage time and have less than 4 minutes for the final passage—reading will use up most of your time, so go straight to questions
  • Do NOT work backwards if:
    • You can finish in time with the Big Read, Big Read with Notes, or Label then Read—reading the entire passage will likely help you score higher
    • You're aiming for 32-36 (can only miss 0-3 questions)—if you never read the passage, you're more likely to get questions wrong because you didn't find the correct evidence (though some students have scored perfectly working backwards, so it depends on you)

How to Tell If Working Backwards Is for You

  • The best way to see if working backwards helps you is to try it on practice passages and practice tests
    • If it sounds like it might help you, try it out—you may find it improves your score, or you may hate it
    • Working backwards takes lots of practice to master since it's somewhat chaotic and requires thinking on the fly

2. General Steps for Working Backwards

  • Working backwards requires answering questions out of order, making quick decisions, knowing when to give up and move on, and thinking on the fly
    • This is a general recommendation, not an exact order—don't feel you must stick to the exact sequence
    • The approach will vary based on the question types and your own reading/skimming skills

Step 1: Go Straight to the Questions

  • Go straight to the questions before reading the passage
    • You will never read the entire passage when working backwards
