    • Instead, you'll read only the parts of the passage needed to answer specific questions

Step 2: Skip Broad Passage Questions

  • Skip any broad passage questions that ask about the entire passage—save those for last
    • You need to understand the whole passage to answer these, which you won't have yet
    • Answer these at the very end after you've read parts of the passage for other questions

Step 3: Skip Questions Requiring Multiple Parts of the Passage

  • Skip questions that require reading various parts of the passage—save those for later
    • Chronological order questions: "Which of the following events occurs in the passage first chronologically?"
    • Questions requiring various details: "The author would most likely agree with which of the following statements?"
    • Vague questions with no good keywords to skim for: "As summarized in the passage, the study focuses primarily on:"

Step 4: Start with Line Reference and Paragraph Questions

  • Start with line reference questions or questions that reference a specific paragraph
    • Example: "The main idea of the third paragraph..."
    • Other easy questions: words in context questions
    • Use the 2-sentence rule for these questions and read for more context if necessary

Step 5: Answer Clear Evidence Questions with Strong Keywords

  • Next, look for clear evidence questions with strong primary keywords
    • Look for capitalized words, numbers, other unique keywords that are easier to find in the passage
    • Look for clear evidence questions with shorter answer choices, as these are often easier to find and faster to answer
    • Skip clear evidence questions with weak keywords and save those for later (unless you already know where to find the evidence)

Step 6: Answer Inference Questions

  • Next, answer inference questions—start with those with strong primary keywords
    • Skip inference questions with weak keywords and save for later (unless you already know where to go)
    • Use the answer choices more actively—for inference questions the Waldo won't be as clear
    • Knowing the 4 options makes it easier and faster to find evidence, eliminate incorrect choices, and answer correctly

Step 7: Handle Purpose Questions Based on Keywords

  • Purpose questions are generally best saved for later, but it depends on the keywords
    • If a purpose question has line references, you can usually answer right away—read for enough context
    • If a purpose question has strong primary keyword, go look for it, read for context, and answer (if you can't find keyword in 30 seconds, move on)
    • If a purpose question is vague and/or you don't have strong keyword(s), skip and save for later
    • Regardless of keywords, if you know where to go in the passage, answer it (as long as you have enough context)

Step 8: Answer Skipped Questions Last

  • Answer the broad passage questions or any other questions you've skipped last
    • If you're running out of time, answer the broad passage questions using the information you know about the passage
    • Answer broad passage questions before other skipped questions if time is limited

3. Answer Right Away vs. Save for Later?

  • One essential skill for working backwards is learning when to answer a question right away vs. skip and save for later
    • Learning this skill takes lots of practice—there's no simple set of rules to follow
    • Every question is a judgment call that depends on: the wording, the keywords (or lack thereof), the parts of the passage you've read so far, and the answer choices

Line Reference Questions

  • Always answer line reference questions right away
    • Since these questions tell you where to go, you never need to search
    • Read for context and answer the question
    • Take time to read for enough context to answer correctly—you can (and often should) read more than 2 sentences before and after

Clear Evidence Questions

  • Usually easier to answer right away, but it depends on keyword strength and answer choices
    • Answer right away: Clear evidence questions with strong primary keyword(s) (like "Jupiter," "Amsterdam," specific names/places)
    • Save for later: Questions without strong primary keywords or with answer choices that may be scattered throughout the passage
    • Use your best judgment based on what you've read—if you have good keywords or already know where to go, answer right away
    • Always follow the 30-second rule—don't get stuck on these for too long

Inference Questions

  • Inference questions are usually saved for later, but it depends on keyword strength and answer choices
    • In general, you should almost always look at the answer choices for inference questions right away
    • Answer right away: Inference questions with very strong, specific keywords that are easy to find
    • Save for later: Inference questions without strong keywords or that require broader passage understanding

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Work backwards if you can't finish in time, don't recall what you read.
  • ✓Go straight to questions, skip broad passage questions and questions requiring multiple parts of the passage .
  • ✓answer line reference questions right away since they tell you where to go.
  • ✓Learning when to answer right away vs.

lessons.subject: reading
lessons.title: Topic 3.2 - 7 Tips to Maximize Your Reading Score
lessons.content:
These 7 tips will help you maximize your Reading score—some are review from earlier in the course while others are brand new skills. Try to use these tips on practice passages and practice ACTs to prepare for your best ACT Reading score ever!

1. Tip #1 — Keep it Moving

  • Time management is critical for success on the Reading Test
    • You have 9 minutes per passage for normal time and 15 minutes per passage for extended time
    • To finish all 4 passages consistently, it's important to know when to guess and move on to the next question
    • In general, never spend more than 1 minute on any single question (1.5 minutes for extended time)

Developing Time Management

  • At first, it may be hard to manage time and know when to move on
    • You'll get a better sense of time management as you complete practice ACTs
    • With practice, you'll develop a voice in your head saying "It's time to bubble in your best guess and move on"
    • This is especially true on the first 4-6 questions of each passage—follow the 30-second rule!
    • If you can't find the correct part of the passage quickly, circle the question number and move on
    • You may come across the evidence as you answer questions in the rest of the passage
    • You can always go back and change your answer if you find the evidence later
  • Knowing when to move on will increase your score
    • We know it feels weird moving on without being confident in your answer choice
    • But moving on allows you to answer more questions and avoid guessing as time runs out

2. Tip #2 — Circle Guesses; Box Non-Confident Answers

  • Circle guesses: Whenever you guess on a question, circle the question number on your test
    • If you finish with time left, go back to the circled questions you guessed on
    • Spend more time looking for the Waldo
    • The question may also seem easier when you come back to it a second time
  • Box non-confident answers: If you're not confident in your answer, box the question number on your test
    • If you have time left after going back to circled questions, you can look over these boxed questions again
    • Only change your answer if you have a very good reason—you're usually correct on your first attempt
    • However, if you realize you misread the question, didn't notice a detail in the passage, or notice something that makes your answer choice incorrect, change your answer

3. Tip #3 — Never Worry About Patterns in the Answer Choices

  • "I bubbled in A and F for the last 4 questions. There is no way this one can be A again, right??" WRONG!
    • When answering a question, only focus on that question
    • Never let any pattern in the answer choices affect which answer choice you pick
    • Sometimes, the same spot on the scantron sheet is correct 4 or even 5 times in a row on the ACT
    • It's also possible that you answered one of the previous questions incorrectly, and there aren't supposed to be 4 or 5 in a row
    • There's no way for you to know on test day, so just focus on selecting what you think is correct for each question

4. Tip #4 — Boring is Better

  • Boring answer choices are usually better on the ACT
    • If you're ever between two answer choices, always pick the more boring answer choice
    • The more specific an answer choice is, the more likely something in that answer choice is incorrect
    • Remember: An answer choice must be 100% correct to be correct

Why We Pick Specific Answer Choices (and Why We Shouldn't)

  • The challenge is that we don't like to pick boring answer choices, especially on challenging questions
    • An answer choice with more details is much easier to come up with a story as to why the answer could be correct
    • This makes you feel better bubbling it in
    • Your job is to pick the answer choice that is supported by the passage, not the one that feels best to you
    • So again, when you're between two answer choices, pick the boring one with fewer details

5. Tip #5 — Beware of Keyword Matching

  • Anytime you see words in an answer choice that directly match words from the passage, proceed with caution
    • Make sure the entire answer choice is correct
    • Matching keywords may be in the correct answer choice, but they can also be in incorrect answer choices
    • These incorrect choices are often half-truths, where part of the answer choice perfectly matches the passage but another part is incorrect
    • Students often mistakenly pick these incorrect answer choices because the keywords match
    • Never just match keywords—always make sure the answer choice you select is 100% correct

6. Tip #6 — Do Not Over-Annotate

  • Some students annotate a lot. Others make no annotations at all. There is no right or wrong way to annotate.
    • You need to find what works best for you
    • What's most important is to make sure that annotating is helping you better understand the passage and work through the questions more efficiently
    • If you're underlining 50% of the passage, those are not helpful annotations
    • If you're writing down notes after each paragraph but never use those notes, you're wasting time

What Good Annotations Should Do

  • Proper annotations should help you:
    • Maintain focus as you read
    • Increase your comprehension of what you read
    • Know where in the passage to go when working through the questions
    • There is no best way to annotate for everyone—how much you annotate and what types of annotations you use varies from student to student
    • On practice ACTs, try different methods for annotation and find what works best for you

7. Tip #7 — Make the Most of Practice ACTs

  • Practice ACTs are the best way to improve on the Reading Test...if you're using and reviewing them properly
    • Here are some tips for how to make the most of your practice ACTs

Always Time Practice ACTs Strictly

  • Never give yourself extra time to finish the section and see how you would have scored
    • It will give you false confidence for how much you're improving
    • Strict timing is essential to building the time management skills you need on test day

Review Your Mistakes Thoroughly

  • Whenever you answer a question incorrectly, go back to the passage and find the evidence for the correct answer
    • Make sure you identify why your answer choice was incorrect
    • It is critical to learn from every single mistake you make to continuously improve

Be Obsessive About Improving

  • Students who improve the most on the Reading Test are the ones who are most obsessive about learning from their mistakes
    • After each question, try to figure out why you missed the question
    • Did you not read the question carefully enough?
    • Were you answering your own question and not exactly what the ACT was asking you?
    • Did you not recognize the type of question?
    • Once you figure out why you made the mistake, think about how you can avoid the mistake in the future
    • If necessary, go review any topic(s) from the chapters we have already covered

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Keep it moving—never spend more than 1 minute on any single question .
  • ✓Circle guesses and box non-confident answers—if you finish with time, go back.
  • ✓Boring is better—when stuck between two answer choices, always pick the more boring one.
  • ✓Don't over-annotate—proper annotations should help you maintain focus, increase comprehension.

lessons.subject: science
lessons.title: Topic 3.4 - Mixing
lessons.content:
Mixing questions require you to combine information from multiple figures, tables, or experiments to answer a single question. The key is to systematically identify what information each source provides and how they connect together.

How to Identify Mixing Questions

  • The question asks you to use multiple sources of information:
    • Mentions two or more figures (e.g., "Based on Figures 1 and 2...")
    • Asks about data from different experiments or trials
    • Requires combining a table with descriptive text
    • Needs you to link data across different parts of the passage
  • One source provides partial information that must be completed with another source:
    • Figure 1 shows temperature, Figure 2 shows pressure at each temperature
    • Table 1 lists compound names, Table 2 shows properties by ID number
    • Graph shows results, but you need text to understand experimental conditions

Strategy: The Bridge Method

  • Step 1: Identify the target - what is the question asking for?
    • What final value or comparison do you need?
    • Circle or note the specific question being asked
  • Step 2: Identify the starting point - what information are you given?
    • What specific value or condition is provided in the question?
    • Where can you find this in the passage?
  • Step 3: Find the bridge - what connects them?
    • Look for a common variable that appears in both sources
    • This is your "bridge" to transfer information between sources
    • Example: Temperature appears in both Figure 1 and Figure 2
  • Step 4: Cross the bridge - follow the connection:
    • Start with the given information in source 1
    • Use the bridge variable to move to source 2
    • Find your target answer in source 2

Common Mixing Patterns

  • Two-step lookup:
    • Question gives you value A
    • Figure 1 converts A → B
    • Figure 2 converts B → C (your answer)
    • Example: Time → Temperature (Fig 1) → Pressure (Fig 2)
  • Condition matching:
    • Text describes which trial had certain conditions
    • Table shows results for each trial
    • You must match the condition to the trial to find the result
  • Cross-referencing:
    • Table 1 uses names (e.g., "Compound X")
    • Table 2 uses codes (e.g., "Compound 1")
    • You need to link them using a key or legend

Tips for Complex Mixing Questions

  • Write it down:
    • For multi-step problems, jot down intermediate values
    • Example: "Time 2 → Temp 40°C → Pressure ?"
    • This prevents errors when switching between sources
  • Check your units:
    • Make sure the bridge variable has matching units
    • If Figure 1 shows temperature in °C, Figure 2 must also use °C
    • Watch for conversions (grams to kilograms, etc.)
  • Don't skip intermediate steps - work methodically through each source in order
  • If you get lost, restart from the beginning and identify the bridge variable again

Key Takeaways

  • ✓the Bridge Method: identify what you're given, what you need.
  • ✓Work step-by-step through each source - don't try to skip ahead or you'll make errors.
  • ✓Write down intermediate values when crossing between multiple figures.
  • ✓verify that the bridge variable has matching units across all sources.

lessons.subject: science
lessons.title: Topic 2.6 - Scatter Plots
lessons.content:
Scatter plots show relationships between two variables by plotting individual data points. Understanding how to read scatter plots and count data points is essential for ACT Science success.

What Is a Scatter Plot?

  • A scatter plot displays individual data points on a graph, with each point representing one measurement or trial
    • The x-axis typically shows the independent variable (what scientists change)
    • The y-axis shows the dependent variable (what scientists measure)
    • Each point represents one trial or observation
  • Unlike line graphs that connect all points, scatter plots show individual data points that may or may not form a clear pattern
    • Some scatter plots show tight clustering (strong relationship)
    • Others show loose patterns (weak relationship)
    • Points may follow positive, negative, or no correlation
  • Scatter plots are commonly used when:
    • Testing for correlations between variables
    • Showing multiple trials at the same conditions
    • Displaying variation or spread in data

How to Read Scatter Plots

  • Start by identifying what each axis represents:
    • Look at axis labels and units
    • Note the scale (linear, logarithmic, etc.)
    • Check the range of values shown
  • To find the value of a specific point:
    • Draw an imaginary vertical line down to the x-axis
    • Draw an imaginary horizontal line to the y-axis
    • Read the values where these lines intersect the axes
  • Look for overall patterns:
    • Positive correlation: points rise from left to right
    • Negative correlation: points fall from left to right
    • No correlation: points scattered randomly
  • Note any outliers (points far from the general pattern)

Counting Data Points on Scatter Plots

  • Questions often ask: "How many trials were conducted at [specific condition]?"
    • Find the x-value that matches the condition
    • Draw an imaginary vertical line at that x-value
    • Count every point that touches that vertical line
  • When counting points:
    • Be systematic - count from top to bottom or bottom to top
    • Watch for overlapping points (multiple trials at same x and y)
    • Don't count points at neighboring x-values
  • Common mistakes to avoid:
    • Counting all points on the graph instead of just at the specified x-value
    • Missing overlapping points that appear as one dot
    • Including points from adjacent x-values

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Each point on a scatter plot represents one trial or observation at specific x and y values.
  • ✓To count trials at a specific condition, find the x-value and count all points at.
  • ✓Watch for overlapping points that may appear as single dots but represent multiple trials.
  • ✓Scatter plots show relationships and variation.

lessons.subject: science
lessons.title: Topic 4.4 - Conflicting Viewpoints
lessons.content:
Conflicting viewpoints passages present two or more scientists, students, or hypotheses that disagree about a scientific topic. Your job is to understand each viewpoint, identify similarities and differences, and determine which viewpoint is supported by given evidence.

Structure of Conflicting Viewpoints Passages

  • Introduction: Brief background on the topic
    • Sets up the scientific question or phenomenon
    • May include basic facts or definitions
  • Viewpoint 1 (Scientist 1 or Hypothesis 1):
    • Presents one explanation or theory
    • Provides reasoning and evidence
  • Viewpoint 2 (Scientist 2 or Hypothesis 2):
    • Presents a different or opposing explanation
    • Provides counter-reasoning and evidence
  • Sometimes a Viewpoint 3 is included with a third perspective

Common Question Types

  • Understanding individual viewpoints:
    • "According to Scientist 1, what causes X?"
    • "Hypothesis 2 would predict that..."
    • Strategy: Find the specific viewpoint section and locate the answer
  • Comparing viewpoints:
    • "How do the viewpoints differ on...?"
    • "What do both scientists agree on?"
    • Strategy: Make a quick comparison chart or note similarities/differences
  • Evaluating with new evidence:
    • "New data shows X. This finding supports which viewpoint?"
    • "Which experiment would help distinguish between the viewpoints?"
    • Strategy: Test the new evidence against each viewpoint's predictions
  • Weakening/strengthening arguments:
    • "Which finding would weaken Scientist 2's viewpoint?"
    • "Which observation supports Hypothesis 1?"
    • Strategy: Look for evidence that contradicts or confirms key claims

Strategy for Conflicting Viewpoints

  • Step 1: Skim the introduction to understand the topic
    • What phenomenon or question is being debated?
    • Don't get bogged down in details - just get the gist
  • Step 2: Go straight to the questions
    • Don't read all viewpoints in detail first
    • Let the questions guide what you need to read
  • Step 3: For each question, locate the relevant viewpoint
    • Question about Scientist 1? Read only that section
    • Question comparing viewpoints? Read both sections
    • Be efficient - don't read more than necessary
  • Step 4: Identify the main claim of each viewpoint
    • Usually stated in the first 1-2 sentences
    • Example: "Scientist 1 believes the extinction was caused by asteroids"
    • Example: "Scientist 2 argues that volcanic activity was responsible"
  • Step 5: Note key differences and similarities
    • What do they disagree on?
    • What do they agree on (if anything)?

Tips for Success

  • Don't take sides - remain objective and understand each viewpoint on its own terms
  • Watch for extreme language in answer choices:
    • "Both scientists agree that..." → Must be stated by BOTH
    • "Only Scientist 1 believes..." → Must be unique to Scientist 1
  • For "new evidence" questions, ask: What would each viewpoint predict?
    • If new data matches Scientist 1's prediction → supports Scientist 1
    • If new data contradicts Scientist 2's prediction → weakens Scientist 2
  • These passages require more reading than data interpretation passages, but the questions are often straightforward if you know where to look

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Go straight to questions - don't read all viewpoints in detail first
  • ✓Identify the main claim of each viewpoint.
  • ✓new evidence questions, determine what each viewpoint would predict.
  • ✓Note key differences and similarities between viewpoints to answer comparison questions.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 2.2 - Word Choice
lessons.content:
Word choice questions appear on the ACT English Test and ask you to select the word that is clearest and most precise in context. These questions test your ability to read for context and choose the word that best conveys the intended meaning of the sentence.

1. Identifying Word Choice Questions

  • Word choice questions always have 4 words with no punctuation or the same punctuation
    • The question asks: "Which choice is clearest and most precise in context?"
    • All choices are grammatically correct
    • You must select the word that best fits the meaning and tone
  • These questions test both vocabulary and context
    • Some test word definitions (knowing what words mean)
    • Others test which word makes the most sense in this specific sentence
    • Context is always the key to finding the right answer

2. How to Approach Word Choice Questions

  • Follow this three-step process
    • Step 1: Read the sentence and surrounding sentences for context
    • Step 2: Plug each word into the sentence one at a time
    • Step 3: Pick the word that makes the most sense in context
  • Context includes both meaning and tone
    • Does the word's definition fit logically?
    • Does the word's formality level match the passage?
    • Does it create the intended relationship between ideas?

Example Approach

  • Question: "Adding solar panels to your house can emit huge savings on energy bills."
    • A. emit
    • B. claim
    • C. gift
    • D. result in
  • Analysis
    • "Emit" means to send out or release—doesn't fit with savings
    • "Claim" means to assert or demand—doesn't make sense here
    • "Gift" is a noun, not a verb that fits this context
    • "Result in" means to cause or produce—this fits perfectly!
  • The answer is D because "result in" is the only phrase that logically completes the meaning

3. Vocabulary Strategy

  • Don't assume the hardest word is correct
    • Sometimes the ACT includes challenging vocabulary you need to know
    • Other times, challenging words are incorrect answer choices
    • The difficulty level of the word doesn't indicate if it's right or wrong
  • What to do when you don't know a word
    • If you know a word works, pick it—even if it seems easy
    • Eliminate words you know are wrong
    • If you don't know a word and have to guess, make your best guess and move on
    • Don't spend too much time on vocabulary you don't know

Trust What You Know

  • Your instinct about common words is usually correct
    • If a simple word like "make" or "show" fits perfectly, it's likely correct
    • Don't overthink or assume you need a fancier word
    • The ACT values precision and clarity, not complexity

4. Common Word Choice Patterns

  • Similar-sounding words with different meanings
    • Affect (verb - to influence) vs. Effect (noun - result)
    • Elicit (to draw out) vs. Illicit (illegal)
    • Complement (to complete) vs. Compliment (to praise)
  • Words with similar meanings but different connotations
    • Dispassionate (unemotional) vs. Disinterested (unbiased) vs. Unbiased (neutral)
    • Display (to show) vs. Reveal (to uncover) vs. Exhibit (to demonstrate)
    • Context determines which shade of meaning is correct
  • Phrasal verbs and preposition choices
    • "Improved over" vs. "improved upon" vs. "improved above"
    • The correct preposition changes the meaning
    • Trust what sounds natural in standard English

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Word choice questions ask "Which choice is clearest and most precise ?" and provide 4 words.
  • ✓the three-step approach: surrounding context, Plug each word into the sentence, Pick the word.
  • ✓Don't assume the hardest vocabulary word is correct—sometimes challenging words are wrong answers.
  • ✓Watch for similar-sounding words with different meanings .

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Absolute Value
lessons.content:
1. What is Absolute Value? (Definition and Basic Operations)

  • Definition: Absolute value is the distance from zero on a number line
    • Distance is always positive, so absolute value is always positive or zero
    • |3| = 3 (3 is three units from zero)
    • |-3| = 3 (-3 is also three units from zero)
  • Order of Operations with Absolute Value:
    • Step 1: Complete all math INSIDE the absolute value bars first
    • Step 2: Take the absolute value (make positive)
    • Step 3: Complete remaining operations outside the bars
  • Example: |3 - 7| + 2
    • Step 1: Work inside bars: |3 - 7| = |-4|
    • Step 2: Take absolute value: |-4| = 4
    • Step 3: Complete outside: 4 + 2 = 6
  • Calculator Tip: Most calculators have an "abs(" function for absolute value
    • On TI calculators: MATH → NUM → abs(
    • You can use this to check your work quickly

2. Solving Absolute Value Equations with Variables

  • Key Concept: Absolute value equations with variables have TWO solutions
    • Why? Because both a positive and negative number can have the same absolute value
    • Example: |x - 3| = 5 means (x - 3) could equal 5 OR -5
  • Four-Step Process to Solve:
    • Step 1: Add/subtract any constants OUTSIDE the absolute value bars to move them to the other side
    • Step 2: Multiply/divide any coefficients directly IN FRONT of the absolute value bars
    • Step 3: Set the expression inside equal to BOTH the positive and negative value
    • Step 4: Solve both equations to get both solutions
  • Example: 3|2x + 1| - 6 = 45
    • Step 1: Add 6 to both sides → 3|2x + 1| = 51
    • Step 2: Divide by 3 → |2x + 1| = 17
    • Step 3: Set up two equations:
    • • 2x + 1 = 17 → 2x = 16 → x = 8
    • • 2x + 1 = -17 → 2x = -18 → x = -9
    • Solution set: {-9, 8}
  • Common Mistake: Only finding one solution
    • ALWAYS check answer choices - if they show two values, you need both solutions!
    • If you only find one solution, you probably forgot the negative case

3. Absolute Value Inequalities (The Most Difficult Type)

  • Key Concept: Absolute value inequalities have INTERVAL solutions (not just two numbers)
    • |x| < 3 means "all numbers less than 3 units from zero"
    • Solution: -3 < x < 3 (between -3 and 3)
  • Two Main Types:
    • Type 1: |x| < a or |x| ≤ a (Less than)
    • • Solution format: -a < x < a (or -a ≤ x ≤ a)
    • • One compound inequality
    • • Think: "close to zero" or "between two values"
    • Type 2: |x| > a or |x| ≥ a (Greater than)
    • • Solution format: x < -a AND x > a (or x ≤ -a AND x ≥ a)
    • • Two separate inequalities with "AND"
    • • Think: "far from zero" or "outside the interval"
  • Four-Step Process:
    • Step 1: Isolate the absolute value bars (move all terms outside to the other side)
    • Step 2: Determine the type (< means "between", > means "outside")
    • Step 3: Set up the inequality based on type
    • Step 4: Solve for the variable
  • Example 1: |x + 3| - 4 < 1 (Less than type)
    • Step 1: Add 4 to both sides → |x + 3| < 5
    • Step 2: This is "less than" type, so solution is between -5 and 5
    • Step 3: Set up: -5 < x + 3 < 5
    • Step 4: Subtract 3 from all parts: -8 < x < 2
  • Example 2: |½x + 2| > 3 (Greater than type)
    • Step 1: Already isolated
    • Step 2: This is "greater than" type, so solution is outside -3 and 3
    • Step 3: Set up two inequalities:
    • • ½x + 2 < -3 → ½x < -5 → x < -10
    • • ½x + 2 > 3 → ½x > 1 → x > 2
    • Step 4: Solution: x < -10 AND x > 2

4. Advanced Absolute Value Concepts

  • Absolute Value Properties You Must Know:
    • If |a| = -a, then a ≤ 0 (a must be zero or negative)
    • Why? The only way absolute value equals its negative is if the number is ≤ 0
    • For x > 0 and y < 0: |x| - |y| = x - (-y) = x + y
    • Positive number's absolute value = itself
    • Negative number's absolute value = its opposite
  • Comparing Absolute Values:
    • If a < b < c and c > 0:
    • • |c| is always the largest (furthest from zero on positive side)
    • • Can't determine which of |a| or |b| is larger without more info
    • Example: If a = -10, b = -2, c = 5:
    • • |a| = 10, |b| = 2, |c| = 5
    • • |a| > |c| even though a < c
  • Distance Interpretation:
    • |x - a| = d means "x is d units away from a"
    • Example: |x + 2| = 8 means "x is 8 units from -2"
    • Note: x + 2 = x - (-2), so we're measuring distance from -2
    • Solutions: x = 6 or x = -10 (both are 8 units from -2)
  • Equivalent Expressions:
    • |x - y - z| = |x - (y + z)|
    • This also equals |-x + y + z| (opposite signs for all terms)
    • Absolute value of opposites are equal: |a| = |-a|
  • Special Case: No Solution
    • If you end up with something like |-3x + 1| + 15 < 12:
    • Isolate: |-3x + 1| < -3
    • Absolute value can NEVER be negative, so NO SOLUTION!

5. Test-Taking Tips for Absolute Value

  • Tip #1: Look at answer choices first to determine what type of problem it is
    • Two numbers in braces like {-9, 8}? → Absolute value equation (2 solutions)
    • Compound inequality like -8 < x < 2? → Absolute value inequality (interval)
    • Two inequalities with AND? → Greater than type inequality
  • Tip #2: For equations, backsolve by plugging in answer choices
    • If the question asks for the solution to |2x - 4| = 10:
    • Try x = 7: |2(7) - 4| = |14 - 4| = |10| = 10 ✓
    • This is often faster than algebraic solving
  • Tip #3: Remember the critical patterns
    • |x| < a → between two values (one compound inequality)
    • |x| > a → outside two values (two separate inequalities with AND)
    • Memorize these patterns - they appear on EVERY ACT test!
  • Tip #4: Watch out for the "no solution" trap
    • If you isolate absolute value bars and get |something| < negative number → NO SOLUTION
    • If you isolate and get |something| = negative number → NO SOLUTION
    • This often appears as answer choice "No solution" or "The empty set"
✨

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Absolute value equations with variables ALWAYS have two solutions - set the inside equal to both positive and negative values
  • ✓For inequalities: |x| a means x a (outside)
  • ✓Always isolate the absolute value bars first before setting up your equations or inequalities
  • ✓Remember: absolute value can never be negative - if you get |something| < 0, the answer is "no solution"

lessons.subject: science
lessons.title: Topic 3.3 - Equations as Answers
lessons.content:
Questions with equations as answer choices require you to identify the correct mathematical relationship between variables based on data patterns in figures or tables. The key is to test each equation systematically using specific data points from the provided information.

How to Identify Equation Questions

  • All four answer choices are mathematical equations or formulas
    • Example: y = 2x + 3
    • Example: T = 100 - 5h
    • Example: P = 760/d
    • The variables in the equations correspond to axes or columns in the data
  • The question typically asks: "Which equation best represents the relationship between..."
    • May ask about relationship between two variables
    • May ask which equation matches the data pattern
    • Sometimes asks for an equation to predict values

Strategy: Pick Easy Numbers to Test

  • Step 1: Identify the variables in the equations and match them to the data:
    • Figure out which variable is which (x-axis, y-axis, table columns)
    • Make sure you understand what each variable represents
  • Step 2: Choose the easiest data point to test:
    • Look for simple numbers (0, 1, 10, 100) that make calculations easy
    • Avoid decimals or complex numbers if possible
    • Using x=0 or y=0 often simplifies equations dramatically
  • Step 3: Plug the data point into each equation:
    • Substitute the values from your chosen data point
    • Calculate what the equation predicts
    • Eliminate equations that don't match the actual data
  • Step 4: If multiple equations remain, test a second data point:
    • Repeat the process with another easy data point
    • Continue until only one equation remains

Common Equation Patterns to Recognize

  • Linear relationships (y = mx + b):
    • Data points form a straight line
    • Constant rate of change
    • Example: Temperature decreases by 5°C for each 1km increase in altitude
  • Inverse relationships (y = k/x):
    • As one variable increases, the other decreases
    • Product of x and y is constant
    • Example: Pressure decreases as volume increases (P = k/V)
  • Direct proportions (y = kx):
    • Linear relationship passing through origin (0,0)
    • Ratio of y to x is constant
    • Example: Distance = speed × time (when starting at 0)
  • You don't need to derive equations - just test the given options against the data

Tips for Quick Elimination

  • Check the direction of relationship first:
    • If data shows y increasing as x increases, eliminate equations with negative slopes
    • If data shows y decreasing as x increases, eliminate equations with positive slopes
  • Use special values strategically:
    • When x=0, equations simplify to y = b (the y-intercept)
    • When y=0, you can solve for x-intercept
    • When x=1, equations simplify nicely (y = m + b)
  • Don't waste time doing complex algebra - systematically test one data point at a time until you eliminate all wrong answers

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Test equations by plugging in actual data points - don't try to derive them from scratch.
  • ✓Choose the easiest data points first (values of 0, 1, 10.
  • ✓Eliminate equations systematically - one data point often eliminates 2-3 wrong answers.
  • ✓Check the direction of the relationship first to quickly eliminate impossible equations.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 2.1 - Redundancy & Wordiness
lessons.content:
Redundancy, wordiness, and irrelevance questions appear frequently on the ACT English Test. For these questions, the shortest and simplest answer choice that expresses the same idea is almost always correct—if anything is redundant, wordy, or irrelevant, eliminate it.

1. Redundancy

  • Redundancy occurs when information is unnecessarily repeated
    • Read the sentence itself AND the sentence(s) before to check for repeated information
    • If two words or phrases mean the same thing, one must be removed
  • Common redundant phrases to watch for
    • ❌ "Returned back" → ✓ "Returned" (returning already means coming back)
    • ❌ "In the Swedish forests" when Sweden was already mentioned → ✓ "In the forests"
    • ❌ "Past history" → ✓ "History" (history is always past)
    • ❌ "Free gift" → ✓ "Gift" (gifts are free by definition)

Example: Context-Based Redundancy

  • ❌ Incorrect: "In Sweden, there are about 300,000 to 400,000 moose, many of which stand over seven feet tall, roaming freely in the Swedish forests."
  • ✓ Correct: "In Sweden, there are about 300,000 to 400,000 moose, many of which stand over 7 feet tall, roaming freely in the forests."
  • Why: The sentence already specifies the moose are in Sweden, so "Swedish" is redundant

2. Wordiness

  • Sentences can be unnecessarily wordy without being redundant
    • Pick the answer choice that uses the fewest words to express the same idea
    • Eliminate flowery or unnecessarily complex language
  • Common wordy phrases and their concise alternatives
    • ❌ "Due to the fact that" → ✓ "Because"
    • ❌ "At this point in time" → ✓ "Now"
    • ❌ "In the event that" → ✓ "If"
    • ❌ "A cultural institution supporting intellectual endeavors related to renaissance art" → ✓ "A museum devoted to renaissance art"

Example: Simplifying Wordy Phrases

  • ❌ Incorrect: "The ancient Italian sculptures were donated to a cultural institution supporting intellectual endeavors related to renaissance art."
  • ✓ Correct: "The ancient Italian sculptures were donated to a museum devoted to renaissance art."
  • Why: The simpler version conveys the exact same meaning with far fewer words

3. Irrelevance

  • Irrelevant information doesn't contribute to the passage's main idea or current paragraph
    • Irrelevant details most often appear as long, wordy answer choices
    • These answer choices are always incorrect
    • Ask: Does this information help tell the story or explain the concept?

Example: Removing Irrelevant Details

  • ❌ Incorrect: "To win the game, Ricky needed to make both free throws. Players are not allowed to step in the lane during a free throw attempt. He made the first one. The entire gym was quiet as he stepped to the line for the second."
  • ✓ Correct: "To win the game, Ricky needed to make both free throws. He made the first one. The entire gym was quiet as he stepped to the line for the second."
  • Why: The rule about stepping in the lane is irrelevant to Ricky's specific free throw situation

4. How to Spot These Questions

  • The ACT directly tells you when testing redundancy, wordiness, or irrelevance
    • Look for questions asking: "Which choice is the least redundant in context?"
    • Or: "Which choice best avoids wordiness and redundancy in context?"
    • When you see these questions, the shortest answer is almost always correct
  • Important warning: ONLY use "shortest is correct" for these specific questions
    • On grammar questions (not asking about redundancy), the shortest answer may be wrong
    • Example: An ambiguous pronoun like "it" or "them" might be shortest but incorrect
    • Always apply grammar rules first unless the question specifically asks about redundancy

Recognizing Ambiguous Pronouns

  • Even though pronouns are short, they're incorrect if ambiguous
    • Watch for: they, them, it, this, that, these, those, some, none
    • If you can't tell exactly what the pronoun refers to, it's incorrect
    • Example: "Freddie ordered some" is ambiguous—some what? Coral? Aquariums?
    • Correct: "Freddie ordered some coral colonies" clearly specifies what he ordered

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Redundancy occurs when information is unnecessarily repeated—check the current sentence and previous sentences for duplicate information.
  • ✓Wordiness means using more words than necessary to express an idea.
  • ✓Irrelevant information doesn't contribute.
  • ✓The ACT directly asks "Which choice is the least redundant ?" or "Which choice best avoids wordiness?" For THESE questions only.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 2.3 - Transitions
lessons.content:
Transition questions test your reading comprehension by asking you to select the word or phrase that best connects ideas between sentences. All answer choices will be grammatically correct, so you must read for context to determine which transition logically relates the ideas.

1. How to Approach Transition Questions

  • Follow this three-step process
    • Step 1: Ignore the transition currently in the passage—cover it up
    • Step 2: Read the sentence(s) before and after to determine their relationship
    • Step 3: Select the transition that correctly relates the ideas
  • Context is everything
    • You cannot determine the correct transition by reading only one sentence
    • Always read both the previous and following sentences
    • Ask: What is the relationship between these ideas?

2. Type 1: All Four Choices Are Transitions

  • When all 4 answer choices are transitions, you're only being tested on selecting the correct one
    • Read for context to understand the relationship
    • Match the transition to the logical connection between ideas

Example

  • "From a distance, the ocean looked pretty calm today even though a storm had arrived last night. Under the circumstances, the scene was much more chaotic with big waves and strong riptides."
    • A. NO CHANGE (Under the circumstances)
    • B. For instance
    • C. Up close
    • D. For example
  • ✓ Correct: C. "Up close" creates a contrast with "from a distance" in the previous sentence

3. Type 2: Three Transitions and One "No Transition" Option

  • When one choice has no transition, the ACT is asking whether a transition is even necessary
    • Most often, the correct answer is the one that removes the transition entirely
    • Only use a transition if it properly links the sentences
    • If the ideas flow naturally without a transition, choose the "no transition" option

When to Remove Transitions

  • Remove the transition if:
    • The sentences are simply continuing the same idea
    • The relationship is already clear without a transition word
    • Adding a transition makes the connection awkward or incorrect

4. Common Transition Categories

  • Contrast/Opposition: However, Nevertheless, On the other hand, In contrast, Despite this
  • Example/Illustration: For example, For instance, Specifically, In particular
  • Cause/Effect: Therefore, Consequently, As a result, Thus, Hence
  • Addition: Furthermore, Moreover, Additionally, In addition, Also
  • Time Sequence: Meanwhile, Subsequently, Previously, Ultimately, Finally
  • Emphasis: Indeed, In fact, Certainly, Undoubtedly

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓the three-step approach: Ignore the current transition, Read sentences before and after.
  • ✓When all 4 choices are transitions, you're choosing.
  • ✓Remove transitions when sentences simply continue the same idea, the relationship is already clear.
  • ✓Know the main transition categories: Contrast , Example , Cause/Effect , Addition , Time .

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Topic 7.4 - Vectors
lessons.content:
A vector is a quantity that has both magnitude (length) and direction. Vectors commonly are used to show motion, such as velocity and acceleration. Since vectors are not commonly taught in math class, many students are stumped when vectors appear on the ACT. The good news is that vector questions on the ACT primarily test vector addition and subtraction, which involves simple arithmetic with like terms.

1. Understanding Vectors

  • A vector shows the magnitude and direction of a motion
    • Vectors are drawn as arrows on the coordinate plane
    • The magnitude is the length of the vector (represents speed, distance, or strength)
    • The direction is shown by which way the arrow points
    • Example: A car driving at 30° east of north at 10 mph would have magnitude 10 and direction 30° from north
  • Vectors on the ACT are most commonly written in two forms:
    • Standard form: v = Ai + Bj
      • Ai shows the x-component (horizontal movement)
      • Bj shows the y-component (vertical movement)
      • Example: 3i + 4j means 3 units right, 4 units up
    • Component form: v = (A, B)
      • A shows the x-component
      • B shows the y-component
      • Example: (3, 4) means 3 units right, 4 units up
  • When starting at the origin, a vector written in Ai + Bj or (A, B) notation ends at point (A, B)
    • Vector (3, 4) starts at origin and ends at point (3, 4)
    • Vector (-4, -2) starts at origin and ends at point (-4, -2)

2. Vector Addition and Subtraction

  • Vector addition and subtraction is the most common vector question on the ACT
    • The good news: it's simple arithmetic!
    • All you do is combine like terms
  • For component form (A, B):
    • Add or subtract the A values (x-components) together
    • Add or subtract the B values (y-components) together
    • Example: (2, 5) + (-6, 8) = (2 + (-6), 5 + 8) = (-4, 13)
  • For standard form Ai + Bj:
    • Combine the i terms (x-components)
    • Combine the j terms (y-components)
    • Example: (4i + 5j) + (-2i + 6j) = 2i + 11j
  • When there's a coefficient in front of a vector, distribute it first
    • If A = 5i - j and we want 2A, distribute: 2A = 2(5i - j) = 10i - 2j
    • Example: If A = 5i - j and B = 12i - 4j, then 2A - B = (10i - 2j) - (12i - 4j) = -2i + 2j
    • Remember to distribute the negative sign when subtracting!
  • Common mistake: Forgetting to distribute the negative sign
    • WRONG: (3i + 4j) - (2i + j) = 3i + 4j - 2i + j = i + 5j ✗
    • RIGHT: (3i + 4j) - (2i + j) = 3i + 4j - 2i - j = i + 3j ✓

3. The Tip-to-Tail Method for Graphing

  • For more advanced vector questions, you may need to visualize vector addition on a graph
    • This uses the tip-to-tail method
    • The "tip" is where the arrow points (the head of the arrow)
    • The "tail" is the straight end (where the arrow starts)
  • Steps for tip-to-tail method:
    • Step 1: Start at the origin and draw the first vector
      • If solving A + B + C, draw vector A first
      • Where the tip (arrow head) lands is your new starting point
    • Step 2: Start at the tip of the first vector and draw the second vector
      • The tail of the second vector starts where the tip of the first ended
      • This is why it's called "tip-to-tail"
    • Step 3: Repeat for any additional vectors
      • Keep connecting tail to tip
    • Step 4: Draw a vector from the origin to the final tip
      • This new vector represents your answer
      • It shows the combined effect of all the vectors
  • When subtracting vectors on a graph:
    • Draw the vector in the opposite direction
    • If +C goes 3 units right and 1 unit down, then -C goes 3 units left and 1 unit up
    • Flip both the horizontal and vertical components
  • Example: To find A + B - C graphically
    • Draw A starting at origin
    • Draw B starting at tip of A
    • Draw -C (opposite direction of C) starting at tip of B
    • Draw final vector from origin to tip of -C

4. Magnitude of a Vector

  • The magnitude of a vector is the length of the vector
    • Magnitude represents the speed, distance, or strength
    • Example: A ball traveling at 40 feet per second has magnitude 40
    • Magnitude is rarely tested on the ACT, but you should know the formula
  • Formula for magnitude:
    • For vector Ai + Bj or (A, B): magnitude = √(A² + B²)
    • This is the same as the Pythagorean theorem!
    • Example: Magnitude of (3, 4) = √(3² + 4²) = √(9 + 16) = √25 = 5
  • If you forget the formula on test day:
    • Draw the vector on the coordinate plane
    • Create a right triangle using the vector as the hypotenuse
    • Use Pythagorean theorem: a² + b² = c²

5. Vectors in Context: Direction and Motion

  • The ACT often presents vectors in real-world contexts
    • Common scenarios: driving, flying, jogging, sailing
    • The vector i represents 1 unit east (or right)
    • The vector j represents 1 unit north (or up)
  • Translating directions to vectors:
    • East: positive i direction (example: 5 mph east = 5i)
    • West: negative i direction (example: 9 mph west = -9i)
    • North: positive j direction (example: 3 mph north = 3j)
    • South: negative j direction (example: 7 mph south = -7j)
  • Example: Sarah is jogging west at 9 miles per hour
    • West means negative i direction
    • 9 miles per hour is the magnitude
    • Vector: -9i
  • Example: Tia drives 5 miles south and 5√3 miles west
    • South = -5j
    • West = -5√3i
    • Combined vector: -5√3i - 5j
  • Angles and directions:
    • Questions may specify "30° north of east" or "45° east of north"
    • These typically require trigonometry to find exact components
    • But on the ACT, these questions usually just ask for magnitude or general direction

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Vectors have two forms: standard form Ai + Bj and component form (A, B), where A is the x-component and B is the y-component
  • ✓To add or subtract vectors, simply combine like terms: add the x-components together and add the y-components together (remember to distribute coefficients and negative signs!)
  • ✓Use the tip-to-tail method for graphing vector addition: draw each vector starting at the tip of the previous one, then draw the result from origin to the final tip
  • ✓Magnitude of vector (A, B) is √(A² + B²), which is the same as the Pythagorean theorem

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Topic 7.5 - Word Problems
lessons.content:
Word problems are one of the most challenging aspects of the ACT Math Test. Word problems can cover any math topic—from algebra to geometry to probability—and are often written in confusing ways that make it difficult to figure out exactly what is being asked. The good news is that word problems at their core are no more difficult than any other ACT Math questions. This lesson will teach you powerful strategies to tackle word problems more effectively and efficiently.

1. Don't Be Intimidated

  • Word problems look scary, but they don't have to be
    • Many students see a big paragraph and think "no way, I can't solve that"
    • They feel intimidated before even trying to solve the question
    • Don't let this be you!
  • Word problems are just regular math problems dressed up in words
    • At their core, they test the same skills as any other ACT Math question
    • The challenge is translating words into math
    • Once you do that, the problem becomes much simpler
  • Mindset matters
    • When you see a big paragraph on test day, take a deep breath
    • Solve it one step at a time
    • Breaking it down makes it manageable

2. Turn Words into Equations

  • This is the most powerful strategy for word problems
    • Read through the question one sentence at a time
    • Identify each piece of key information
    • Write it down as an equation or mathematical expression
  • If you can convert the word problem into equations, it becomes much easier to solve
    • Example: "The price of Matt's meal was $6 more than John's meal" → M = J + 6
    • Example: "They split the cost evenly" → Each pays (J + M) / 2
  • Common translations from words to math:
    • "More than" → Addition (+)
      • "5 more than x" → x + 5
    • "Less than" → Subtraction (-)
      • "3 less than y" → y - 3
    • "Times" or "product of" → Multiplication (×)
      • "6 times as many" → 6x
    • "Per" or "divided by" → Division (÷)
      • "200 cubic inches per minute" → 200/min
    • "Is" or "equals" → Equals sign (=)
      • "The total is 100" → Total = 100
  • System of equations word problems
    • One of the most common types of word problems
    • You'll need to turn the word problem into two equations
    • Once you have the equations, solve using substitution or elimination
    • Example: "10 bagels and 3 tubs of cream cheese cost $24.40. 16 bagels cost $22.72"
      • Equation 1: 10b + 3c = 24.40
      • Equation 2: 16b = 22.72
      • Solve for b first, then find c

3. Backsolve with the Answer Choices

  • Sometimes writing your own equations is difficult or time-consuming
    • In these cases, backsolving can be faster and easier
    • Take the answer choices and work backwards through the problem
    • See which answer choice satisfies all the conditions in the problem
  • How to backsolve effectively:
    • Step 1: Start with answer choice C (the middle value)
      • Answer choices are usually listed in order
      • If C doesn't work, you can often tell if you need a larger or smaller value
    • Step 2: Plug the answer choice into the problem
      • Go through each step described in the word problem
      • See if the numbers work out correctly
    • Step 3: Check if it satisfies all conditions
      • If yes, you found the answer!
      • If no, try the next logical answer choice
  • When backsolving is especially useful:
    • When setting up equations seems complicated
    • When you're not confident your equation is correct
    • When the problem involves multiple steps that are easier to check than to set up
  • Benefits of backsolving:
    • Even if you can't find the right answer, you can often eliminate wrong answers
    • This allows you to make a better guess
    • It's a safety net when algebraic approaches fail

4. Organize Your Information

  • Create a visual representation of the problem
    • Drawing a picture, table, or diagram can clarify what's happening
    • This is especially helpful for geometry word problems
    • Example: Rate problems (distance = rate × time) benefit from a table
  • Label what you know and what you need to find
    • Write down all given information clearly
    • Circle or underline what the question is asking for
    • This prevents you from solving for the wrong thing
  • Assign variables strategically
    • Use letters that make sense (b for bagels, c for cream cheese)
    • Write down what each variable represents
    • This prevents confusion when you have multiple variables
  • Break complex problems into smaller steps
    • Don't try to solve everything at once
    • Find one piece of information at a time
    • Build up to the final answer step by step

5. Time Management and Strategic Guessing

  • Don't waste too much time on a single word problem
    • It's easy to waste minutes reading and rereading confusing word problems
    • Students who do this often run out of time on the ACT Math test
    • Time spent on one hard problem could be better used answering several easier ones
  • Know when to guess and move on
    • If you've tried the strategies and still have no idea, it's time to guess
    • Circle the question in your test booklet so you can find it later
    • Bubble in your best guess
    • Move on to questions you know how to solve
  • Giving up quickly might actually improve your score
    • This sounds backwards, but it's true!
    • Saving those precious minutes for other questions is strategic
    • You can always come back if you have time remaining
  • Coming back to problems with fresh eyes
    • If you complete the rest of the section and have time, return to circled questions
    • Sometimes when re-reading, you'll suddenly see how to solve it
    • It's easier to think clearly when you're not worried about finishing
  • Eliminate obviously wrong answers
    • Even if you can't solve the problem, you can often rule out some choices
    • Is the answer clearly too big or too small?
    • Does it have the wrong units?
    • Eliminating even one answer choice increases your guessing odds

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Don't be intimidated by word problems—they test the same math skills as other questions, just dressed up in words; take a deep breath and solve one step at a time
  • ✓Turn words into equations by reading one sentence at a time and translating key information into mathematical expressions; this makes complex problems much easier to solve
  • ✓Use backsolving when setting up equations is difficult: start with answer choice C, plug it into the problem, and check if it satisfies all conditions
  • ✓Manage your time wisely—if you're stuck after trying the strategies, guess and move on to save time for questions you can solve; you can always come back later with fresh eyes

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Probability
lessons.content:
Counting problems ask "how many" ways something can occur. The ACT tests factorials, the fundamental counting principle, permutations, and combinations.

1. Factorials

  • The factorial function, symbolized by "!", multiplies an integer by every integer below it:
    • n! = n × (n-1) × (n-2) × ... × 2 × 1
    • Example: 5! = 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1 = 120
    • Example: 3! = 3 × 2 × 1 = 6
    • Special case: 0! = 1 (by definition)
  • Most ACT factorial questions are simple calculations:
    • Example: 2! + 4! = ?
    • 2! = 2 × 1 = 2
    • 4! = 4 × 3 × 2 × 1 = 24
    • 2! + 4! = 2 + 24 = 26
  • Calculator tip:
    • Most calculators have a "!" button
    • Check your calculator manual if unsure
    • Saves time on larger factorials like 7! or 10!
  • Simplifying factorial fractions (advanced):
    • Example: (3! × n!)/(n+1)!
    • Expand: (6 × n × (n-1) × ... × 1)/((n+1) × n × (n-1) × ... × 1)
    • Cancel common terms: n! cancels out
    • Result: 6/(n+1)

2. Fundamental Counting Principle

  • The fundamental counting principle: If one event can occur in m ways and another can occur in n ways, then both can occur in m × n ways
    • Multiply the number of choices for each decision
    • This is the MOST common counting method on the ACT
    • Works when order matters AND when order doesn't matter (for independent choices)
  • Example: Creating outfits
    • You have 3 shirts, 4 pairs of shoes, and 5 pairs of pants
    • How many different outfits can you create?
    • Total outfits = 3 × 4 × 5 = 60
  • Example: Lock codes
    • A lock code has 3 numbers (0-9) and 2 letters (A-Z)
    • How many different codes are possible?
    • Numbers: 10 choices for each digit = 10 × 10 × 10 = 1,000
    • Letters: 26 choices for each letter = 26 × 26 = 676
    • Total codes = 1,000 × 676 = 676,000
  • When choices decrease (without replacement):
    • Example: Selecting 3 people from a group of 10 for 1st, 2nd, 3rd place
    • 1st place: 10 choices
    • 2nd place: 9 choices (one person already selected)
    • 3rd place: 8 choices
    • Total arrangements = 10 × 9 × 8 = 720

3. Permutations (Order Matters)

  • Permutations count arrangements where ORDER MATTERS:
    • Different orderings count as different outcomes
    • Example: ABC is different from BAC
    • Used for rankings, positions, seating arrangements
  • The permutation formula:
    • nPr = n!/(n-r)!
    • n = total number of items
    • r = number of items being selected
    • nPr = number of ways to arrange r items from n items
  • Example: How many ways can you arrange 3 books from a shelf of 5 books?
    • n = 5 books total, r = 3 books selected
    • 5P3 = 5!/(5-3)! = 5!/2!
    • 5P3 = (5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1)/(2 × 1)
    • 5P3 = 120/2 = 60 arrangements
  • Shortcut using fundamental counting principle:
    • Same problem: 5 books, select 3
    • 1st position: 5 choices
    • 2nd position: 4 choices
    • 3rd position: 3 choices
    • Total = 5 × 4 × 3 = 60 (same answer, faster!)

4. Combinations (Order Doesn't Matter)

  • Combinations count selections where ORDER DOESN'T MATTER:
    • Different orderings count as the SAME outcome
    • Example: ABC is the same as BAC is the same as CAB
    • Used for groups, committees, selections
  • The combination formula:
    • nCr = n!/(r!(n-r)!)
    • n = total number of items
    • r = number of items being selected
    • nCr = number of ways to select r items from n items
  • Example: How many ways can you select 3 books from a shelf of 5 books?
    • n = 5 books, r = 3 books (order doesn't matter)
    • 5C3 = 5!/(3! × 2!)
    • 5C3 = (5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1)/((3 × 2 × 1) × (2 × 1))
    • 5C3 = 120/(6 × 2) = 120/12 = 10
  • Key difference from permutations:
    • Same problem with permutations gave 60 arrangements
    • With combinations, we get 10 selections
    • Combinations are ALWAYS smaller (or equal) to permutations
    • We divide by r! to remove duplicate orderings

5. When to Use Each Method

  • Use Fundamental Counting Principle when:
    • Making multiple independent choices
    • Creating combinations of items (outfits, meals, codes)
    • This is the FASTEST method—use it whenever possible!
  • Use Permutations when:
    • ORDER MATTERS in the selection
    • Words: "arrange," "order," "rank," "position"
    • Examples: Race finish order, seating arrangements, passwords
  • Use Combinations when:
    • ORDER DOESN'T MATTER in the selection
    • Words: "group," "committee," "team," "select," "choose"
    • Examples: Choosing committee members, selecting toppings, forming groups
  • Quick decision tree:
    • Question asks "how many outfits/meals/codes?" → Fundamental Counting Principle (multiply choices)
    • Question asks "arrange" or "order" → Permutation (order matters)
    • Question asks "select" or "choose a group" → Combination (order doesn't matter)
  • Common ACT trick:
    • The ACT will often make permutation and combination both answer choices
    • Read carefully: does order matter?
    • If you select people for a "committee," order doesn't matter (combination)
    • If you select people for "president, VP, secretary," order matters (permutation)

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Factorials: n.
  • ✓Fundamental Counting Principle .
  • ✓Permutations : nPr = n!/!
  • ✓Combinations : nCr = n!/!).

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Topic 4.1 - Systems of Equations
lessons.content:
A system of equations is a set of two equations with the same unknowns. The ACT frequently hides systems questions in word problems about tickets, prices, or quantities. This lesson covers elimination, substitution, and the powerful backsolve strategy for complex problems.

1. The Elimination Method (When Neither Variable is Isolated)

  • Key Concept: Elimination works by canceling out one variable
    • We cannot solve an equation with two variables
    • By making coefficients equal and opposite, one variable cancels when we add equations
    • This leaves us with one equation and one unknown we can solve
  • Step-by-Step Process:
    • Step 1: Choose which variable to eliminate (usually the one that's easiest)
    • Step 2: Multiply one or both equations to make coefficients equal and opposite
    • Step 3: Add the equations together (one variable cancels out)
    • Step 4: Solve for the remaining variable
    • Step 5: (If needed) Plug back into either original equation to find the other variable
  • Example: 10x - 4y = 16 and 2x + 4y = 8, solve for y
    • Step 1: Eliminate x (easier because we need to solve for y)
    • Step 2: Multiply second equation by -5:
    • • 10x - 4y = 16
    • • -10x - 20y = -40
    • Step 3: Add equations (x cancels!):
    • • -24y = -24
    • Step 4: Solve: y = 1
  • When to use Elimination:
    • Neither variable is already isolated in either equation
    • Both equations are in standard form (Ax + By = C)
    • The coefficients are "nice" numbers that make elimination easy
  • Pro Tip: Look for coefficients that already match or almost match
    • In the example above, the y-coefficients were already -4 and +4
    • Sometimes you don't need to multiply at all - just add or subtract!

2. The Substitution Method (When One Variable is Already Isolated)

  • Key Concept: Substitution replaces a variable with its equivalent expression
    • If one variable is already isolated (like y = something), use substitution
    • Replace that variable in the other equation with the expression
    • This gives you one equation with one unknown
  • Step-by-Step Process:
    • Step 1: Identify which variable is already isolated
    • Step 2: Substitute the expression into the other equation
    • Step 3: Solve for the remaining variable
    • Step 4: (If needed) Plug back to find the other variable
  • Example: 12x + 8y = 8 and y = 6x - 14, solve for x
    • Step 1: y is already isolated in the second equation
    • Step 2: Substitute (6x - 14) for y in the first equation:
    • • 12x + 8(6x - 14) = 8
    • Step 3: Distribute and solve:
    • • 12x + 48x - 112 = 8
    • • 60x - 112 = 8
    • • 60x = 120
    • • x = 2
  • When to use Substitution:
    • One variable is ALREADY isolated (y = ..., x = ..., etc.)
    • One variable has a coefficient of 1 or -1 (easy to isolate)
    • If you see "y = " or "x = " in the problem, use substitution!
  • Common Mistake: Forgetting to distribute
    • When substituting, make sure to distribute to ALL terms in parentheses
    • Example: 8(6x - 14) = 48x - 112, NOT 48x - 14 ❌

3. Word Problems: Setting Up Systems from Real Situations

  • Key Concept: The ACT loves to hide systems of equations in word problems
    • The hardest part is translating words into equations
    • Once you have the equations, just use elimination or substitution
    • Look for TWO different relationships between the same variables
  • Common Word Problem Patterns:
    • Pattern #1: Total + Cost
    • • One equation for total number of items
    • • One equation for total cost (price × quantity)
    • Pattern #2: Tickets sold
    • • One equation for total tickets
    • • One equation for total revenue
    • Pattern #3: Two rates
    • • Distance = rate × time (two different scenarios)
  • Example: Mary buys 42 plants for $108. Tomato plants cost $3, pepper plants cost $2. How many pepper plants?
    • Step 1: Define variables
    • • Let x = tomato plants, y = pepper plants
    • Step 2: Write equation for TOTAL plants:
    • • x + y = 42
    • Step 3: Write equation for TOTAL cost:
    • • 3x + 2y = 108
    • Step 4: Use elimination (multiply first equation by -3):
    • • -3x - 3y = -126
    • • 3x + 2y = 108
    • • Add: -y = -18 → y = 18
    • Answer: 18 pepper plants
  • Pro Tip: Always check which variable the question asks for!
    • In the example above, we need y (pepper plants), not x (tomato plants)
    • Eliminate the variable you DON'T need to find your answer faster

4. Advanced Word Problems with 3+ Unknowns (The Backsolve Strategy)

  • Key Concept: Questions with 3+ unknowns are MUCH easier if you backsolve
    • Setting up and solving 3 equations algebraically takes forever
    • The answer choices give you the value to test - use them!
    • This strategy is faster, easier, and less error-prone
  • Backsolve Strategy:
    • Step 1: Pick an answer choice (start with B or C - they're usually in the middle)
    • Step 2: Use the relationships in the problem to find the other unknowns
    • Step 3: Check if all conditions are satisfied
    • Step 4: If it works, you're done! If not, try another answer
  • Example: Malik has $738 in $1, $5, and $20 bills. He has 5 more $5 bills than $20 bills, and 6 more $1 bills than $5 bills. How many $1 bills?
    • Answer choices: A) 33 B) 38 C) 48 D) 53
    • Step 1: Try B) 38 $1 bills
    • Step 2: Use relationships to find other values:
    • • He has 6 more $1 bills than $5 bills
    • • So $5 bills = 38 - 6 = 32 bills
    • • He has 5 more $5 bills than $20 bills
    • • So $20 bills = 32 - 5 = 27 bills
    • Step 3: Check total money:
    • • 38($1) + 32($5) + 27($20)
    • • = 38 + 160 + 540
    • • = $738 ✓
    • It works! Answer is B) 38
  • Why Backsolve Works Better:
    • Algebraic solution requires writing 3 equations and complex substitution
    • Backsolve takes 30 seconds with a calculator
    • Much less room for algebra errors
    • The ACT expects you to use this strategy - don't overcomplicate it!
  • When to Use Backsolve:
    • 3 or more unknowns
    • The question asks "how many" and gives you numerical answer choices
    • Word problems with multiple relationships between variables

5. Test-Taking Tips for Systems of Equations

  • Tip #1: Choose your method based on what's given
    • See "y = " or "x = "? → Use SUBSTITUTION
    • Both equations in standard form? → Use ELIMINATION
    • 3+ unknowns with answer choices? → BACKSOLVE
  • Tip #2: For word problems, always define your variables first
    • Write "Let x = number of tomatoes" at the top
    • This prevents confusion when writing equations
    • Double-check which variable the question asks for!
  • Tip #3: Look for "total" and "cost" keywords
    • "Total items" → x + y = [number]
    • "Total cost" → [price₁]x + [price₂]y = [total]
    • These two equations together = classic systems problem
  • Tip #4: When backsolving, start with choice B or C
    • Answer choices are usually in numerical order
    • If B is too small, try C or D
    • If B is too large, try A
    • This narrows down options faster
  • Tip #5: Check your answer makes sense
    • If Mary bought 42 plants total, pepper plants can't be 50!
    • Use logic to eliminate obviously wrong answers
    • This catches careless errors

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓elimination when neither variable is isolated.
  • ✓Word problems require TWO relationships.
  • ✓problems with 3+ unknowns, BACKSOLVE using answer choices—it's faster and less error-prone than algebra.
  • ✓check which variable the question asks for and make sure.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 2.4 - Which Choice Questions
lessons.content:
"Which choice" questions ask you to make specific changes to a sentence, and the question itself tells you exactly what to do. These questions are easy to spot—they always include the words "which choice" or "which one" in the question.

1. How to Identify and Approach These Questions

  • Easy to spot: Look for "which choice" or "which one" in the question
    • The question tells you exactly what change to make
    • All answer choices are usually grammatically correct
  • Your job: Figure out what the question asks and do exactly that
    • Don't worry about grammar, conciseness, or style unless the question specifically asks
    • Shorter is NOT always better on these questions
    • Just answer the question—don't overthink it!

2. Type 1: Specific Detail Questions

  • These ask you to provide or emphasize a specific detail
    • Common phrasing: "most specifically describes," "most clearly emphasizes," "provides the most relevant detail"
    • Focus on the sentence you're editing
    • Read sentences before and after for context, but don't rely on them too heavily

Example: Specific Description

  • Question: "Which choice most specifically describes what was used to build iceboxes?"
  • Context: "Americans kept their food cold in iceboxes, which required ice to be bought and placed into the box each week."
    • A. NO CHANGE
    • B. which were only cold enough to keep food cool but not freeze anything
    • C. wooden boxes with tin and insulated with cork and sawdust
    • D. the very first invention that allowed people to keep food cold
  • ✓ Answer: C—it's the only choice that describes the materials used to build iceboxes

3. Type 2: Emphasis and Tone Questions

  • These ask you to emphasize a particular aspect or create a certain tone
    • Common phrasing: "most clearly emphasizes," "best conveys," "creates the most vivid image"
    • Focus on which word choice highlights the specific quality mentioned

Example: Emphasis

  • Question: "Which choice most clearly emphasizes how the dinosaurs increase in size?"
  • Context: "Harold always begged for grow-in-water dinosaurs that sprawl when placed into water."
    • A. NO CHANGE (sprawl)
    • B. change in size
    • C. expand
    • D. soak
  • ✓ Answer: C—"expand" most clearly emphasizes the size increase

4. Common Question Phrasings

  • Questions asking for specific details
    • "Which choice most specifically describes..."
    • "Which choice provides the most relevant detail about..."
    • "Which choice best supports the claim that..."
  • Questions asking for emphasis or tone
    • "Which choice most clearly emphasizes..."
    • "Which choice best conveys..."
    • "Which choice creates the most vivid image of..."
  • The key strategy: Read the question carefully and give it exactly what it asks for—nothing more, nothing less

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓"Which choice" questions are easy to spot—they always include "which choice" or "which one" in the question.
  • ✓All answer choices are usually grammatically correct.
  • ✓Specific detail questions ask for information about a particular aspect .
  • ✓Emphasis and tone questions ask you to highlight a particular quality or create a certain feeling.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 2.5 - Adding or Deleting Information
lessons.content:
Adding or deleting information questions ask whether specific information should be included in a passage or not. For these questions, you must read for context—we recommend reading the entire paragraph where the question appears to determine if the information fits.

1. How to Approach These Questions

  • Read the paragraph twice: once with the information included and once with it deleted
    • This makes it clear whether the information should be included
    • Consider: Does the information fit the paragraph's focus?
    • Depending on the question, you may need to read more than one paragraph
  • Context is critical
    • You must understand what the paragraph is discussing
    • The information should support or relate to the main idea

2. Adding Information Questions

  • These questions give you a sentence or phrase and ask if it should be added
    • Answer choices have two parts: (1) Yes or No, (2) Justification why
    • First decide yes or no, then pick the correct justification

Critical Strategy: Only Consider What the Sentence Says

  • When evaluating justifications, only consider the sentence being added
    • Many students pick justifications that go far beyond what the sentence says
    • Don't include details that have nothing to do with the sentence itself
    • The justification must accurately describe what that specific sentence provides

Example Structure

  • Question: "Should the writer add this sentence about Dr. Anderson's education?"
    • A. Yes, because it establishes Dr. Paul's mentor's qualifications
    • B. Yes, because it indicates Dr. Anderson had a top-notch education
    • C. No, because it does not indicate where Dr. Paul studied
    • D. No, because it is not relevant to the passage's discussion of Dr. Paul's career
  • If the passage is about Dr. Paul's career, not his mentor's, the answer is D

3. Deleting Information Questions

  • These ask if existing information should be removed
    • Same format: Yes/No + Justification
    • Consider whether the information is relevant and necessary

When to Delete Information

  • Delete when the information:
    • Is irrelevant to the paragraph's main idea
    • Repeats information already stated
    • Distracts from the paragraph's focus
    • Doesn't add anything meaningful
  • Keep when the information:
    • Supports the main idea
    • Provides necessary detail or clarification
    • Connects ideas within the paragraph

4. Common Answer Choice Patterns

  • Good justifications are specific and accurate
    • They describe exactly what the sentence provides
    • They relate to the paragraph's focus
    • Example: "provides specific detail about the location" (if the sentence actually does that)
  • Bad justifications are vague or go too far
    • They claim the sentence says more than it actually does
    • They focus on irrelevant details
    • Example: "proves the scientist was the best in his field" (when sentence only mentions one achievement)

Common Wrong Answer Traps

  • Watch out for justifications that:
    • Reference information NOT in the sentence being added/deleted
    • Make logical leaps beyond what the sentence states
    • Focus on the wrong person, topic, or idea
    • Use absolute language ("proves," "always," "never") when the sentence is less definitive

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Read the paragraph twice—once with the information included and once with it deleted.
  • ✓Answer choices have two parts: Yes or No, Justification.
  • ✓Delete information when it's irrelevant to the main idea, repeats what's already stated.
  • ✓Avoid justifications that reference information NOT in the sentence.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 2.6 - Logical Placement
lessons.content:
Logical placement questions ask you to place a sentence in the paragraph based on context and logical flow. These questions test your ability to recognize where information fits best by reading the sentences before and after each potential placement spot.

1. How to Identify These Questions

  • Logical placement questions are easy to spot because they always ask where to place a sentence
    • Common phrasing: "For the sake of logic and coherence, Sentence X should be placed..."
    • Or: "The sentence would most logically be placed..."
  • Look for bracketed numbers [1] [2] [3] at the beginning of sentences
    • Bracketed numbers only appear when there's a logical placement question
    • Read these paragraphs more carefully—they may currently be out of order
    • The paragraph may seem confusing at first because sentences are misplaced
  • Bracketed letters [A] [B] [C] appear for end-of-passage placement questions
    • Don't worry about the letters while reading—just note there will be a placement question
    • The question will ask where to place a new sentence in the passage

2. The Critical Strategy: Plug and Read

  • To find the correct answer, plug the sentence into each potential spot and re-read
    • Don't just read the sentence before the placement—this is the most common mistake
    • You MUST read the sentence(s) before AND after where you're placing it
    • The correct placement should flow smoothly in both directions

Step-by-Step Approach

  • Step 1: Read the entire paragraph first to understand the overall context
    • Even if it seems confusing, get a sense of the topic and flow
    • Identify what the paragraph is discussing
  • Step 2: Identify the sentence you need to place
    • What specific information does it contain?
    • What does it refer to or connect to?
  • Step 3: Test each answer choice by plugging in the sentence
    • Read from the sentence before → through the placed sentence → to the sentence after
    • Does it create smooth, logical flow?
    • Do pronouns have clear references?
    • Does the information follow a logical sequence?

3. What Makes a Placement Correct

  • The correct placement creates logical flow and coherence
